In summary, Germans prefer more cooperation with Russia than Americans do, while Americans show a slightly greater preference for cooperation with China; these preferences are influenced by political leanings and regional differences within each country.

In the U.S., there are slight partisan differences regarding close relationships with Russia or Germany. Republicans (31%) are more inclined to prefer close relations with Russia than Democrats (21%) [1]. Conversely, Democrats (66%) show a stronger preference for close ties with Germany compared to Republicans (57%) [1]. Increased cooperation with Russia is more favored among Republicans (41%) than Democrats (32%) [11].

In Germany, supporters of CDU/CSU are more willing to cooperate with the U.S. than supporters of the Greens and SPD [6].
![Party alignment in the U.S. and Germany, with percentage values indicating approval or support levels.](image6)
Germans generally show more support for close relationships with both Russia and China compared to Americans [9, 11]. In the former East Germany, there is significantly more support for a close relationship with Russia, with nearly 40% favoring Russia compared to only 23% for the U.S. [10]. West Germans, however, are twice as likely to prefer a close relationship with the U.S. over Russia [10].
![Preferences for U.S., Russia, or Both (VOL) in West and East Germany.](image7)

When it comes to China, Americans are almost equally divided, with 41% preferring Germany and 44% preferring China [9].
![Opinions of Americans and Germans towards choosing between Germany and Russia, and between Germany and China.](image2)
Germans, on the other hand, are about twice as likely to say they prefer a close relationship with the U.S. over China (50% to 24%) [9].

In summary, political divides significantly shape attitudes toward international cooperation, with Republicans in the U.S. showing more openness towards Russia, while Democrats prefer Germany; in Germany, CDU/CSU supporters favor cooperation with the U.S. more than supporters of other parties, and East Germans show greater support for close ties with Russia.

Americans and Germans differ in their views on international cooperation and relationships, with political affiliations playing a significant role in shaping these attitudes [1].

In the U.S., Republicans are more inclined to favor increased cooperation with Russia (41%) compared to Democrats (32%) [8].

In Germany, there are regional differences in attitudes towards Russia, with those in former East Germany being more favorable towards Russia than those in the former West [4].
![Germans in the former East prioritize relations with Russia over U.S.](image4)
Specifically, nearly four-in-ten East Germans prefer close ties with Russia, a view less commonly held in the former West [9]. West Germans are twice likely to prefer a close relationship with the U.S than with Russia [9].

Overall, political and regional affiliations significantly influence views on cooperation with Russia in both the U.S. and Germany.

Americans and Germans have markedly different views on which country is the world's leading economic power. Half of Americans identify the U.S. as the leading economic power, while about a third (32%) believe it is China [3]. In contrast, a majority of Germans (53%) name China as the leading economic power, with only 24% naming the U.S. [3]. This difference is visually represented in a chart. ![The image is a bar chart comparing various percentages related to the U.S., China, Japan, and the EU.](image8)

Regarding international relationships, Germans tend to view various nations and organizations more positively than Americans do [6]. This difference is particularly stark when it comes to views of the EU. Approximately seven-in-ten Germans favor the EU, compared to only about half of Americans [6]. A comparative bar chart illustrates these approval ratings, showing that Germany has an 18% higher approval rating for the EU compared to the U.S.
![The image is a comparative bar chart showing approval ratings of five international entities (EU, Russia, China, UN, and NATO) from the perspectives of three groups: U.S., a 32-country median, and Germany.](image2)

When it comes to specific countries like China, views differ as well. The chart shows that Germany has a +8% difference compared to U.S. approval of China [image2]. Germans are also more likely to consider the U.S. as an important partner than vice versa. ![The image is a comparative bar graph showing the percentages of Americans and Germans who view certain countries as important partners.](image1)

In summary, Americans are more likely to view the U.S. as the leading economic power, while Germans view China as such, and Germans generally have more favorable views of international entities like the EU and China compared to Americans.

Americans and Germans have notably different views of international organizations and which countries are considered economic powers.

Germans generally view international organizations more favorably than Americans [10]. This is particularly evident in their views of the EU, with about 70% of Germans favoring the union, compared to about half of Americans [10]. A similar trend is present regarding the UN and NATO, although there is more consensus [1, 10].
![Comparative views on international entities between the U.S., Germany, and a 32-country median.](image5)

Regarding who is a world-leading economic power, half of Americans name the U.S., while a majority of Germans (53%) name China [7].
![Economic power perception comparison.](image1)

Several factors influence these perceptions, Ideology plays a significant role [2]. Conservative Americans and Germans on the right are more likely to view Russia favorably, while liberals and those on the left are more likely to favor the UN and EU [11].
![Ideological differences in views of the UN, EU, and Russia among Americans and Germans.](image6)

Geographical factors, specifically within Germany, also play an important role. Germans living in former East Germany tend to view Russia more favorably and the EU less favorably than those living in the former West [4].
![Regional preferences within Germany.](image2)

In summary, Americans and Germans differ in their views of international organizations and economic powers due to ideological differences, and, within Germany, geographical location based on former East and West divisions.

Americans are more likely than Germans to believe military force is sometimes necessary to maintain order in the world [9]. Regarding defense spending, half of Americans think that European allies should maintain their current spending levels. [3] Germans are divided on the issue, with about four-in-ten supporting increased spending and a similar proportion favoring maintaining current levels [7].

However, from 2017 to 2019, fewer Americans think European allies need to increase national defense spending. [8]. Specifically among Republicans and Republican-leaning independents who think the U.S.’s European allies should increase their defense budgets has fallen by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019. [2].
![The image is a line graph showing trends over three years, from 2017 to 2019, for two political affiliations: "Republican/Lean Rep" and "Democrat/Lean Dem." ](image1)
Despite these differences, young people in both countries have more positive views of the U.S.-German relationship [11].

In the U.S., 82% of 18- to 29-year-olds say the relationship is good, compared to 73% of those 65 and older [11]. In Germany, 40% of young people see relations as good, compared to 31% of those 65 and older [11].

In summary, Americans are more inclined to support the use of military force and believe in defending NATO allies, while Germans are more divided on defense spending and less likely to support military intervention. Younger people in both countries view the U.S.-German relationship more positively.

There are also ideological differences within each country, with those on the right being more likely to justify the use of force than those on the left [1].

Regarding defense spending, Americans and Germans have differing views. Half of Americans believe European allies should maintain their current defense spending levels, a shift from 2017 when 45% felt spending should increase [12].

In the U.S., Republicans are more likely than Democrats to favor increased defense spending in Europe, although support among Republicans has decreased since 2017 [4].

Americans' opinions on whether European allies should increase defense spending have shifted since 2017. In 2017, 45% of Americans believed European allies should increase spending, but this dropped to 35% by 2019 [3]. Half of Americans in 2019 felt that spending levels should remain the same [3].

Germans are divided on whether to increase or maintain current levels of defense spending [8]. In 2019, 40% of Germans supported an increase, while 41% favored maintaining current levels. This is a change from 2017, when about half of Germans were content with their country's defense spending [8].

Within the U.S., Republicans are more likely than Democrats to favor increased defense spending in Europe [9]. However, the share of Republicans who think European allies should increase their defense budgets has fallen by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019. There has also been a more modest decline in this view among Democrats [9].

In Germany, partisan gaps also emerge [11]. Supporters of the CDU/CSU are generally in favor of defense spending increases, while supporters of the Greens are more skeptical [11].

In summary, American views on European defense spending have become more moderate, with fewer favoring increases, while German public opinion is split between increasing and maintaining spending, and partisan divisions are present in both countries.

Americans' and Germans' views on national defense spending have shifted between 2017 and 2019, with internal partisan differences influencing these perspectives.

In the U.S., the percentage of people who believe European allies should increase their national defense spending has decreased. In 2017, 45% of Americans thought European allies should increase spending. By 2019, this number had dropped to 35%. Meanwhile, the percentage of Americans who believe European allies should maintain their spending levels rose from 37% to 50% in the same period [4].

In Germany, the public is split between increasing or maintaining current defense spending levels. In Germany, younger individuals are more likely to doubt the importance of American military bases. Approximately six-in-ten Germans aged 18 to 29 believe that U.S. military bases in Germany do *not* contribute to German national security [10]. This is illustrated by a chart showing that 62% of Germans aged 18-29 consider the bases "Not important," while only 33% find them "Important" ![Perception of the importance of a certain topic, divided by age groups](image8). Conversely, 61% of Germans aged 65 and older believe the bases *are* important to Germany's defense [10].

In the U.S., perceptions of foreign policy partners are significantly influenced by political affiliation. Republicans and Democrats both agree that the UK is their most important partner [9]. However, Republicans show a stronger preference for Israel (26%) compared to Democrats (9%) [9]. A bar chart visually represents these preferences, highlighting the differing priorities between Republican/Lean Republican and Democrat/Lean Democrat respondents ![The image contains two bar charts comparing the preferences of Republican/Lean Republican and Democrat/Lean Democrat respondents towards certain countries.](image1). Democrats, on the other hand, place more emphasis on Canada and Mexico as key foreign policy affiliates [9]. Despite these differences, both Republicans and Democrats rank Germany similarly, as their fifth most important foreign policy partner [9].

In summary, age plays a significant role in how Germans perceive the importance of U.S. military bases, with younger Germans being more skeptical, while political affiliation in the U.S. influences the prioritization of foreign policy partners, although both parties value Germany similarly.

Americans' views on U.S. global engagement and its handling of international issues, including the coronavirus outbreak, vary significantly based on political affiliation and educational background.

There are notable partisan differences regarding whether the U.S. should focus on its own problems or help other countries. About three-quarters of Republicans prefer the U.S. to deal with its own problems and let other countries manage as best they can [7]. A majority of Democrats believe the U.S. should assist other countries, although this view is more pronounced among liberal Democrats (64%) compared to conservative and moderate Democrats (44%) [3].

![Opinions on whether the U.S. should deal with its own problems or help other countries, broken down by political affiliation and other demographics.](image5)

Educational background also influences these perspectives. Individuals with higher levels of education are more inclined to support the U.S. helping other nations [6]. Specifically, 60% of postgraduates believe the U.S. should assist other countries, while college graduates are evenly split [6]. Conversely, majorities of those with some college experience or a high school diploma or less believe the U.S. should prioritize its own problems [6].

When it comes to handling the coronavirus outbreak, opinions are strongly divided along party lines [11]. Approximately three-quarters of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents criticize the U.S.'s response, while a similar share of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents praise it [11].

![Bar chart showing views on U.S. handling of the coronavirus outbreak, segmented by political affiliation and demographic groups.](image4)

Furthermore, educational attainment correlates with opinions on the U.S. response to the disease. More educated Americans tend to be more critical; around two-thirds of postgraduates and six-in-ten college graduates say the U.S. has done a poor job [10].

In summary, views on U.S. global engagement and its handling of international issues differ greatly, with Republicans and less-educated individuals favoring a focus on domestic issues, while Democrats and more-educated individuals are more inclined to support international aid and are more critical of the U.S.'s handling of the coronavirus.

Americans' perceptions of how the U.S. and China handled the COVID-19 pandemic are significantly influenced by their political affiliations, with educational background playing a smaller, yet notable, role in the perception of the US' response.

Partisan differences are wide regarding the U.S. response [5]. A significant majority of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (71%) praise the country's handling of the outbreak, while a similarly large majority of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents (73%) are critical of it [7]. This partisan divide is visually represented in a bar chart comparing different countries' political leanings, where the U.S. shows a +44 difference between Republicans (71%) and Democrats (27%) in their positive evaluation of the country's response.
![Political leanings towards Democratic/Lean Democrat and Republican/Lean Republican in various countries.](image6)

Education plays some role how people view US'response to COVID-19 [1].
More educated Americans tend to be more critical of the U.S. response. Around two-thirds of those with a postgraduate degree and about six-in-ten college graduates say the U.S. has done a poor job, compared to 43% of those with a high school degree or less [10].
![People's evaluation as "Only fair/poor" or "Good/excellent."](image4)

Regarding China's handling of the pandemic, most Americans are critical, but there are notable partisan differences [2]. While majorities across the political spectrum believe China has not done a good job, Republicans are much more likely to hold this view than Democrats [9]. The data shows that 76% of Republicans and Republican-leaners rate China's response as "Only fair/poor," compared to 54% of Democrats and Democratic-leaners.
![Opinions on a scale of "Only fair/poor" to "Good/excellent" across various demographic groups.](image2)
Education does seem to have impact on views of China's handling of the COVID-19 [1].

In summary, political affiliation is the primary factor influencing perceptions of both the U.S. and China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, with Republicans generally viewing the U.S. response positively and China's negatively, and Democrats holding largely opposite views, while education background affects views of US' handling, and has little effects on opinions of China's handling.

Americans' views on the handling of the COVID-19 pandemic by both the U.S. and China are significantly influenced by their political affiliations [10].

In assessing the U.S. response, there's a wide partisan divide: 71% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents believe the U.S. has done a good or excellent job, compared to only 27% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents [3]. This stark contrast highlights how deeply political views shape the evaluation of the domestic response to the pandemic.
![Political affiliations significantly influence perceptions of how the U.S. handled the pandemic.](image7)

When it comes to China's handling of the virus, partisan differences are also evident, though majorities from both sides agree that China has not done a good job [9]. However, Republicans are much more likely to hold this view. Specifically, eight-in-ten conservative Republicans believe China has not handled the crisis well [9].
![The chart reflects varied opinions influenced by political affiliations and demographics on China's performance.](image8)

Education plays a minor role compared to political affiliation. Instead, clear majorities across all educational levels indicate that China has not managed the pandemic effectively [8].

Overall, the perception of how well both the United States and China have handled the COVID-19 pandemic is heavily influenced by political affiliation, with Republicans generally viewing the U.S. response more favorably and China's response more critically than Democrats.

Americans' views on whether the U.S. can learn from other countries in handling the coronavirus outbreak are significantly divided along political lines. A majority of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents (60%) believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from other countries, while only 28% of Republicans and Republican leaners share this view [5]. This divide is even more pronounced between liberal Democrats and conservative Republicans, with 67% of the former and only 25% of the latter believing the U.S. can learn a great deal [8].

This difference in perception correlates with trust levels in international organizations. For instance, 86% of liberal Democrats trust information from the WHO at least a fair amount, compared to just 27% of conservative Republicans [2]. A similar pattern exists for trust in the EU, with 79% of liberal Democrats and 49% of conservative Republicans trusting information from this source.
![Trust levels in WHO, EU, and Chinese government among different political groups](image3)

The partisan divide extends to assessments of how well the U.S. is handling the outbreak. Those who think the U.S. can learn from other countries tend to evaluate its handling of the pandemic less positively [1]. Only 44% of those open to learning from abroad rate the U.S.'s handling as excellent or good, compared to 63% of those who believe the U.S. cannot learn much from other countries [1].
![Opinions on a certain issue across demographic groups, including political affiliation](image4)

Republicans who believe the U.S. can learn from other nations are more likely than other Republicans to say that other countries are handling the pandemic effectively [9].

In summary, perceptions of the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries in handling the coronavirus differ significantly between political affiliations, with Democrats being more open to learning and having higher trust in international organizations like the WHO and EU, compared to Republicans.

Americans exhibit diverse perspectives on the future influence of the U.S., EU, and China, influenced by political affiliation and education.

Regarding the United States' future influence, there's a noticeable partisan divide. Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to believe the U.S.'s international influence will be strengthened [1]. Democrats, conversely, are about four times more likely than Republicans to expect American influence to weaken [1]. ![Survey results on perceptions of influence by education level and political affiliation.](image1)

Education also plays a role, with Americans who have completed higher levels of education being more likely to think the country's global influence will recede [10].

When it comes to China's influence, half of Americans believe it will decline after the coronavirus outbreak [12]. However, there are significant differences based on political affiliation. Roughly six-in-ten Republicans believe China's international clout will diminish, while just 40% of Democrats say the same [6].
![Bar chart of different demographics' opinions on China's future influence.](image4)

Concerning the European Union, majorities from both parties think the EU’s international influence will be unaffected by the coronavirus outbreak [3]. ![Bar chart comparing opinions across political groups for the EU's future influence.](image8)

In summary, views on future global influence differ significantly, with political affiliation and education level playing key roles in shaping opinions about the U.S., China, and the EU.

Americans were largely split on how they think U.S. influence will be affected by the pandemic [8]. Approximately half of Americans believe China will emerge from the current crisis with less influence in world affairs, while far fewer say this about the U.S. or the European Union [10].

Specifically, regarding China's influence:

*   50% of Americans believe China will have less influence in world affairs after the pandemic [6].
*   Nearly one-in-five think Chinese influence will grow, and about a third think its global standing will be about the same [7].
*  The bar chart shows that 17% said "More," 31% said "About the same," and 50% said "Less" regarding China's global influence. This is broken down further by race, age, and political affiliation. For instance, 63% of Republicans and Republican leaners believe China will have "Less" influence, compared to 40% of Democrats and Democratic leaners. Older adults (65+) are more likely than younger adults (18-29) to predict a decrease in China's influence (59% vs. 43%) [12].
![Perceptions of China's future global influence vary significantly across demographic and political lines, with a majority predicting reduced influence.](image8)

Regarding U.S. influence:

*   Roughly three-in-ten believe the U.S.’s international clout will be bolstered after the outbreak, while the same share thinks it will be weakened. About four-in-ten see the U.S. coming out of the outbreak with the same influence as before [8].

*   Education is also tied to views about how the pandemic will shape America’s role in international affairs, those who have higher education are more likely to forsee its global influence will recede [9].
*   The overall perception shows 29% believe the U.S. will have "More" influence, 41% believe it will be "About the same," and 29% believe it will have "Less" influence.
![Overall opinions are divided, with significant variations across educational and political subgroups.](image5)

There are clear partisan gaps. Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to believe the U.S.’s international influence will be strengthened. Democrats are about four times more likely than Republicans to expect American influence to weaken [3].

In summary, a majority of Americans, especially Republicans and older adults, predict that China's global influence will decrease, while opinions on U.S. influence are more divided, with significant variations across educational levels and political affiliations.

Americans generally view China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak negatively. Nearly two-thirds of Americans believe China has not done a good job [9], with 37% saying the country has done a "poor" job [9]. This negative assessment is visually represented in a chart showing that only a small percentage rated China's performance as "Good" or "Excellent."  ![This image is a bar chart comparing perceptions of performance across various categories for seven entities: South Korea, Germany, UK, U.S., WHO, Italy, and China. Each entity is evaluated on a scale ranging from "Poor" to "Excellent."](image3)

There are significant partisan divisions in these perceptions. Republicans are far more likely than Democrats to hold a negative view of China's handling of the outbreak [2]. Eight-in-ten conservative Republicans, in particular, believe China has not handled the crisis well [2].

Regarding China's future influence, half of Americans think it will decline after the pandemic [11]. The other half is dived between that China's influence will not be impacted and that it will rise. ![This image is a bar chart showing levels of influence.](image7)

A significant partisan divide exists on this question as well. Roughly six-in-ten Republicans believe China's international clout will diminish, while only 40% of Democrats agree [5].

In conclusion, Americans largely disapprove of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak and a majority believe its global influence will decrease, with Republicans notably more critical than Democrats on both counts.

Democrats are about four times more likely than Republicans to expect American influence to weaken after the outbreak [4]. Liberal Democrats are particularly pessimistic, with 56% believing the U.S. will have less influence, compared to just 8% of conservative Republicans [1].

Partisan views significantly differ, with Republicans more likely to think the U.S. does too much globally and Democrats more likely to foresee a decline in U.S. influence post-outbreak.

There are significant partisan divisions regarding the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries and its role in global affairs during the coronavirus pandemic. A majority of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents (60%) believe the U.S. can learn "a great deal" from other countries about ways to slow the spread of the coronavirus, whereas only 28% of Republicans and Republican leaners share this view [11].

This partisan divide is visually represented in a chart:
![Partisan differences in views on learning from other countries.](image5)

Liberal Democrats are much more likely (67%) to believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations compared to conservative Republicans (25%) [5]. In terms of the U.S.'s role in global affairs, 64% of liberal Democrats believe the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems [9]. This contrasts sharply with the views of Republicans, where a smaller percentage believes the U.S. should assist other nations.

Overall, Democrats are more inclined to believe the U.S. can learn from and should assist other countries, while Republicans are more likely to think the U.S. should focus on its own problems.

Americans hold differing views on whether the U.S. should prioritize its own problems or assist other countries, with significant variations across political and educational lines.

Overall, a majority (60%) believe the U.S. should focus on its own problems and let other countries handle their issues independently [4]. This perspective is particularly strong among Republicans and Republican-leaning independents, with 76% favoring this approach [11].
![Various demographics' views on whether the U.S. should deal with its own problems or let other countries deal with their own problems as best they can.](image6)
Conversely, a majority of Democrats and Democratic-leaning individuals (53%) believe the U.S. should help other countries [6]. This view is more pronounced among liberal Democrats (64%) compared to conservative and moderate Democrats (44%) [6].

Educational attainment also plays a crucial role in shaping these opinions. Individuals with higher levels of education are more inclined to support the U.S. helping other nations [3]. Specifically, 60% of postgraduates advocate for assisting other countries, while college graduates are evenly split [3, 4]. In contrast, majorities of those with some college experience or a high school diploma or less believe the U.S. should focus on its own problems [3, 4].

In summary, views on the U.S. dealing with its problems versus helping other countries vary significantly, with Republicans and those with lower educational levels favoring a focus on domestic issues, while Democrats and those with higher education levels are more supportive of international assistance.

Americans express a variety of significant concerns regarding China, with a notable percentage viewing specific issues as very serious problems [2]. These concerns include cyberattacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China's growing military power, and China's human rights policies [12].

Specifically, a high percentage of Americans consider cyberattacks from China (65%) and China's growing military power (52%) as very serious issues. Additionally, the loss of U.S. jobs to China (53%) and China's policies on human rights (50%) are also seen as very serious problems by a substantial portion of the population [7].
![Concerns about China](image7)

Despite these high levels of concern, Americans have relatively less confidence in President Biden's ability to deal effectively with China compared to other foreign policy issues [4, 9]. While 53% of Americans have confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China, this is the lowest percentage among six foreign policy issues tested [5]. The confidence levels vary significantly across demographics.
![Confidence in dealing with China](image4)

There are significant partisan differences, with 83% of Democrats and leaners having confidence in Biden on China, compared to only 19% of Republicans and leaners [7].

In summary, Americans' confidence in Biden's ability to deal effectively with China is moderate (53%) and lower than their confidence in him on other foreign policy matters, despite high levels of concern about specific issues like cyberattacks, military power, job losses, and human rights related to China.

Americans express significant concerns about various aspects of the U.S.-China relationship, with certain issues standing out more prominently. The most pressing concerns are cyberattacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China's growing military power, and China's human rights policies [12]. Specifically, 65% of Americans view cyberattacks from China as a "very serious" problem, while 53% say the same about the loss of U.S. jobs to China [8].
![Concerns about China](image8)

Confidence in President Biden's ability to deal effectively with China varies significantly across different demographic groups. Overall, 53% of Americans have confidence in Biden's ability to handle China effectively [4].
![Confidence in Biden on China](image7)
However, this confidence differs considerably based on political affiliation, gender, race, and education level [7, 10]. For instance, Democrats and those leaning Democratic have significantly higher confidence (83%) in Biden's ability to deal with China compared to Republicans and those leaning Republican (19%) [7]. Women (59%) are more confident than men (48%), and Black (82%) and Hispanic adults (70%) express more confidence than White adults (43%) [10]. Additionally, those with a college degree show higher confidence levels (60%) compared to those without a college degree (50%) [10].

In summary, confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China varies widely across demographics, with the highest confidence among Democrats, women, Black and Hispanic adults, and college graduates, and Americans are most concerned about cyberattacks, job losses, China's military power, and human rights issues.

Americans have distinct perceptions of China in different contexts. Regarding China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, a majority of Americans (54%) believe China has done a bad job [2, 4]. Americans across the political spectrum show a strong inclination to prioritize human rights over economic gains in their relationship with China [1, 6]. A significant majority, 70% of Americans, believe that the U.S. should promote human rights in China, even if it harms economic relations [6]. This sentiment is largely consistent across party lines, with Democrats and Republicans largely agree [7].

Specifically, 72% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents favor prioritizing human rights, with conservative Republicans showing even stronger support at 77% [2].
![Prioritize human rights or economic relations, by political affiliation.](image2)
Among Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents, 69% prioritize human rights, and this view is particularly strong among liberal Democrats, at 76% [2].

Americans across the political spectrum show a strong inclination to prioritize human rights in China, even at the expense of economic relations. However, when it comes to economic and trade policies with China, there's a partisan divide. This is particularly pronounced among conservative Republicans, with 81% favoring a tougher stance [12]. In contrast, about six-in-ten Democrats and Democrat-leaning independents would rather focus on building stronger ties with China [12].

American opinions on trade policies with China vary significantly across political affiliations. A majority (51%) of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents believe these tariffs are "Good for the U.S.," with this belief being even stronger among conservative Republicans (61%) [5].

In contrast, Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents largely see these tariffs as detrimental [5]. A majority (60%) believe that increased tariffs were "Bad for the U.S." [9].

A significant majority (72%) of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents prefer the U.S. to "Get tougher" with China on economic issues, a sentiment particularly strong among conservative Republicans (81%) [2, 5].

On the other hand, about 60% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents favor "Building a stronger relationship" with China [2, 5].

Overall, different political affiliations in the U.S. have divergent views on the impact of trade policies with China, directly influencing their preference for either a tougher stance or stronger relationship.

![Perspectives of different political groups on whether they believe something is "Bad for the U.S.," has "No real effect," or is "Good for the U.S."](image2)

In summary, Democrats generally view international students more favorably and tariffs more negatively than Republicans, with significant differences in opinion regarding limiting Chinese students in the U.S.

A majority of Americans (55%) support limiting Chinese students studying in the U.S. [8]. This sentiment varies significantly across age and political affiliation.

Older Americans are more likely to support restrictions. Roughly 70% of those aged 50 and older favor limiting Chinese students [7], while nearly two-thirds of Americans aged 18 to 29 oppose the idea [7].
![Opinions on limiting Chinese students in U.S., by age.](image4)

Republicans are more likely to support limits on Chinese students than Democrats. [7, 4]. Specifically, 69% of Republicans and Republican-leaning individuals support these limitations, compared to only 42% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning individuals [4].
![Opinions on limiting Chinese students in U.S., by political affiliation.](image4)

This difference in opinion may correlate with differing levels of confidence in Chinese leadership. Older Americans, who are more supportive of limiting Chinese students, are also more likely to have no confidence in Chinese President Xi Jinping [10]. Republicans, who are also more supportive of student limitations, express greater distrust in Xi compared to Democrats [4, 12].
![Confidence levels in Chinese President Xi Jinping, by demographic groups.](image6)

In summary, older Americans and Republicans are more likely to support limiting Chinese students in U.S. universities, and this is related to the groups lower confidence in the Chinese leadership.

American perceptions of China have grown increasingly negative from 2018 to 2021 [9]. In 2018, 46% of Americans reported feeling "cold" (a rating of 0 to 49 on a "feeling thermometer") toward China. By 2021, this percentage had risen significantly to 67% [7]. The intensity of these negative feelings has also increased, with the share of Americans reporting "very cold" feelings (0-24 on the thermometer) doubling from 23% to 47% [1].
![Americans have grown increasingly negative in how they view China.](image4)

This shift is evident across both Republicans and Democrats, although the increase is more pronounced among Republicans. The percentage of Republicans feeling "very cold" toward China rose from 31% since 2018, up to 62%. Among Democrats, the increase was 21%, reaching 38% [3].

Several key issues are driving these increasingly negative perceptions. Human rights concerns are a major factor [11].
![Breakdown of public perceptions of China into themes.](image1)
One-in-five Americans mentioned human rights concerns, with specific attention given to China's treatment of Uyghurs in Xinjiang [10]. Half of Americans view China's human rights policies as a very serious problem for the U.S., up 7% since 2020 [5, 8].

Economic concerns are also prominent. Many Americans mentioned China's powerful economy and dominance in manufacturing, sometimes referencing the negative impact of these factors on environment or workers [4]. Approximately 64% of Americans describe the economic relations between the U.S. and China as "somewhat or very bad" [4].

Other significant concerns include cyberattacks from China, job losses to China, and China's growing technological and military power [8].
![The change in percentage from 2020 to 2021 on various issues related to China.](image6)

Limiting China's power and influence has become an increasingly important foreign policy priority for Americans [6]. Nearly half (48%) believe it should be a top priority, an increase of 16 percentage points since 2018 [6].

In summary, American perceptions of China have become substantially more negative between 2018 and 2021, driven by concerns over human rights, economic practices, cyberattacks, and China's growing power and influence.

Americans have expressed substantial concerns regarding various aspects of the U.S.-China relationship [3]. Key concerns include cyberattacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China's growing military power, and China's human rights policies [3]. These issues stand out as very serious problems for half or more Americans [3].

Specifically, the concern about cyberattacks from China has increased from 58% in 2020 to 65% in 2021. Similarly, concerns about China's human rights policies have risen from 43% to 50% during the same period [1]. The loss of U.S. jobs to China and China's growing military power have also seen increases in concern.
![Chart showing increased concerns over China from 2020 to 2021](image2)

Americans also noted China’s powerful economy and its dominance as a manufacturing center, sometimes at the expense of the environment or workers [10].
![Public perceptions related to China](image8)

The image data shows a growing trend of Americans who consider limiting China's power and influence a top priority, and an increasing percentage who feel "cold" toward China.
![The trend of public opinions of China from 2018 to 2021](image7)

Republicans are significantly more likely to have concerns.
![Republicans are more concerned about China than Democrats.](image1)

In summary, the key concerns of Americans regarding China include cyberattacks, job losses, military and technological growth, and human rights, with these concerns having increased significantly from 2020 to 2021.

Latino subgroups have generally become more optimistic about their finances since 2008 [6]. Specifically, eight-in-ten Latinos (81%) reported in 2015 that they expected their family's financial situation to improve in the coming year, marking a 14 percentage point increase since 2008 [4]. This increase in optimism is seen across various demographics, including both U.S.-born and immigrant Hispanics, with each group's hopeful views rising by 14 percentage points to 81% [3].

![Comparison of 2008 and 2015 financial optimism among various demographics.](image8)

Further breakdowns reveal that Latino men's optimism increased by 18 percentage points, while Latina women's optimism increased by 11 percentage points [3]. Optimism among Latinos who had completed some college rose by 20 percentage points [9]. The age group analyses indicate that younger Latinos are more optimistic than older Latinos, there are significant increases across all age groups [1, 2].

![Data related to the perceived economic well-being of different Hispanic groups.](image2)

Compared to the general population, Latinos' financial optimism has risen more rapidly [5]. The share of Latinos expecting financial improvement increased by 14 percentage points from 67% in 2008 to 81% in 2015. In contrast, the general population's optimism rose by 6 percentage points, from 56% in 2008 to 61% in 2015 [5, 6].
![Survey results from 2004 to 2015, comparing the percentage of favorable opinions between Hispanics and the General public.](image5)

In Summary, financial optimism among different Hispanic subgroups significantly increased from 2008 to 2015, outpacing the growth in optimism seen in the general population during the same period.

Hispanics' current financial situations and educational levels significantly influence their expectations for their children's financial futures.

A large majority (72%) of Hispanic adults expect their children to be better off financially than they are [1, 7]. This optimism is visualized in a chart showing that across various demographics within the Hispanic community, the majority believe their children will be "better off" [3].
![Perceived economic well-being of different Hispanic groups](image3)

However, expectations vary based on current financial situations. Hispanics with a positive view of their current finances are more likely to believe their family's finances will improve [4].
![People's expectations about how their financial conditions will change based on their current financial situation](image8)

Educational attainment also plays a role in these expectations. Among those with less than a high school education, 71% expect their children to be better off, while 79% of high school graduates hold this expectation [10]. The optimism slightly dips to 69% for those with some college experience or more [10].

In conclusion, while most Hispanics are optimistic about their children's financial futures, those with better current financial situations and those who are high school graduates are the most optimistic, with educational attainment beyond high school slightly tempering, but not erasing, this optimism.

Latinos have become more optimistic about their personal finances and future prospects since the Great Recession [1]. The share of Latinos who expect their family finances to improve has risen significantly, up 14 percentage points from 67% in 2008 and 2011 to 81% in 2015 [4]. This optimism extends to their children's financial future, with 72% of Hispanic adults expecting their children to be better off financially than they are [3, 11].

![Opinions of Hispanic individuals have remained generally higher than the general public from 2004 to 2015.](image4)

However, economic indicators present a mixed picture [6]. While the unemployment rate for Latinos has improved since the Great Recession, falling from a high of 12.8% in the first quarter of 2010 to 6.4% in the last quarter of 2015, it remains above its 2006 low of 5% [6, 7].
![The graph shows fluctuations in unemployment rates, with Hispanic rates consistently higher than non-Hispanic rates throughout the period.](image7)
Median household income for Hispanics has stagnated since the Great Recession, and their poverty rate, while less than its peak in 2010, remains above pre-recession levels [5].
![The image visually demonstrates the economic disparity between Hispanic households and the broader U.S. population in terms of income, poverty rate, and wealth.](image2)

In summary, while Latinos are increasingly optimistic about their financial well-being, with many anticipating improvements for themselves and their children, unemployment rates, although declining, are still higher than pre-recession levels, indicating a complex economic reality.

The unemployment rate for Hispanics has consistently been higher than that for non-Hispanics from 2000 to 2015 [8]. Despite this, the Hispanic unemployment rate has improved since the Great Recession, dropping from a high of 12.8% in the first quarter of 2010 to 6.4% in the last quarter of 2015 [8]. However, it still remains above its low of 5% in the fourth quarter of 2006 [8].
![Unemployment rates comparison between Hispanic and non-Hispanic groups from 2000 to 2015](image8)

Latino perceptions of their economic well-being have increased [1]. This is reflected in their expectations for their children's financial futures, with 72% saying they expect their children will be better off financially than they are [4].
![The pie chart shows that 72% of people feel better off.](image1)
However, the median household income for Hispanics has stagnated since the Great Recession, remaining at $42,491 in 2014 [2]. The poverty rate for Hispanics in 2014 was 23.6%, lower than the peak of 26.5% in 2010 but still above pre-recession levels [2].
![Income, poverty, and wealth trends](image2)

In summary, while Hispanics have a more positive outlook on their economic situation and future, their unemployment rates remain higher than those of non-Hispanics, and their income and wealth have not fully recovered since the Great Recession.

The economic challenges faced by Hispanic households present a complex picture when compared to all U.S. households from 2000 to 2015.

In terms of unemployment, Hispanic rates have consistently been higher than those of non-Hispanics throughout the period [7]. This is visually represented in a line graph, which shows fluctuations in unemployment rates, with the Hispanic rate consistently above the non-Hispanic rate. ![Unemployment rates for Hispanic and non-Hispanic groups from 2000 to 2015](image4)

Regarding median household income, Hispanic households experienced stagnation since the Great Recession, with a median income of $42,491 in 2014, a level essentially unchanged since that time [8]. In contrast, all US household's median income are higher than Hispanic households. ![Median household income trends for Hispanic households versus all U.S. households.](image5)

The poverty rate for Hispanic households in 2014 was 23.6%, notably higher than the 14.8% rate for all U.S. households [8]. ![Poverty rates of Hispanic households compared to all U.S. households.](image5)

Finally, concerning wealth, Hispanic households had a significantly lower median wealth of $13,700 in 2013, compared to $81,400 for all U.S. households. ![Disparity in median household wealth between Hispanic households and all U.S. households.](image5)

In summary, Hispanic households faced greater economic challenges than U.S. households overall, with higher unemployment and poverty rates, lower median household income, and significantly lower median household wealth.

In 2015, 40% of Latinos reported their personal finances were in "excellent" or "good" shape, a 17 percentage point increase since 2008 [10]. This is visually represented by a line graph showing an increase in favorable opinions among Hispanics from 23% in 2008 to 40% in 2015. ![Trends in favorable opinion of personal finances.](image5)

Gains were observed across most major Latino demographic subgroups [8]. For instance, positive views of economic well-being rose by 16 percentage points among Latino men and 18 points among Latina women [6]. A bar chart details these gains, showing increases across various demographics, including nativity, generation, gender, education, and age [6]. ![Percent of each group that rates its personal finances as “excellent” or “good,” by demographic group.](image6)

However, perceptions of family income relative to the cost of living remained largely unchanged between 2014 and 2015 [4]. In 2015, about 53% of Latinos said their family income was not keeping up with the cost of living [11].
The perceptions of family income relative to cost of living is showed in a bar chart. ![Family income relative to cost of living, 2014 and 2015](image1)

In summary, perceptions of personal financial situations among Latinos significantly improved from 2008 to 2015, while their views on family income relative to the cost of living remained stable.

Internet usage and device ownership among seniors differ significantly from the general adult population. While a majority of adults aged 65 and over do go online (59%), this is notably lower than the 86% of all adults [2]. Similarly, broadband adoption is lower among seniors (47%) compared to all adults (70%) [2].

![Internet and broadband use among seniors compared to all adults.](image2)

Device ownership also shows distinct differences. 77% of seniors own a cell phone, compared to 91% of all adults [2]. Smartphone ownership is particularly low among seniors, at only 18%, in stark contrast to 55% for all adults [6].

![Smartphone and tablet ownership percentages for all adults and people aged 65 and over.](image6)

However, once seniors are online, they tend to be active users. Among older adults who use the internet, 71% go online every day or almost every day, and another 11% go online three to five times per week [1, 7].
![Frequency of internet usage among different age groups.](image4)

Affluent and well-educated seniors tend to adopt the internet and broadband at substantially higher rates than those with lower income and educational attainment. [6, 7].
Internet use and broadband adoption decrease starting around age 75. [8, 11]. For instance, smartphone ownership drops to 10% for 75-79 year-olds and to 5% for those 80 and older [5, 10].

![Internet use and broadband availability decrease with age.](image8)

In summary, while internet usage and device ownership, especially smartphones, are lower among seniors compared to the general adult population, a significant portion of seniors who do go online use the internet daily.

Technology adoption rates differ significantly between older adults (65+) and the general adult population. While 59% of seniors report using the internet [6], this trails the national average of 86% for all U.S. adults.
![Technology adoption rates are lower for those over 65 compared to the general adult population.](image1)
Smartphone ownership is much lower among older adults (18%) compared to the general population (over 50%) [7]. Interestingly, tablet and e-book reader ownership is more prevalent among seniors (27%) than smartphone ownership [4].
![Tablet and e-reader ownership is more prevalent among seniors than smartphone ownership.](image6)
Even though internet usage is lower overall, a significant majority of older adults who do go online use the internet regularly. 71% of older internet users go online daily or almost daily [5].
![A significant majority of senior internet users are online daily.](image3)
Factors like age, education, and income impact these numbers, as usage and ownership vary across demographics within the 65+ age group.
![Internet use and broadband access decrease with age within the 65+ group.](image7)

In conclusion, device ownership among older adults shows a preference for tablets and e-readers over smartphones, while their internet usage, though lower than the general population, is still significant and frequent among those who are online.

Technology adoption rates vary significantly between seniors (adults aged 65 and older) and the general adult population. Smartphone ownership is much lower among seniors at 18%, compared to 55% for all adults [1, 5]. Conversely, seniors show a higher rate of ownership for tablets or e-readers (27%) than for smartphones (18%) [1].
![Chart showing different rates of technology ownership between all adults and people over 65.](image1)
Internet usage among seniors has steadily increased over time. In 2000, only about 14% of seniors were online, but by 2013, that number rose to 59% [6, 11].
![Line graph tracking internet usage for all adults vs. those aged 65+.](image4)
Even though 59% of seniors go online, this still trails the general adult population, where 86% are online [11].
![Technology usage rates show that adults lead seniors in cell phone, internet, and broadband adoption.](image3)
Within the senior population, certain demographics show higher rates of technology use. Factors such as higher education levels and higher income correlate with increased internet and broadband adoption [8, 12]. A significant portion of older adults (27%) also engage with social networking sites [4, 9].
![The pie chart presents the proportion of older adults according to their online usage.](image2)

In summary, seniors have lower smartphone adoption but similar or higher tablet/e-reader ownership compared to the general adult population, and their internet usage, while growing, still lags behind overall adult usage.

Among older adults, the adoption of online social networking differs significantly from their device ownership trends. While a substantial portion of seniors own devices like tablets and e-readers, a smaller percentage actively use social networking sites (SNS).

Specifically, 27% of seniors own a tablet or an e-reader, or both, whereas 18% own a smartphone [7]. This is visually represented by a bar chart showing that 18% of individuals aged 65 and over own a smartphone, while 27% own a tablet or e-reader.
![Device ownership comparison between all adults and people aged 65 and over](image3)

However, only 27% of the total older adult population uses social networking sites such as Facebook [4]. A pie chart illustrates this, showing that 27% of seniors use SNS, 32% go online but don't use SNS, and 41% do not go online at all.
![Online usage distribution of older adults.](image4)
Although 59% of seniors report using the internet [8], many do not engage with social media platforms [1].

In summary, while many seniors have embraced devices like tablets and e-readers, a smaller proportion uses social networking sites.

Internet and broadband adoption rates among seniors show significant variations based on age, education, and income, and generally lag behind the overall adult population [1]. As of the data provided, 59% of seniors (aged 65 and older) report using the internet, a notable increase from previous years but still substantially lower than the 86% of all U.S. adults who go online [1].

The breakdown of internet and broadband use among seniors reveals several key trends:

*   **Age:** Internet use and broadband adoption decrease significantly around age 75 [3, 5]. For instance, 74% of seniors aged 65-69 go online, and 65% have broadband at home. These percentages drop to 37% and 21%, respectively, for those aged 80 and older [6].
*   **Education:** Seniors with higher educational attainment have much higher adoption rates. 87% of college-educated seniors go online, and 76% have broadband, compared to 40% and 27%, respectively, for those with a high school education or less [6].
*   **Income:** Affluent seniors also exhibit higher adoption rates. 90% of seniors with a household income of $75,000 or more use the internet, and 82% have broadband. In contrast, among seniors with an income below $30,000, only 39% go online, and 25% have broadband [6].

These disparities are visually represented in the following table:

![The table shows the percentage of people aged 65 and older who go online and have broadband at home, categorized by age, education, and household income.](image6)

The trends indicate that younger, more educated, and higher-income seniors have internet and broadband adoption rates that approach or even exceed those of the general population in some cases [5, 7]. Conversely, older seniors, those with lower levels of education and income, are much less connected to online life [2, 8].

The trend of increasing internet usage across years is also clear, as the image below show:

![This image shows a line graph depicting trends over time from 2000 to 2013. It compares two groups: "All Adults 18+" and "65+".](image5)

In Summary, while internet and broadband adoption rates among seniors are increasing, they vary considerably based on age, education, and income, with significant disparities compared to the general adult population.

Internet and broadband adoption rates among seniors vary significantly based on income and education levels [9].

Among seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more, 90% go online and 82% have broadband at home [8]. Fully 87% of seniors with a college degree go online, and 76% are broadband adopters [6].
![The table shows the percentage of people aged 65 and older who go online and have broadband at home, categorized by age, education, and household income.](image3)
In contrast, among seniors earning less than $30,000 annually, 39% go online and 25% have broadband at home [8]. Among seniors who have not attended college, 40% go online and just 27% have broadband at home [8].

Cell phone adoption is high among seniors, with 77% owning cell phones [12].
![The table shows the percentage of people aged 65 and older who own cell phones and smartphones, broken down by age, education, and household income.](image8)
Smartphone adoption, however, is lower, with just 18% of seniors owning a smartphone [3].
![The image is a bar chart showing the percentage of ownership of smartphones and tablets or e-readers among two groups: all adults and people aged 65 and over. ](image4)

Income and education are strongly correlated with internet and technology usage among seniors.

Internet and smartphone adoption rates among older adults (65+) vary significantly based on income and education levels, mirroring trends seen in the general population, but generally at lower rates.

For internet usage, a clear majority of seniors, 59%, report going online, and 47% have a high-speed broadband connection at home [8]. However, these numbers differ greatly when examined by income and education:
*   90% of seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more go online, and 82% have broadband at home.
*   87% of seniors who are college graduates go online, with 76% having broadband [1].
These figures contrast sharply with seniors who have not attended college or have an annual income of less than $30,000, where overall adoption levels are much lower [12]. Specifically, among those with lower incomes, only 39% go online, and 25% have broadband [1].
![Table showing internet and broadband adoption rates for seniors by age, education, and income.](image1)

Smartphone ownership among seniors also shows a disparity based on income and education:
*   Only 18% of seniors overall are smartphone adopters [10].
*    Among seniors with an income of $75,000 or more, 42% own a smartphone [9].
*   35% of college-graduate seniors own a smartphone[4].
In comparison, smartphone ownership is much lower among seniors with less income and education. For those earning less than $30,000 annually, only 8% own a smartphone, and for those who are high school graduates or less, the figure is 10% [4].
![Table showing cell phone and smartphone ownership rates for seniors by age, education, and income.](image4)

Overall trends show that 77% of seniors own cell phones, but smartphones remain rare within the 65-and-older population [7]. Fully 77% of senior use cell phone [5]. While cell phone ownership is high across all demographics, smartphone adoption decreases substantially for seniors in their mid-70s and becomes nearly non-existent among those in their 80s and beyond [6].

In summary, internet and smartphone adoption rates among older adults are significantly higher for those with greater income and higher education levels, but these rates are generally lower than the overall trends for all adults.

Internet usage and broadband adoption among seniors are significantly influenced by their educational background. Seniors with higher educational levels are much more likely to use the internet and have broadband connections at home. For example, 87% of seniors who are college graduates go online, and 76% have broadband at home [1].

This contrasts sharply with seniors who have a high school education or less. Only 40% of this group goes online, and a mere 27% have broadband at home. Seniors with some college education fall in between, with 69% going online and 57% having broadband [1].
![Internet and broadband adoption rates vary by education](image1)

Smartphone ownership also varies considerably based on educational attainment. Among seniors who are college graduates, 35% own a smartphone. This rate drops to 19% for those with some college education, and further down to just 10% for seniors with a high school education or less [8].
![Smartphone ownership by education](image8)
These differences highlight how education is a key factor influencing technology adoption among seniors.

In summary, internet usage and smartphone ownership are significantly higher among seniors with higher educational attainment compared to those with lower educational levels.

Internet and broadband adoption, as well as cell phone and smartphone ownership, varies significantly among seniors based on education and income levels.

Among seniors with a college degree, 87% go online, and 76% have broadband at home [2]. This same group shows high rates of cell phone ownership (87%) but significantly lower smartphone ownership (35%) [5].
![Internet and Broadband Adoption by Education](image2)
In contrast, seniors who have not attended college have much lower rates: 40% go online, and only 27% have broadband at home [12]. Cell phone ownership is at 70% in this group, and smartphone ownership is only 10% [5].
![Cell Phone and Smartphone Ownership by Education](image5)

When looking at income, 90% of seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more go online, and 82% have broadband [12]. This high-income group also has high cell phone ownership (92%) and the highest smartphone ownership among seniors at 42% [5]. Seniors earning less than $30,000 annually show much lower adoption rates: 39% go online, and 25% have broadband at home [12]. Cell phone ownership among this lower-income group is at 67%, with smartphone ownership at a mere 8% [5].

In summary, higher education and income levels correlate with higher rates of internet and broadband adoption, as well as cell phone and smartphone ownership among seniors.

Broadband adoption among seniors varies significantly based on both educational attainment and household income. Seniors with higher education levels are much more likely to have broadband at home [9]. Specifically, 76% of seniors with a college degree have broadband, compared to just 27% of those who have not attended college [9].

![Broadband and online access for seniors by age, education, and income](image5)

Similarly, household income plays a crucial role in broadband adoption among seniors [9]. For those earning $75,000 or more annually, 82% have broadband at home [9]. In stark contrast, only 25% of seniors earning less than $30,000 annually have a broadband connection [9].

These differences highlight a digital divide among seniors, where access to high-speed internet is strongly correlated with both education and income levels.

In summary, broadband adoption at home among seniors is significantly higher for those with a college education and higher household income compared to those with lower education levels and lower incomes.

Tablet and e-book reader adoption among seniors is significantly influenced by their education level [4, 12]. Seniors who have graduated from college are approximately three times more likely to own both an e-book reader and a tablet compared to seniors who have not attended college [12]. Specifically, 30% of college graduates aged 65 and older use e-book readers, and 31% use tablets. In contrast, among those with a high school education or less, only 12% use e-book readers, and 11% use tablets. For seniors with some college education, the adoption rates are 19% for both e-book readers and tablets.
![Tablet and E-book Reader Usage by Education Level Among Seniors](image8)

This trend mirrors the general population, where technology adoption, including tablets and e-book readers, is most prevalent among college graduates and higher-income Americans [12]. When observing technology adoption trends across different age groups over time, it's clear that younger age groups consistently show higher usage rates.

![Technology Adoption Trends Over Time](image1)

For example, the 18-29 age group had the highest usage percentage in 2006 and reached 90% by 2013, while the 65+ age group, although showing consistent growth, reached only 46% by the same year [image1].

In summary, education level significantly boosts the adoption of tablets and e-book readers among seniors, similar to broader national trends, while younger age groups generally exhibit higher technology usage rates compared to older adults.

Workforce technologies have different impacts depending on educational levels [1]. Those with higher education levels, such as college graduates, tend to view technology more positively, stating that it makes their work more engaging and increases career opportunities [1, 2]. Specifically, 64% of college graduates find their work more interesting and 53% see increased opportunities for career advancement because of technology [2].

Many Americans foresee significant changes due to automation technologies, particularly with the advent of driverless vehicles [1]. The majority, around two-thirds of the public, expect that most vehicles on the road will be driverless within the next half-century, and 9% believe this will happen within the next 10 years [1]. This anticipation reflects a broader expectation of how automation will reshape daily life and work [10].

In contrast, current experiences with workforce technologies present a more mixed view [4]. Many workers acknowledge the positive impacts of technologies such as word processing, spreadsheet software, smartphones, and email [8]. For example, 70% of workers feel that word processing or spreadsheet software has positively impacted their careers [8]. Similarly, 67% report a positive impact from smartphones, and 60% from email or social media [8].

However, these positive perceptions are not universal and largely depend on the workers' educational backgrounds [6]. A detailed breakdown shows that higher educational attainment correlates with a more positive view of technology's impact:
![Perceived impact of various technologies by educational groups](image2)

The positive views also extend to how technology has made work more interesting and increased opportunities for career advancement [12]. Specifically, 53% of workers feel that technology has made their work more interesting, and 46% believe it has increased their opportunities for advancement [12].

However, a significant share of workers views these technologies neutrally or even negatively [5]. While many have benefited, those without a college education are less likely to see these technologies in a positive light [6].

In summary, while many Americans anticipate significant future impacts from automation like driverless vehicles, the current workforce experiences with technology are varied, with substantial positive impacts reported, especially among those with higher education, but also notable portions experiencing neutral or negative effects.

Workers with higher levels of education tend to have a more positive outlook on workplace technologies. Specifically, college graduates are more likely than those with a high school diploma or less to report that technology has made their work more engaging. The percentage breakdown shows that 64% of college graduates found their work more interesting due to technology, compared to 38% of those with a high school diploma or less [8].

![Bar chart showing differences in perception of technology impact by education level.](image1)

In terms of career advancement, 53% of college graduates believe technology has increased their opportunities, whereas only 32% of workers with a high school diploma or less share this view [8]. These differences are also evident in the perceived impact of specific technologies. For example, 90% of workers with college degrees feel that office productivity tools like word processing or spreadsheet software have had a positive impact, compared to only 45% of those with a high school diploma or less [1].

![Educational Attainment vs Technology Positivity](image4)

The survey reveals that college graduates have markedly more positive views on the impact of workplace technologies on their jobs or careers [11]. In contrast, a substantial share of workers with high school diplomas or less say that technology has not significantly impacted their careers, either positively or negatively [7].

In conclusion, perceptions of workplace technologies differ significantly by education level, with college-educated workers reporting more positive impacts on job interest and career opportunities compared to those with a high school education or less.

Workers with higher levels of education tend to have a more positive view of workplace technologies [7]. Specifically, college graduates are more likely to report that technology has made their work more interesting and increased their opportunities for career advancement [12].

Americans' awareness of automation significantly impacts their views on machines taking over human jobs. Those who have heard a lot about this concept show a greater sense of its realism. Specifically, 48% of those who have "Heard a lot" believe the concept seems extremely realistic. ![The concept seems extremely realistic to 48% of those who have heard a lot.](image1)

Even with increased awareness, the level of worry remains high. Among those who have heard a lot, 76% express some level of worry. ![76% of people who have heard a lot are worried about concept.](image1) This concern is comparable to those with less awareness [5].

In terms of expected outcomes, a majority of Americans foresee negative consequences. Roughly three-quarters (76%) expect greater economic inequality [4], and 64% anticipate people will have difficulty finding fulfilling activities [7].
![Inequality between rich and poor will be much worse than today according to 76% of people.](image6) Only 25% believe that the economy will create many new, well-paying jobs for humans [12].

In summary, Americans' awareness of automation leads to a higher perception of realism and sustained worry, with a majority anticipating negative outcomes such as increased inequality and job displacement.

Americans show a range of opinions on policies related to workforce automation, with notable differences between Democrats and Republicans. A significant partisan divide exists regarding government intervention in the form of a universal basic income and a national service program [7]. Democrats and those leaning Democratic are more supportive of a guaranteed income (77%) and a national service program (66%) compared to Republicans and those leaning Republican, who show less support (38% and 46%, respectively) [12].
![Public opinion on four policies.](image1)
However, there's more consensus on limiting machines to dangerous and unhealthy jobs, with no major partisan differences [12].
![Support levels by party for various policies.](image6)
The vast majority of Americans, regardless of party affiliation, support limiting machines to performing dangerous and dirty jobs [1]. Specifically, 85% of Democrats and 86% of Republicans favor this policy [6].

In summary, while Democrats are more supportive of government interventions like guaranteed income and national service programs in response to workforce automation, both Democrats and Republicans overwhelmingly agree on limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs.

Political affiliations significantly influence opinions on the government's obligation to care for workers displaced by automation [4, 10]. Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are much more supportive of the government providing for displaced workers, even if it requires raising taxes, with 65% agreeing with this view [4]. Conversely, 68% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents believe individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being, even if jobs are widely automated [4].
![Opinions on government obligations and automation limits, by political affiliation and education.](image8)
Education levels have a notable impact on opinions about limiting the number of jobs businesses can replace with machines [6, 10]. Support for limiting automation is much higher among those with lower levels of educational attainment [6]. 70% of individuals with a high school diploma or less believe there should be limits on job automation, compared to only 41% of those with a four-year college degree [6, 8]. However, educational differences are less pronounced on the question of government obligation, with similar responses across education levels [6].

In summary, political affiliation strongly shapes views on government responsibility for displaced workers, while education level significantly influences opinions on limiting job automation by businesses.

Political affiliation significantly influences American views on policies concerning workforce automation and job displacement. Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are notably more supportive of a universal basic income and a national service program compared to Republicans and Republican-leaning independents [4, 9].

Specifically, 77% of Democrats favor a universal basic income, while only 38% of Republicans support this idea [4]. Similarly, 66% of Democrats favor a national service program, compared to 46% of Republicans [4].
![Support for policies by political affiliation](image6)
However, there is more alignment between the parties on other policies. For instance, the vast majority of Americans, regardless of party affiliation, support limiting machines to performing dangerous and dirty jobs [9]. Additionally, similar percentages of Democrats (60%) and Republicans (54%) believe there should be limits on the number of jobs businesses can replace with robots or computers [11, 4].
![Opinions on automation and job displacement, by political affiliation](image1)
There are notable partisan divisions regarding the government's obligation to assist workers displaced by machines [2]. 65% of Democrats believe the government should take care of displaced workers, even if it means higher taxes, whereas 68% of Republicans believe individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being [3].

In summary, political affiliation strongly affects views on government intervention in workforce automation, with Democrats generally more supportive of measures like universal basic income and national service programs than Republicans.

Overall, attitudes towards workforce automation and technology's impact vary significantly across different age groups and education levels.
