Social media evokes a range of emotional responses, varying significantly across different age groups. The most commonly reported emotion is amusement, with 88% of users experiencing this either frequently or sometimes [5]. A significant portion of users (44%) frequently feel amused by the content they encounter [5].

However, the experience is not uniformly positive. A considerable share of users (71%) also report feeling angry due to social media content, with 25% experiencing this frequently [7].
![Different emotions felt with its frequency](image7)

Younger adults (18-29) are more likely to report stronger emotional reactions. For instance, 54% frequently feel amused, while 27% frequently feel angry [6, 8]. They are also more prone to feeling lonely (15%) and depressed (17%) compared to older age groups [7, 8].
![Emotional responses of different age groups to humorous or amusing content.](image8)
Older adults (65+) show a more balanced emotional response, with 30% frequently feeling amused and 24% frequently feeling angry [6, 7]. Other frequently observed behaviors include encountering overly dramatic or exaggerated posts (58%) and people making accusations without facts (59%) [11].

In summary, while amusement is the most frequent emotion experienced by social media users across all age groups, younger users report a wider range of intense emotions, including higher rates of loneliness and depression, whereas older users experience a more balanced mix of amusement and anger.

Social media users across various age groups experience a range of emotions, with some notable differences. Younger adults (18-29) are more likely to report feeling amused by content they see on social media (54%) compared to older adults aged 65 and older (30%) [4].  The image shows the emotional responses of different age groups when browsing social media.
![The chart depicts how different age groups react emotionally, particularly highlighting that younger people (18-29) tend to report stronger emotions across all categories compared to older age groups.](image5)
Younger users are also more prone to feeling lonely, with 15% of 18- to 29-year-olds reporting frequent loneliness, compared to only 4% of those 50 and older [6].

In terms of content exposure, a significant majority of social media users frequently encounter posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated (58%) and people making accusations or starting arguments without having all the facts (59%) [12].
![The image is a bar chart that displays how frequently certain types of posts occur, based on survey responses. There are four categories of posts, and for each category, participants indicated whether they encounter these posts "Frequently" or "Sometimes." The NET column represents the combined percentage of "Frequently" and "Sometimes" responses for each type.](image1)
These types of content are seen frequently by a large portion of users, irrespective of age. It also present the how frequently certain types of posts occur.

Different age groups experience a range of emotions on social media, with younger users more frequently feeling amused but also lonely, and many users frequently encounter dramatic or accusatory content.

Different age groups and genders experience a range of emotions and encounter various types of content on social media. A significant majority of users across all age groups report seeing content that amuses them [6]. The largest share of users (44%) frequently experience amusement on these sites [6]. However, the frequency of experiencing other emotions varies by age. Younger adults (18-29) are more likely to report frequently feeling lonely (15%) compared to older adults aged 30-49 (7%) and those 50 and older (4%) [7].
![Emotional responses to content vary across age groups.](image3)
In terms of gender differences, men are more likely than women to report seeing people being mean or bullying (29% vs. 19%) [12]. Women are slightly more likely than men to say they more often see kind or supportive behavior [12].
![Perceptions of online behavior differ between men and women.](image6)
Users frequently encounter posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated (58%) and people making accusations or starting arguments without all the facts (59%) [10].
![Posts that are overly dramatic or with people making accusations without facts occur most.](image5)
Many users also see a mix of people trying to be deceptive and people trying to point out inaccurate information [9].

In conclusion, while amusement is the most common emotion experienced on social media, younger users are more prone to loneliness, men are more likely to observe negative interactions, and users often encounter dramatic or factually unsupported content.

Social media users experience a range of emotions, with amusement being the most common, followed by anger and connection. A breakdown by age shows that younger users (18-29) report higher percentages for all emotions, including amusement, anger, connection, inspiration, depression, and loneliness, compared to older age groups [4].
![Emotional responses across age groups, with younger users reporting higher frequencies of all emotions.](image8)

Regarding behaviors, a significant 54% of users report seeing an equal mix of kind/supportive and mean/bullying behavior, while 24% say they more often see mean or bullying behavior [3]. Men are more likely (29%) than women (19%) to report seeing primarily mean or bullying behavior [9].
![Comparison of perceptions of online behavior between men and women.](image7)

The most common types of posts encountered are those that are overly dramatic or exaggerated (58% frequently see this) and those where people make accusations or start arguments without having all the facts (59% frequently see this) [8].
![Frequency of different types of posts encountered on social media.](image3)
A majority of users also encounter post that appear to be one thing but turn out to be another [11].

In conclusion, different age groups and genders experience a variety of emotions and behaviors on social media, with younger users reporting higher emotional responses, and the most common posts are often dramatic or lacking factual basis.

There are notable differences between men's and women's perceptions of online behaviors. Men are more likely than women to report seeing mean or bullying behavior (29% vs. 19%) [2, 10].
![The data suggests differences in perceptions between men and women regarding these online behaviors.](image4)
Conversely, women are more likely than men to report seeing kind or supportive behavior (24% vs. 17%) [2]. However, the largest proportions of both genders, 52% of men and 56% of women, report seeing an equal mix of both supportive and bullying behaviors on social media [2].

In terms of deception and correcting misinformation, men are nearly twice as likely as women to say they more often see people being deceptive online (24% vs. 13%) [12]. Despite this, majorities of both men (58%) and women (67%) report seeing an equal mix of deceptiveness and attempts to correct misinformation [12].

These perceptions correlate with the high frequency of encountering dramatic or exaggerated posts on social media. A majority of social media users frequently see people engaging in drama and exaggeration (58%) [1, 6].
![The image is a bar chart that displays how frequently certain types of posts occur, based on survey responses.](image2)
Additionally, 59% of users frequently see people making accusations or starting arguments without having all the facts [1].

In summary, men are more likely to perceive negative behaviors like bullying and deception online, while women are more likely to notice positive behaviors; however, both genders frequently encounter dramatic or exaggerated content and a mix of positive and negative interactions.

The perceptions of social media content and behavior vary between men and women, particularly in recognizing negative interactions [6]. Men are more likely to report seeing deceptive and bullying behavior [1, 3]. For example, 29% of men, compared to 19% of women, report more frequently seeing mean or bullying content. Similarly, 24% of men, versus 13% of women, say they more often encounter deceptive behavior [1, 4].
![Perceptions of online behavior among men and women.](image4)
Women, on the other hand, tend to notice kind or supportive behavior more often than men (24% of women vs. 17% of men) [4]. However, majorities of both genders, 52% of men and 56% of women, observe a mixture of supportive and bullying behaviors [3].
![Frequency of emotions experienced.](image1)
In terms of specific content, users frequently encounter overly dramatic or exaggerated posts (88% NET) and posts where people make accusations without facts (87% NET) [image2]. This suggests a prevalence of emotionally charged or potentially misleading information.
![Frequency of posts that users encounter.](image2)
Regarding the use of personal data for recommendations, a majority of users, 75%, find it acceptable for platforms to recommend local events [11].
![Acceptance of different online recommendations.](image3)
However, acceptance varies when it comes to other uses, such as recommending potential friends (57%) or displaying product advertisements [11, image 3].

In conclusion, men are more likely to perceive negative behaviors like deception and bullying on social media, while women are more attuned to positive or supportive interactions.

User comfort with social media platforms using their personal data varies significantly based on how the data is used and the age of the user [9, 10]. A majority of users across different age groups are comfortable with their data being used to recommend local events [8]. Specifically, 75% of social media users find it acceptable for platforms to use their data to recommend events in their area [12].
![This image is a bar chart showing the acceptability of different online recommendations. The categories are: 1. Recommend events in their area, 2. Recommend someone they might want to know, 3. Show them ads for products or services, 4. Show them messages from political campaigns.](image2)
However, acceptance levels differ when it comes to other uses of personal data. For instance, while a majority (57%) find it acceptable for their data to recommend potential friends, this sentiment varies significantly by age [12]. About two-thirds of social media users younger than 50 find it acceptable for social media platforms to use their data to recommend connecting with people, a view shared by fewer than half of users ages 65 and older [1, 4].
![This image is a chart comparing how different age groups feel about certain types of recommendations and advertisements they receive.](image3)
When it comes to showing advertisements, around half (52%) of users think it is acceptable for social media sites to use their data for this purpose, but 47% find it unacceptable [2]. There are also notable age differences, nearly six-in-ten users ages 18 to 49 find using data for ads acceptable [4]. In contrast, users are much less comfortable with their data being used for political messaging, with a substantial majority finding it unacceptable [2, 8].

In summary, different age groups have varying levels of comfort with social media platforms using their data, with older users generally being less accepting of these practices, especially for recommendations and advertisements, while most users are comfortable with data being used to recommend local events.

Americans show diverse reactions to different automated decision-making systems, with notable differences between how fair and how effective these systems are perceived to be. For instance, a significant portion of the public believes that an automated personal finance score would be effective at identifying good customers (54%) [8, 9], but only a much smaller percentage (32%) consider it fair to consumers [8, 11]. This 22-percentage-point difference is the largest among the scenarios presented [11], as visualized in the data:
![Perception of fairness and effectiveness of automated systems](image8)

This discrepancy suggests a substantial lack of public trust in the fairness of personal finance algorithms, even when they are perceived as effective. Similarly, automated video analysis of job interviews is seen as more effective (39%) than fair (33%) [8], indicating that people slightly doubt the fairness in technology’s judgment in hiring processes. A majority finds this system unacceptable.
![Opinions on acceptability of automated video analysis of job interviews](image5)

In contrast, the automated scoring of people up for parole shows a more balanced view, where 49% find it effective and 50% find it fair [8]. However, there are notable concerns. The chart clearly states that more people find it not acceptable(56%) than acceptable(42%):
![Opinions on using automated criminal risk scores](image7)

Across all systems, there's a trend indicating skepticism, with a significant number concerned that these systems might always reflect some level of human bias [6]. Concerns include the removal of the human element from crucial decisions and the inability of systems to capture the nuances of complex human situations [7]. The responses show a split with concerns about:
![Belief on whether programs can make decisions without human bias](image4)

Overall, the perceptions indicate that while some automated systems are recognized for their effectiveness, there is considerable concern about their fairness.

The perceptions of fairness and effectiveness vary significantly across different automated systems, which implies that public trust is highly dependent on the context and perceived implications of these technologies.

Public perception of President Trump's ethical standards and trustworthiness is notably lower than that of previous presidents, with significant partisan divisions. A majority of the public (58%) trusts what Trump says less than what previous presidents said [3, 6]. This distrust is particularly pronounced among Democrats, with 94% saying they trust Trump's statements less than those of his predecessors [7].
![Opinions on trust in statements compared to previous presidents, categorized by political affiliation.](image4)

In contrast, 58% of Republicans and Republican leaners trust Trump's statements more than previous presidents [11].

Regarding ethical standards, only 39% of the public rates the ethical standards of top administration officials as excellent or good, while 59% rate them as not good or poor [5]. These evaluations are lower than those for officials in administrations dating back to Reagan [5, 10].
![Approval ratings of U.S. presidents, including Trump, Obama, G.W. Bush, Clinton, G.H.W. Bush, and Reagan.](image1)
Partisan divisions are stark, with 76% of Republicans rating the ethical standards of top administration officials as excellent or good, compared to 90% of Democrats who rate them as not good or poor [1].

In conclusion, perceptions of Trump's ethical standards and trustworthiness are significantly lower compared to previous presidents, with a stark divide between Republicans and Democrats.

Public perceptions of Trump's responsibilities and trustworthiness differ significantly from those of previous presidents, with notable partisan divisions.

A majority of the public (64%) believes Trump has a responsibility to release his tax returns, a view held by nearly all Democrats (91%) and a smaller portion of Republicans (32%) [10].
![Opinions on whether Trump should release tax returns.](image4)

Trust in Trump's statements is lower compared to previous presidents. A majority (58%) say they trust what Trump says less than what previous presidents said [6], with this view being nearly unanimous among Democrats (94%) [8]. In contrast, 58% of Republicans trust Trump's statements more than those of previous presidents [11].
![Public trust in Trump's statements compared to previous presidents.](image6)

The data reveals a deep partisan divide in how Trump is perceived compared to his predecessors, particularly regarding his responsibilities and trustworthiness.

In conclusion, the public generally perceives Trump as having a responsibility to release his tax returns, and his trustworthiness is viewed as lower compared to previous presidents, with significant differences based on partisan lines.

Public perception of President Trump's presidency is deeply divided along partisan lines, particularly regarding ethical standards, economic impact, and long-term success.

Views on the ethical standards of Trump administration officials are remarkably low compared to previous administrations [10], with a stark contrast between Republicans and Democrats. A significant majority of Republicans (76%) believe the ethical standards are good or excellent [3], while an overwhelming 90% of Democrats view them as not good or poor [3].

Regarding Trump's economic impact, there's a growing partisan divide [12].
![Opinions on whether something made things better, had not much effect, or made things worse.](image4)
In January 2019, 79% of Republicans believed his policies improved economic conditions, a rise from 63% in October 2017 [12]. Conversely, 46% of Democrats believed his policies made things worse [12]. Overall, 40% of the public thinks Trump's policies have improved the economy, while 28% believe they have worsened it [11].

As for long-term success, 65% of Republicans predict Trump will be successful [6].
![Perceptions of presidential success among party affiliates.](image8)
This is similar to Republican views of Bush in 2003 (69%) [8]. However, 80% of Democrats believe Trump will be unsuccessful [4]. This partisan divide in predicting presidential success is more pronounced for Trump than for previous presidents [7].
![Public opinion on how successful recent U.S. presidents will be in the long run.](image3)
Compared to Obama and George W. Bush at similar points in their presidencies, more people have a definitive view on whether they'll be successful, with fewer saying it's too early to say [5].

In summary, perceptions of Trump's presidency are highly polarized, with Republicans generally positive about his economic impact and long-term success and Democrats overwhelmingly negative, particularly concerning ethical standards.

Partisan views on presidential success vary significantly, and this is particularly evident when comparing perceptions of Donald Trump's presidency with those of his predecessors.

In January 2019, 65% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents believed Trump would be a successful president, while 80% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents thought he would be unsuccessful [2]. This contrasts sharply with views on previous presidents. For instance, in January 2011, 43% of Democrats and Democratic-leaners believed Obama would be successful, while 47% of Republicans and Republican-leaners thought he would be unsuccessful [2].
![Perceptions of presidential success among party affiliates at different points in their presidencies](image2)

The trend of polarization is clear, with a much larger share of Democrats predicting Trump's failure compared to Republican predictions for Obama [1]. Furthermore, fewer people say it's "too early to tell" whether Trump will be successful compared to similar points in the presidencies of Obama, Bush, and Clinton [3, 5].

In December 2003, 69% of Republicans thought Bush would be successful, similar to the 65% who felt the same about Trump in 2019 [10].
![Public opinion on how successful recent U.S. presidents will be in the long run](image3)
Overall, public opinion on Trump's presidency is more negative and polarized than for his recent predecessors at comparable points in their administrations [11, 12].

In conclusion, perceptions of Trump's presidency are significantly more polarized among party affiliates compared to those of Obama, Bush, and Clinton, with a clear trend of increasing division and fewer people undecided about his success.

Public opinion on Donald Trump's potential success as president is sharply divided along partisan lines. A significant majority of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (65%) believe Trump will be a successful president in the long run [12]. Conversely, a large majority of Democrats and Democratic leaners (80%) think he will be unsuccessful [9].
![Comparison of perceptions of presidential success among party affiliates](image6)

This partisan divide extends to views on Robert Mueller's investigation into Russian involvement in the 2016 election. A larger share of Republicans say they are not confident in Mueller (58%) [10].
![Levels of agreement among different groups concerning the Mueller investigation.](image7)
In contrast, about seven-in-ten Democrats (72%) are at least somewhat confident in the fairness of Mueller's investigation [10].
![Levels of agreement among different groups in handling of the matters.](image8)

These contrasting views highlight the deeply partisan nature of both opinions on Trump's presidency and the Mueller investigation [2, 5].

In summary, Republicans are optimistic about Trump's success and less confident in Mueller's investigation, while Democrats hold the opposite views.

Public views on local job availability have become significantly more positive over the past two decades, reaching their highest point since the question was first asked in 2001 [5, 8]. Currently, 60% of adults believe there are plenty of jobs available in their local community [5]. However, perceptions vary significantly between political affiliations.

Republicans are more optimistic about job availability than Democrats. Specifically, 71% of Republicans believe there are plenty of jobs available, compared to 53% of Democrats [6]. This partisan gap is also evident in perceptions of "good jobs," with 58% of Republicans believing plenty are available, compared to 39% of Democrats.  ![Perceptions of job availability, showing differences between "jobs" and "good jobs" across political affiliations.](image4)

Over time, the trend shows an increasing divergence in views between the two political groups. The graph of job availability perceptions highlights these shifts, particularly between 2016 and 2019. ![Trends in job availability perceptions over time, differentiated by political affiliation.](image3) A similar trend is observed in personal financial situations, with Republicans consistently rating their finances more positively than Democrats. ![Trends in personal financial situation ratings over time, by political affiliation.](image5)

In terms of economic mobility, there are notable differences as well. Republicans are more likely to believe their family income is going up faster (16%) compared to Democrats (7%). Conversely, 54% of Democrats believe their income is falling behind, compared to 31% of Republicans [11].  ![Perceptions of economic mobility, broken down by political affiliation and other demographics.](image1)

In summary, Republicans generally have a more positive perception of economic conditions and job availability than Democrats, and this gap has widened over time, especially in recent years.

Americans' perceptions of job availability have significantly transformed, with a majority believing there are plenty of jobs in their communities [1]. This positive outlook is seen across party lines, with both Republicans and Democrats holding more favorable views of local job opportunities than in the past two decades [2, 4].

Specifically, 71% of Republicans and 53% of Democrats report ample job availability in their areas [6]. This partisan gap is visually represented in a survey chart:
![Perceptions of Job Availability](image5)

The trend of increasing positive job availability perceptions is also notable, as illustrated by the following graph:
![Job Availability Trends](image6)
Perceptions have improved since 2017, correlating with more positive views of the economy overall [11]. However, there's a distinct difference between perceptions of "jobs" and "good jobs," the graph shows that there are more positive opinions in 'jobs' rather than 'good jobs' [image5].

The evolution of these perceptions reveals a widening partisan gap. Republican views have become significantly more positive since Trump's election [12].
![Political Affiliation Trends](image1)
In summary, perceptions of job availability differ significantly between political affiliations, with Republicans generally holding more positive views than Democrats, and these perceptions have become increasingly positive over time, particularly among Republicans.

Overall, 46% of Americans believe that Wall Street has a positive impact on the U.S. economy, while 39% believe it has a negative impact [4]. However, these views vary significantly by political affiliation.

Republicans and Republican-leaning individuals are more likely to view Wall Street positively, with 55% believing it helps the economy more than it hurts it [2]. ![A chart showing that 55% of Republicans believe Wall Street helps the economy more than it hurts.](image1)

In contrast, Democrats and Democratic-leaning individuals are more divided [7, 9]. 41% believe Wall Street helps the economy, while 46% believe it hurts the economy more [7]. ![A chart showing that 46% of Democrats believe Wall Street hurts the economy more than it helps.](image1)

Regarding national conditions, public satisfaction has been low for over a decade, with only 26% of Americans expressing satisfaction in recent surveys [3, 5]. This dissatisfaction has increased since September, affecting both parties [3, 12]. Notably, satisfaction levels among Democrats have been consistently low during the Trump presidency, with only 8% currently expressing satisfaction [6, 8]. Republican satisfaction, while higher, has also dropped since September [1]. The trend of dissatisfaction of all American has showed in the graph.  ![A line graph shows the trend of American's satisfaction and dissatisfaction with the way things are going in the country from 1990-2019.](image5)

In summary, Republicans tend to view Wall Street more favorably than Democrats, while overall public satisfaction with national conditions remains low across party lines.

Public dissatisfaction with the state of the nation has increased significantly, reaching 70% in 2019, up from 54% in 1990 [5, 11]. Conversely, public satisfaction decreased from 41% in 1990 to 26% in 2019 [5].
![Public dissatisfaction with the state of the nation is at its peak.](image5)
Political affiliations have also seen shifts over this period. The graph indicates fluctuations in party identification, with periods of both Republican and Democratic dominance.
![Political affiliations changes from 1990 to 2019.](image4)
These trends are reflected in partisan views regarding Wall Street's impact on the economy [6]. Republicans are more likely to believe that Wall Street helps the economy more than it hurts it (55% vs. 31%) [6]. Democrats are more divided, with 46% saying Wall Street hurts the economy and 41% saying it helps [7].
![Views on how Wall street impacts the US economy, by political affiliation.](image8)
In conclusion, from 1990 to 2019, public satisfaction decreased while dissatisfaction increased, accompanied by fluctuating political affiliations and divided views on Wall Street's economic impact along party lines.

Public confidence in Trump's ability to make good appointments to the federal courts varies significantly between Republicans and Democrats. A substantial majority of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents express confidence in this area, with 64% being very confident and 24% somewhat confident [image7]. In stark contrast, only a small fraction of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents share this sentiment, with only 2% very confident and 10% somewhat confident [image7].

![Confidence levels in Trump's abilities among Republicans/Lean Republicans and Democrats/Lean Democrats](image7)

This disparity is consistent across other tasks. For instance, when it comes to negotiating favorable trade agreements, 89% of Republicans are confident in Trump's ability, compared to just 19% of Democrats [6]. A similar pattern exists for making good decisions about economic policy [2, image7].

When looking more broadly at public confidence across various tasks, Trump garners the most confidence in his ability to negotiate favorable trade agreements (51%) and make good decisions about economic policy (49%) [7]. Confidence in making good appointments to federal courts is slightly lower at 45% [11].

![Survey results on public confidence in Trump](image3)

However, this confidence varies significantly across all tasks, managing the executive branch effectively (41%)[image3].

In conclusion, there is a significant partisan divide in confidence in Trump's ability to make good appointments to the federal courts, with Republicans expressing high confidence and Democrats expressing low confidence, mirroring the trend observed in other areas such as trade negotiations and economic policy.

Public confidence in President Trump's ability to separate his business interests from his presidential decisions is low overall, with significant partisan divisions. Only about three-in-ten Americans (28%) are very confident that Trump keeps his own business interests separate from the decisions he makes as president, and another 13% are somewhat confident [8]. A majority are either not too (16%) or not at all (41%) confident [8].
![Survey results on confidence levels, categorized by political affiliation.](image8)

The partisan divide is stark. A majority of Republicans say they are very (55%) or somewhat (23%) confident in this separation, with conservative Republicans (66% very confident) being much more likely to express this view than moderate and liberal Republicans (39% very confident) [5].
![Survey results on confidence levels, categorized by political affiliation.](image8)
In sharp contrast, Democrats are deeply skeptical. Nearly seven-in-ten (69%) say they are not at all confident, and another 20% are not too confident [6]. Liberal Democrats are especially skeptical, with 83% expressing no confidence at all [6].
![Survey results on confidence levels, categorized by political affiliation.](image8)

Regarding the release of tax returns, a majority of Americans (64%) believe Trump has a responsibility to release them [9].
![Chart showing public opinion on Trump's responsibility to release tax returns.](image1)

However, most Republicans (64%) maintain that Trump does not have this responsibility, while only 32% believe he does [10]. This contrasts sharply with the views of Democrats, of whom vast majority believe that Trump has a responsibility to release his tax return. [image1]

In conclusion, confidence in Trump's separation of business and presidential decisions is low overall and deeply divided along partisan lines, mirroring the division over whether he should release his tax returns.

Partisan divides significantly influence perceptions of the COVID-19 response and institutional trust. Democrats are more likely than Republicans to view the U.S. response as less effective compared to other wealthy nations [8]. Specifically, 87% of Democrats and Democratic leaners believe the U.S. response has been less effective [8], while only 22% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents say the U.S. has been more effective than other wealthy countries [1, 8].
![Opinions on US COVID-19 Response Compared to Other Wealthy Countries](image7)

There are also wide partisan differences in views of how public health officials, such as those at the CDC, are responding to the outbreak [9]. About seven-in-ten Democrats (72%) say public health officials have done an excellent or good job, a figure that has remained relatively stable since March [12]. In contrast, only about half of Republicans (53%) give CDC officials and other public health officials positive ratings, a significant decrease from 84% in late March [12].
![Change in Approval Ratings of Public Health Officials from March to August](image4)

The chart indicates that, overall, 63% of respondents rated public health officials positively, with a breakdown of 72% of Democrats/Lean Democrats and 53% of Republicans/Lean Republicans agreeing [image1].
![Confidence in Institutions and Leaders](image1)

Democrats are more likely than Republicans to believe that factors like inadequate federal government response and lifting restrictions too quickly are major reasons the outbreak has continued [2]. For instance, 82% of Democrats view inadequate federal government response as a major reason, compared to only 21% of Republicans [2]. Similarly, 82% of Democrats versus 31% of Republicans believe lifting restrictions too quickly contributed to the prolonged outbreak [2].
![Major reasons the outbreak has continued.](image8)

Partisan differences are far wider than geographical differences in opinions about the pandemic and policies to address it [10, 11].

In conclusion, partisan divides profoundly shape perceptions of COVID-19, with Democrats generally more critical of the response and showing higher trust in public health officials compared to Republicans.

Partisan differences significantly impact perceptions of the response to the COVID-19 outbreak. Democrats and those leaning Democratic generally have a more positive view of public health officials, while Republicans and those leaning Republican have a more favorable view of Donald Trump.

Since March, the share of Republicans who rate public health officials positively has fallen 31 points, from 84% to 53% [2, 10]. Democrats' views have remained largely unchanged during the same period (74% in March, 72% currently) [2, 10]. This decline among Republicans is visually represented in a line graph showing approval ratings for public health officials, such as those at the CDC [9].
![Approval ratings for public health officials decreased among Republicans.](image2)

In contrast, there's a wide gap in approval ratings for Donald Trump. The percentage of Democrats rating Trump's response as "poor" increased from 56% in March to 82% [3]. A line graph illustrates the decreasing approval of Donald Trump, especially among Democrats, from March to August.
![Donald Trump's approval rating decreased from March to August.](image2)
Republicans are more likely give high rates to Donld Trump [8]. The confidence on Donld Trump is:
   - Democrats/Lean Democrats: 6%
   - Republicans/Lean Republicans: 73% [8]
![The confidence of Donald Trump is much higher in Republicans than Democrats.](image8)

In conclusion, partisan differences greatly affect the perception of responses to the COVID-19 outbreak, with Republicans' approval of public health officials declining while Democrats' views remain steady, and with a large and increasing disapproval of Donald Trump's response among Democrats.

Public approval ratings for both public health officials and Donald Trump have declined from March to August.

The overall approval rating for public health officials, such as those at the CDC, has decreased from 79% to 63% [4]. This decline is primarily driven by a significant drop in approval among Republicans [6, 12]. In March, 84% of Republicans rated public health officials positively, but by August, this had fallen to 53% [1, 12]. Democrats' views have remained relatively stable, with 74% approving in March and 72% in August [1, 12].
![Chart showing decreased approval rating for public health officials.](image7)

Similarly, Donald Trump's overall approval rating for his response to the coronavirus outbreak has decreased from 48% in March to 37% in August [7].
![Chart showing decreased approval rating for Donald Trump.](image7)
There's a wide partisan difference with 73% of Republicans and only 6% of Democrats approve his response [5].
![Chart showing partisan differences in confidence levels towards officials and institutions.](image5)
Overall, 38% of Americans approve of Donald Trump's performance, while 59% disapprove [3].
![Chart showing overall approval and disapproval ratings.](image4)

In summary, approval ratings for both public health officials and Donald Trump have decreased from March to August, with a significant drop in approval among Republicans for both.

Americans have varying perceptions of the effectiveness of different groups in handling the COVID-19 pandemic. While the public views the response of local hospitals and medical centers overwhelmingly positively (88%) [1], perceptions of elected officials and public health officials are more critical.

Specifically, 63% of Americans believe public health officials, such as those at the CDC, are doing an excellent or good job responding to the outbreak [5]. This is in contrast to lower ratings for elected officials, with 60% rating local elected officials positively and only 56% rating state elected officials positively [1]. Several factors are perceived to contribute to the continued outbreak. A significant majority (75%) believe that too few people abiding by social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines is a major reason [2]. Additionally, 58% say that lifting restrictions too quickly in some places is a major contributing factor [2].
![Reasons for the spread of COVID-19.](image8)
There are notable partisan differences in these perceptions, particularly regarding the federal government's response and the speed of lifting restrictions [11]. Democrats tend to see inadequate response from the federal government and the lift of restriction is too quick.
![Opinions on several issues related to COVID-19, segmented by political affiliation.](image3)

In summary, Americans generally view public health officials more favorably than elected officials in handling COVID-19, with the continued outbreak largely attributed to insufficient adherence to guidelines and premature lifting of restrictions.

Political affiliations significantly influence perceptions of government responsibility during the COVID-19 pandemic. Republicans and those leaning Republican tend to believe that state and local governments should be primarily responsible for developing and implementing policies to limit the spread of the coronavirus (68%) [8]. Conversely, Democrats and Democratic-leaning individuals largely believe that the federal government bears most of the responsibility (64%) [8].
![Opinions on government trust by political affiliation.](image4)
This division is also shown that the Democrats are more likely than Republicans to say the factors, like the federal government response is inadequate [11].
![Opinions on COVID-19 issues by political affiliation.](image2)
A majority of Americans (75%) cite insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing as a major reason for the continued COVID-19 outbreak [5]. This view is shared by a large majority of Democrats (89%) and a smaller majority of Republicans (57%) [image2]. Another significant factor cited is that restrictions were lifted too quickly in some places (58%) [12].
![Reasons for the spread of an issue.](image1)

In summary, political affiliation significantly shapes views on government responsibility during the pandemic, with Republicans favoring state and local control and Democrats favoring federal control, and major reasons cited for the outbreak's continuation include insufficient social distancing, inadequate mask-wearing, and premature lifting of restrictions.

Americans across the political spectrum offer varying perspectives on why the COVID-19 outbreak has continued, with significant differences influenced by party affiliation.

A key factor is the perceived inadequacy of the federal government's response. A large majority of Democrats (82%) cite this as a major reason, compared to only 21% of Republicans [1, 12]. This partisan divide is visually represented in a chart, which clearly shows the stark contrast between the two groups.
![A chart comparing opinions on several issues related to COVID-19, segmented by political affiliation.](image2)

Another significant factor is social distancing, or rather, the lack thereof. The majority of Americans (75%) believe that not enough people are following social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines [5].
![Reasons for the spread of an issue.](image7)
However, there's still a partisan difference: 89% of Democrats see this as a major reason, compared to 57% of Republicans [6]. The chart illustrates this difference, though it is not as dramatic as the split over the federal government's response [image2].

In summary, political affiliation significantly influences perceptions of the COVID-19 outbreak's continuation, with Democrats largely blaming inadequate federal response and insufficient social distancing more than Republicans.

There's a significant partisan divide in how the federal government's response to the COVID-19 outbreak is perceived. A large majority of Democrats (82%) believe the inadequate federal response is a major reason the outbreak has continued, compared to only 21% of Republicans [11]. This is one of the widest partisan differences observed in the data [11].
![Opinions on various factors contributing to the spread of COVID-19, categorized by political affiliation.](image7)
The general public cites several major reasons for the continuation of the outbreak. Insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing is the most commonly cited reason [4]. Specifically, 75% of the general public consider it a major reason [5]. Other significant factors include restrictions being lifted too quickly in some places (58%), inadequate federal government response (53%), and lack of timely testing (49%) [5].
![Reasons for the spread of an issue, categorized by the level of importance.](image5)
Overall, Democrats are much more likely than Republicans to view most factors as a major reason for the continuation of the outbreak [11]. There are also major differences that divide republicans and democrats on the reason why COVID-19 has continued in the US, some places are being too quick to ease restriction [9].

In summary, perceptions of the federal government's response to the COVID-19 outbreak differ significantly between political affiliations, with Democrats largely blaming the federal government and Republicans less likely to do so, while the general public cites insufficient social distancing, premature lifting of restrictions, inadequate federal response, and lack of timely testing as major reasons for the outbreak's continuation.

There are significant differences between Republicans and Democrats regarding the reasons for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak and the perceived adequacy of the measures in place.

One major point of divergence is the attribution of increased case counts. A majority of Republicans (62%) believe that the increase in confirmed cases is primarily due to more testing [3]. This view is particularly strong among conservative Republicans (68%) [image1]. In stark contrast, 80% of Democrats believe the rise in cases is mainly due to increased infections [2, image3].
![Opinions on COVID-19 testing and new infections, segmented by political affiliation.](image1)

Another key difference lies in the perception of the federal government's response. A substantial 82% of Democrats view the federal government's response as inadequate, compared to only 21% of Republicans [8].
![Comparison of COVID-19 opinions by political affiliation.](image8)
This partisan gap extends to opinions on lifting restrictions. While 82% of Democrats believe that restrictions were lifted too quickly in some places, only 31% of Republicans share this view [7,8].

Furthermore, Democrats are more likely than Republicans to attribute the continuation of the outbreak to a lack of social distancing and mask-wearing (89% vs. 57%) [image8]. There is also a divide on the issue of timely testing, with 67% of Democrats and 30% of Republicans considering it a major reason for the ongoing outbreak [12, image8].

In conclusion, partisan beliefs differ significantly on the reasons for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak, with Democrats largely attributing it to inadequate government response, premature lifting of restrictions, and insufficient social distancing, while Republicans tend to emphasize increased testing and, to a lesser extent, the inherent difficulty in controlling the spread.

There's a significant partisan divide in the United States regarding the reasons for the rise in COVID-19 cases and the pace of lifting restrictions.

A majority of Republicans (62%) believe the increase in confirmed cases is primarily due to increased testing [8, 10]. This view is particularly strong among conservative Republicans [8]. In stark contrast, Democrats overwhelmingly (80%) attribute the rise to increased infections, not just more testing [4, 10]. This difference is visually represented in a bar chart showing the contrasting views.
![The chart illustrates differing beliefs about testing and infection rates between political groups.](image5)

Regarding the lifting of restrictions, most Americans (69%) express more concern that state governments have been lifting restrictions too quickly [11]. However, Republicans are relatively divided on this issue, with a slight majority (53%) expressing more concern that restrictions have not been lifted quickly enough [3].
![The image is a bar chart showing survey results on opinions about lifting restrictions too quickly versus not quickly enough.](image1)
Democrats, on the other hand, overwhelmingly (88%) believe that restrictions have been lifted too quickly [12]. A significant partisan gap exists, with 82% of Democrats pointing to some places being too quick to ease restrictions as a major reason for the outbreak continuing, compared to only 31% of Republicans [2].
![This image is a chart that compares opinions on several issues related to COVID-19, segmented by political affiliation: Republicans/Lean Republican (in red) and Democrats/Lean Democrat (in blue).](image2)

In conclusion, perspectives on rising COVID-19 cases and lifting restrictions differ significantly across political lines, with Republicans attributing the rise to increased testing and Democrats to more infections, while also differing on whether restrictions were lifted too quickly.

There's a strong correlation between views on the causes of increased COVID-19 cases and opinions on lifting restrictions, with significant differences between political groups. Democrats overwhelmingly attribute the rise in cases to increased infections (80%) rather than increased testing [5, 8], and they are more likely to believe that restrictions have been lifted too quickly (82%) [11].
![Opinions on lifting restrictions vs. not quickly enough, by demographics.](image2)
Republicans, on the other hand, are more likely to attribute the rise in cases to increased testing (62%) [9].
![Perspectives on testing vs. new infections, by political affiliation.](image3)
This difference in perspective aligns with their views on lifting restrictions. While a majority of Republicans and those who lean Republican attribute the rise to testing, they are much less likely than Democrats to say the restrictions have been lifted too quickly, and considerable more likely say they are not being lifted quickly enough [1]. A significant partisan gap exists, with 82% of Democrats pointing to some places being too quick to ease restrictions, compared to just 31% of Republicans [4, 11].

In conclusion, views on the causes of increased COVID-19 cases (more infections vs. more testing) strongly correlate with opinions on lifting restrictions, with significant differences between Democrats and Republicans.

There are significant differences in preferences regarding the requirement for government-issued photo identification to vote, and these preferences vary considerably across racial groups and political affiliations.

Overall, a substantial majority (76%) of adults favor requiring photo identification [6]. However, this support is not uniform across all demographics. Republicans are considerably more likely than Democrats to strongly favor photo identification requirements, with 81% of Republicans strongly in favor compared to 30% of Democrats [11]. Even with this partisan divide, majorities in both groups do favor this policy [11].

Racial differences are also apparent within each party. Among Democrats, White adults (54%) are less likely to favor photo ID requirements than Black (65%), Hispanic (72%), and Asian (71%) Democrats [3]. This is visually summarized by the data points, with red dots representing lower support and blue dots showing higher support.

In summary, while a majority of Americans favor requiring government-issued photo identification to vote, there are significant variations in support levels across different racial groups and political affiliations, with Republicans and Black, Hispanic, and Asian Democrats showing higher levels of support than White Democrats.

Racial and ethnic differences significantly influence support for various voting policies. For example, while a narrow majority of White Democrats (54%) favor requiring government-issued photo identification, larger shares of Black (65%), Hispanic (72%), and Asian Democrats (71%) support the same [7]. In summary, racial and ethnic differences, intertwined with partisan affiliations, create varied levels of support for voting policies, with Black Americans generally favoring more expansive policies and differing views on photo ID requirements compared to other groups.

Americans overall favor requiring all voters to show government-issued photo identification to vote [12]. Majorities in both partisan groups favor this policy, but Republicans are considerably more likely than Democrats to strongly favor photo identification requirements for voting (81% strongly favor compared with 30% of Democrats) [7].
![Opinions on voting-related policies by racial groups.](image1)
There are also racial difference within each party. While only a narrow majority of White Democrats (54%) favor requiring voters to show government-issued photo identification to vote, larger shares of Black (65%), Hispanic (72%), and Asian (71%) Democrats say the same [3].
![Data comparing support for a policy across racial groups: White (54, 96), Black (65), Hispanic (72, 90), and Asian (71).](image5)
In contrast to perspectives on policies like photo ID requirements, many Americans favor policies that make voting easier [1, 2, 11]. For example, White adults are less likely to favor making Election Day a national holiday and automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote than are Black, Hispanic, and Asian adults [11].

In conclusion, while majorities in both parties favor photo ID requirements, Republicans are more strongly in favor; within the Democratic Party, White members are less supportive of photo ID requirements compared to Black, Hispanic, and Asian members, and White adults generally show less support for certain expansive voting policies compared to other racial and ethnic groups.

Americans show varied perspectives on electoral reforms, influenced by political affiliation and demographic factors.

Regarding independent redistricting, a proposal by House Democrats to establish bipartisan commissions for drawing congressional maps garners substantial support. Nearly half of U.S. adults (49%) approve of this measure [2]. Democrats and those leaning Democratic show stronger support (59%) compared to Republicans and their leaners (38%) [2].
![A bar chart showing approval, disapproval, and uncertainty ratings among different groups.](image1)

On the topic of early and absentee voting, a majority of Americans (63%) believe any voter should have the option to vote early or absentee, without needing a documented reason [3]. However, there's a significant partisan divide: only 38% of Republicans favor this, compared to 84% of Democrats [7, 11]. This disparity is visualized.
![A bar chart depicting public opinion regarding early and absentee voting options in elections.](image8)
Among Republicans, those who voted absentee or early in 2020 are more likely to support no-excuse absentee voting compared to those who voted in person [6, 8, 10]. Specifically, 52% of Republicans who voted absentee favor no-excuse absentee voting. Ideological differences also play a role, with moderate and liberal Republicans more evenly split on the issue than their conservative counterparts [9].

Demographic differences are evident as well. Black adults are more likely than White, Hispanic, and Asian adults to favor no-excuse early and absentee voting [5].

In summary, while there's broad support for independent redistricting, opinions on early and absentee voting are deeply divided along political and, to a lesser extent, demographic lines, with Democrats and certain demographic groups showing stronger support for expanded access.

A significant majority of Democrats and Democratic-leaning individuals (84%) believe that any voter should have the option to vote early or absentee [3]. This is visually supported by a bar chart showing that 84% of Democrats/Lean Democrats support open early or absentee voting, compared to only 16% who believe documentation should be required.

![Any voter should have the option to vote early or absentee](image1)

In contrast, Republicans and Republican-leaning voters are more divided. 62% of Republican/Lean Republican respondents believe a voter should only be allowed to vote early or absentee if they have a documented reason, while only 38% think any voter should have that option [image1]. There's also a notable difference in opinion within the Republican party based on how they voted in 2020. Those who voted early or absentee are more likely to favor no-excuse absentee voting [1, 5]. Just 22% of Republicans who voted in person on Election Day favor this policy, compared with 52% of Republicans who voted early or absentee in the 2020 presidential election [1].
GOP voters are split among ideological lines as well.
Conservative Republicans are more likely (70%) to believe in documented reasons, moderate to liberal Republicans are close to evenly split [10].

![The image is a bar chart depicting public opinion regarding early and absentee voting options in elections. It is divided into two main categories: 

1. "A voter should only be allowed to vote early or absentee if they have a documented reason for not voting in person on Election Day" - which is represented by lighter colored bars.
2. "Any voter should have the option to vote early or absentee" - represented by darker colored bars.](image1)

Regarding redistricting, a proposal to use independent commissions with equal numbers of Democrats and Republicans to draw congressional district maps, rather than state legislatures, receives more approval (49%) than disapproval (13%) from all adults. Democrats are more inclined to favor these commissions than Republicans [1].

![The image is a bar chart showing approval, disapproval, and uncertainty ratings among different groups.](image3)

Specifically, 59% of Democrats/Lean Democrats approve of the proposal, compared to 38% of Republicans/Lean Republicans [image3]. However, a significant percentage of adults (38%) are unsure about this proposal, indicating a lack of strong opinion either way [9]. Republicans show the most unsurety (42%) [4].

In summary, Democrats overwhelmingly support no-excuse absentee voting and independent redistricting commissions, while Republicans are more divided on both issues, with a greater preference for requiring documented reasons for absentee voting and greater uncertainty about independent redistricting.

There's a notable shift in views among Republicans regarding "no excuse" early or absentee voting between 2018 and 2021. The percentage of Republicans who support allowing any voter to vote early or absentee without a documented reason has significantly decreased from 57% to 38% [7, 1]. Conversely, those who believe documentation should be required rose from 42% to 62% [2]. This trend is visually represented in a chart showing the evolving attitudes towards voting flexibility.
![The image is a bar chart comparing the views of different political groups regarding early or absentee voting over time. The chart is divided into three sections: Total, Rep/Lean Rep, and Dem/Lean Dem. Each section shows survey results from three time points: October 2018, June 2020, and April 2021.](image5)
In contrast, Democrats and Democratic leaners have maintained consistently high support for "no excuse" early voting, with 84% in favor, remaining virtually unchanged in recent years [7].

Regarding automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote, there's also a divergence.
![The image is a line graph comparing public opinion on three voting policies between October 2018 and April 2021, segmented by political affiliation: Total (grey), Republican/Lean Republican (red), and Democrat/Lean Democrat (blue).](image4)
Republican support decreased from 49% in 2018 to 38% in 2021, while Democratic support increased from 78% to 82% [5, 4].

In summary, from 2018 to 2021, Republican support for 'no excuse' early or absentee voting decreased significantly, while their support for automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote also decreased; Democratic views remained largely unchanged, with high support for both.

There are notable differences in how partisans view making Election Day a national holiday and requiring photo ID to vote, with shifts in these views between 2018 and 2021.

Regarding making Election Day a national holiday, the percentage of Democrats who favor this policy increased from 71% to 78% [7, 8]. Republicans' support remained constant at 59% [8].
![Opinions on making Election Day a national holiday from 2018 to 2021, by party affiliation.](image8)

As for requiring photo ID to vote, Republican support increased from 91% to 93% from 2018 to 2021, while Democrat support decreased slightly from 63% to 61% [8]. Republicans are much more likely than Democrats to strongly favor photo ID requirements (81% vs. 30%) [1].
![Opinions on requiring photo ID to vote from 2018 to 2021, by party affiliation.](image7)

In summary, between 2018 and 2021, Democratic support for making Election Day a national holiday increased, while Republican support remained constant; Republican support for requiring photo ID to vote increased, while Democratic support decreased slightly.

Over the period from 2019 to 2022, Latino voters' party affiliation remained relatively stable, with a nearly two-to-one preference for the Democratic Party over the Republican Party [9]. Specifically, 64% of Latino registered voters identified with or leaned toward the Democratic Party, compared to 33% for the Republican Party in 2022, with little change observed over the past few years [9]. This trend is visually represented in a graph showing the percentages over the years, where the Democratic Party consistently holds a significant lead.
![Party affiliation trend from 2019 to 2022](image5)

Key election issues for Latino voters in 2022 include the economy, which remains the top concern at 80%, followed by healthcare (71%), violent crime and education (70% each), and gun policy (66%) [12]. Notably, the importance of abortion as a voting issue has risen significantly among Hispanics, increasing from 42% in March to 57% in August 2022 [2, 10].
![Change in importance of abortion as an election issue](image6)

Demographic factors also play a crucial role in shaping preferences. For instance, a majority of Hispanics who consider their Hispanic identity extremely or very important (60%) would vote for the Democratic candidate in their local congressional district [6]. The bar chart illustrates these preferences across various demographic groups, showing variations in support for Democratic and Republican candidates [11].
![Preferences of different voter demographic groups](image4)
Latino registered voters’ future party affiliation remains uncertain [1].

In summary, Latino voters' party affiliations have remained largely unchanged from 2019 to 2022, with a consistent preference for the Democratic Party, while the importance of issues like the economy remains high and abortion has significantly risen in importance.

Hispanic Democrats and Republicans hold significantly differing views on both Trump's future political role and the perception of racial discrimination.

Regarding Trump's future role, a clear majority of Hispanic registered voters (73%) do not want Trump to remain a national political figure [4]. This sentiment is overwhelmingly shared by Latino Democrats and Democratic leaners, with 94% opposing his continued involvement [4].  A detailed breakdown further reveals that among Latino Democrats or those leaning Democratic, 93% believe Trump should not remain a national political figure [1].  Conversely, 63% of Hispanic Republicans and GOP leaners want Trump to remain a national political figure [4], and two-thirds within that group specifically desire his continued presence [2]. The view also differs on religious lines.  Evangelicals (43%) are more likely than Catholics (22%) and those with no religious affiliation (18%) to say Trump should remain a national political figure [3].
![Opinions on whether Trump should remain a national political figure, by demographic groups.](image6)

On the issue of racial discrimination, there is a sharp partisan divide. Nearly three-quarters of Latino Democrats and Democratic leaners (73%) believe that the bigger problem is people not seeing racial discrimination where it really exists [10].
![Perceptions of racial discrimination among Latinos, by political affiliation and importance of Hispanic identity.](image5)
In contrast, 62% of Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners say the bigger problem is people seeing racial discrimination where it does not exist [10].

In conclusion, Hispanic Democrats largely oppose Trump's continued political involvement and believe that अनदेखी racial discrimination is a significant problem, while Hispanic Republicans generally support Trump's continued role and are more concerned about perceived overstatements of racial discrimination.

Hispanic registered voters' views on Donald Trump's political future are sharply divided along party lines [6, 11]. A significant majority (73%) of Hispanic registered voters believe Trump should not remain a national political figure [4, 6]. This sentiment is overwhelmingly strong among Latino Democrats (94%) [4, 6]. In contrast, 63% of Hispanic Republicans want Trump to remain a national political figure [6, 11].
![Those who think trump should remain a political figure.](image5)

This division among Hispanics extends to the issues of racial discrimination. A clear majority of Hispanics (66%) who consider being Hispanic important to their identity say that people not seeing racial discrimination where it exists is a significant problem [8].
![Perception of racial discrimination](image8)

Regarding gun policy, about seven-in-ten Hispanics (73%) believe it is more important to control gun ownership, while 26% prioritize protecting the right to own guns [9]. Hispanic Democrats are about twice as likely as Hispanic Republicans to prioritize controlling gun ownership (85% vs. 45%) [9].
![Hispanic and US adults views on gun control](image7)

In summary, Hispanic registered voters' views on Trump's political future are strongly tied to their party affiliation, with Democrats overwhelmingly opposing his continued involvement, while Republicans largely support it, mirroring their differing views on issues like racial discrimination and gun control.

A significant partisan divide exists among Hispanic voters regarding the political future of Donald Trump. A clear majority of Hispanic Republicans and GOP leaners (63%) want Trump to remain a national political figure, with approximately 40% favoring a presidential run in 2024 [12].  In stark contrast, nearly all Latino Democrats and Democratic leaners (94%) believe Trump should not remain a national political figure [12]. This division is visually represented in a bar chart.
![The image is a bar chart showing survey results about whether Trump should remain a national political figure. It breaks down respondents by demographics and political affiliation, illustrating the percentage of each group that thinks Trump should not remain in politics and those that think he should, divided into two categories.](image1)

Perceptions of racial discrimination also differ significantly between Hispanic Republicans and Democrats [9]. While a majority of Latino Democrats and Democratic leaners (73%) believe that the bigger problem is people not seeing racial discrimination where it truly exists, about six-in-ten Republicans and Republican leaners (62%) hold the opposite view, stating that it is a bigger problem that people see racial discrimination where it does not exist [2]. This disparity is illustrated on another bar chart.

![The image is a bar graph comparing perceptions of racial discrimination among different groups of Latinos. It shows two main categories.](image8)

In summary, Hispanic Republicans are more likely to support Trump's continued political involvement and believe that people often perceive racial discrimination where it doesn't exist, whereas Hispanic Democrats overwhelmingly oppose Trump's political future and believe that the bigger issue is the failure to recognize actual racial discrimination.

Hispanic perceptions of socialism and capitalism vary significantly based on political affiliation and age.

Among all Hispanics, a larger share views socialism negatively (53%) compared to positively (41%), while views on capitalism are more positive (54%) than negative (41%) [5].

Breaking it down by political affiliation:
*   Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners are split in their views of socialism, with 50% viewing it positively and 48% negatively [2].
*    Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners have a much more negative impression of socialism, with 72% viewing it negatively [8].
*  About two-thirds of Hispanic Republicans have a positive view of capitalism (68%), compared to 50% of Hispanic Democrats [7].
*  ![Perceptions of Hispanic Identity by Political Affiliation and Age](image5)

When considering age:
*   Latinos ages 18 to 29 are more evenly divided on socialism, with 46% holding a positive view and 50% a negative view [12].

In summary, Hispanic Republicans are more negative towards socialism and more positive towards capitalism than Hispanic Democrats, and older Hispanics generally view socialism more negatively than younger Hispanics.

Hispanic views on socialism and capitalism vary significantly across political affiliations. Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners are more likely to have a positive view of capitalism (68%) compared to Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners (50%) [12]. This difference is visually represented in a bar chart.

Conversely, Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners are split on their view of socialism, with 50% viewing it positively and 48% negatively [11]. The views on socialism among Hispanics are further detailed showing that a larger share of Hispanics have a negative impression (53%) than a positive one (41%) [10].
