The population distribution in Nepal as of September 2014 shows distinct patterns across caste/ethnicity, religion, and geographic location.

In terms of caste/ethnicity, the data is categorized into various groups such as Chhetri, Brahman-Hill, Magar, Tharu, and others, with further classification into Non-Madhesi and Madhesi origins [5]. The specific percentages for September 2014 are detailed in a table, showing a diverse ethnic composition. ![Distribution of Castes and Ethnicities in Nepal, September 2014](image4). The Non-Madhesi group constitutes 64.7% of the population, while the Madhesi group makes up 35.3% [11].
![Non-Madhesi and Madhesi Population Distribution, September 2014](image11)

Religiously, the population predominantly follows Hinduism, with a significant increase to 84.9% in September 2014. Other religions such as Buddhism, Islam, Christianity, and Kirat have smaller percentages, with some variations over time. ![Religious Distribution in Nepal, September 2014](image8).

Geographically, the population distribution is divided among the Mountain, Hill, and Tarai regions [4]. The distribution shows that the Mountain region holds 6.7%, the Hill region 43.1%, and the Tarai region 50.2% of the population in September 2014. ![Geographic Population Distribution in Nepal, September 2014](image10). The sample distribution among Eastern, Central, Western, Mid-Western, and Far-Western follow general population distribution as well [4].
![Population Distribution by Regions in Nepal, September 2014](image9)

The population distribution by caste/ethnicity, religion, and geographic location in Nepal as of September 2014 reveals a diverse ethnic composition dominated by the Non-Madhesi group, a predominantly Hindu population, and a geographic distribution concentrated in the Tarai and Hill regions.

The provided information focuses on the demographic composition of a *sample* used in surveys, not the entire population of Nepal. It describes the sample's characteristics across three survey waves, emphasizing its alignment with national census data.

The data consistently shows that the sample's rural-urban distribution reflects the 2011 census figures [10]. Specifically, 83 percent of respondents were from rural areas, and 17 percent were from urban areas across all three survey waves [3, 10]. This consistency suggests there were no intentional changes in the sampling methodology regarding rural-urban distribution between the initial period and September 2014.

There is no image provided.
The documents do not offer a direct comparison of caste/ethnicity composition changes over time, and only show the Sample composition by caste/ethnic group [11].

In summary, the rural-urban distribution in the sample remained constant, reflecting the national distribution, with 83% from rural areas and 17% from urban areas, and no information on caste/ethnicity changes are presented.

Indonesian mobile internet users engage in a variety of activities, with social media being the most prominent at 24%, followed by entertainment (20%), and general information seeking (16%) [2]. Shopping accounts for 8% of mobile internet activities.

![Most downloaded mobile content are games/apps and video.](image2)

When it comes to online shopping, apparel is the most popular category (67.1%), followed by shoes (20.2%) and bags (20.0%). A similar trend is observed in offline shopping, where apparel (79.2%) also leads, followed by shoes (56.4%) and bags (17.0%).

![Types of products respondents bought offline and online.](image4)

Instant messaging is heavily used, with 90% of mobile phone users utilizing it daily [10]. E-commerce users show a preference for shopping through various channels, including IM groups (27%), social media (26%), conventional e-commerce sites (20%), and forums/classifieds (27%) [10]. This shows how there is intersect between social media and shopping behaviors.

In conclusion, mobile internet usage in Indonesia significantly influences shopping behavior, with a considerable portion of online shopping activities being conducted through channels directly related to popular mobile internet activities like social media and instant messaging.

Indonesia has a significant number of mobile internet users, with 62% of internet users accessing the web via mobile [10]. The demographics of these users show a youthful skew, with the largest segments of mobile users being between 18-24 (32%) and 25-35 (33%) years old. This data suggests there are notable percentage of mobile users are young.
![Age distribution and occupations of mobile internet users in Indonesia.](image8)

This demographic profile directly influences mobile content preferences. The most downloaded mobile content includes games/apps (70%), video (49%), and music (44%) [3]. In terms of activities, social media (24%) and entertainment (20%) are highly popular [3].
![Mobile Internet Usage and Download Statistics.](image3)

Instant messaging is also a crucial communication method, with 90% of mobile phone users using IM daily [12].

The prevalence of young users and their engagement with social media, entertainment, and instant messaging opens significant business opportunities. For instance, e-commerce is growing, with a substantial portion of online shopping occurring via social media (26%) and IM groups (27%) [12]. Revenue models in the mobile internet space include advertisements, revenue share/commission, and traffic/user exchange (for businesses), as well as games, music, downloads, and value-added services (for consumers) [4].
![Business models in the mobile internet space.](image4)
![Offline and online shopping preferences among respondents.](image5)

Venture capital firms are actively investing in Indonesian internet and consumer sectors, indicating strong market potential [7].
![Venture capital firms and their investment portfolios.](image7)

The Indonesian mobile ads market is also substantial, with mobile devices influencing 55% of customer decisions [5].

In summary, the demographics of mobile internet users in Indonesia, characterized by a young and highly engaged user base, drive content preferences towards social media, entertainment, and instant messaging, creating diverse business opportunities in e-commerce, mobile advertising, and digital content.

Over the years, the telecommunications landscape in Indonesia has seen significant shifts, especially concerning subscriber numbers and data usage among the major providers: Telkomsel, XL, and Indosat.

In Indonesia, 6 GSM/WCDMA & CDMA operators, 1 LTE operator, and 1 WiMAX operator are present [10]. Big 3 telco are Telkomsel, XL Axiata, and Indosat (all GSM operators) [10].
GSM is much more dominant technology.
![GSM has a significantly larger share compared to CDMA.](image4)

Telkomsel has consistently led the market.
![Telkomsel has the largest market share at 42%.](image5)
In terms of subscribers and data users, there are clear distinctions among these providers.
![Telkomsel leads in both subscriber count and data user numbers, followed by XL and then Indosat.](image3)
Telkomsel has the highest subscribers (139.3 million), Smartphone Users(35.4 million), and Data users(63.5 million) [image3]. XL has the second highest Subscribers (58.3 million) and data users (32 million) [image3]. Indosat has 54.2 million subscribers and 29 million data users [image3]. The dominance of Telkomsel is clear in subscriber and data users.

There are some changes if we see the metrics, for example, subscribers, Smartphone users, BlackBerry Users, and Data Users for late 2014.
![Telkomsel still maintains the lead in subscribers and data users in late 2014, but XL shows a notable increase in subscriber count.](image6)

The Average Revenue Per User (ARPU) has changed over the years across various services.
![Mobile Data ARPU has been increasing.](image1)
The prepaid ARPU figures for 2008 and 2012, sourced from Venture Consulting Analysis.
![Prepaid ARPU has declined for all major telecom companies from 2008 to 2012.](image7)

In conclusion, Telkomsel consistently leads in both subscriber count and data user numbers, followed by XL and Indosat, across the observed periods.

Let's analyze the changes in Telkomsel's subscriber base and ARPU (Average Revenue Per User) from 2013 to 2014, along with potential contributing factors.

Telkomsel had 139.3 million subscribers in early 2014 [12]. And It had 132.7 million Subscribers in late 2014[11].

![Telecom Subscriber Comparison](image6)

The subscriber base increased. As for ARPU.

![Prepaid ARPU Comparison (2008-2012)](image1)

Telkomsel's prepaid ARPU decreased from 53,000 Rp in 2008 to 34,000 Rp in 2012. This represents a significant decline over the four years. A general trend of declining ARPU in Indonesia was present until 2015. This decline was initially caused by a massive price war initiated by the government [7]. CDMA operators also played a role by forcing GSM operators to reduce their tariffs [6].

![ARPU Trends (2013-2017)](image2)

More recently, the shift towards data-based communication methods (Instant Messaging, VoIP) has led to decreased usage of traditional SMS and voice calls [9], further impacting ARPU. The graph shows declining Voice and SMS, but Mobile Data will increase after 2015 [5].

In conclusion, Telkomsel's subscriber base experienced continuous growth, while its ARPU decreased between 2008 and 2012, and there is a continued trend of declining ARPU until 2015 where data users will start to enroll for bigger data plans [5].

Between 2013 and 2014, Telkomsel and XL experienced changes in their number of smartphone users and ARPU.

Telkomsel had 35.4 million smartphone users, and XL had 15 million smartphone users[3].
![Subscriber, Smartphone User, BlackBerry User, Android User, and Data User Metrics for Telkomsel, XL, and Indosat](image3)

The ARPU trends showed a general decline during this period. Voice and SMS ARPU were decreasing [1], influenced by the increasing use of data-based IM and VoIP services [4]. This shift led to less usage of traditional SMS and voice calls, consequently reducing ARPU [7].
![ARPU Trends for Voice, SMS, and Mobile Data from 2013 to 2017](image1)
The overall ARPU in Indonesia also saw a decline from 2008 to 2012 [5].
![Indonesia Prepaid ARPU Trend from 2008 to 2012](image5)
Initially, the massive price war, initiated by the government, was the factor causing the decline in ARPU[11].

In conclusion, between 2013 and 2014, Telkomsel and XL saw an increase in smartphone users, while ARPU for voice and SMS declined due to increased data usage and previous price wars.

Streaming and album sales vary significantly across different music genres, reflecting diverse consumption patterns. For instance, Rock has the highest share of album sales at 37%, but its streaming share is much lower at 23%  ![image8](image8). This suggests a preference for traditional album consumption among Rock listeners [11].

In contrast, R&B/Hip-Hop shows a higher streaming share (26%) compared to album sales (18%) ![image8](image8), indicating a trend towards streaming in this genre [12]. Pop music has a relatively balanced distribution, with album sales at 19% and streaming at 23% ![image8](image8), highlighting a mixed consumption pattern [12].

Country music shows a similar trend to Rock, with a higher album sales share (12%) than streaming (6%) ![image8](image8). However, Latin music exhibits the most significant shift towards streaming, with a 10% share in streams compared to only 2% in album sales ![image8](image8). This could be related that Latin music fans are more inclined towards digital consumption through streaming platforms.

Overall, the comparison indicates that while album sales remain significant for genres like Rock and Country, streaming is becoming dominant, especially in genres like R&B/Hip-Hop and Latin music. Streaming has become the leading format. [7].

In conclusion, streaming is more prevalent in R&B/Hip-Hop and Latin genres, while album sales are more significant in Rock and Country, reflecting varied consumer preferences across genres.

Streaming constitutes a significant portion of total music activity, but its impact varies considerably across different genres. Overall, streams make up 70% of total music activity [8].
![Streams are 70% of music activity.](image2)

However, when broken down by genre, the contribution of streaming shows diverse patterns:

-   **Rock**: Streaming accounts for 82% of the catalog share in Rock music [10].
![The catalog share of streams in Rock music is 82%.](image3)
-   **R&B/Hip-Hop**: Streams make up 61% of the catalog share for this genre.
![Streams make up 61% of the R&B/Hip-Hop catalog.](image3)
-   **Pop**: 58% of the catalog share in Pop music comes from streams.
![Streams account for 58% of the Pop catalog share.](image3)
-   **Country**: Streaming represents 70% of the catalog share in Country music.
![Streams are 70% of the Country catalog share.](image3)
-   **Latin**: This genre has the highest reliance on streaming, with 68% of total activity attributed to Streaming Equivalent Albums (SEA).
![68% of total Latin music activity is SEA.](image5)
-   **Dance/Electronic**: 51% of the total activity in this genre is from SEA.
![SEA makes up 51% of Dance/Electronic total activity.](image5)

In Latin music streaming is 68%.

Streaming's contribution to total music activity varies significantly by genre, with the highest percentages in Latin (68%) and Rock (82%) music, and the lowest in Dance/Electronic (51%).

The catalog shares of different music formats vary significantly across genres [12].

![The image is a bar graph comparing the catalog share of different music formats across four music genres: Rock, Pop, R&B/Hip-Hop, and Country. Each genre is represented by four bars, each indicating the percentage share of Total Activity, Album Sales, Song Sales, and Streams.  - **Rock**:   - Total Activity: 68%   - Album Sales: 63%   - Song Sales: 68%   - Streams: 82%  - **Pop**:   - Total Activity: 36%   - Album Sales: 21%   - Song Sales: 30%   - Streams: 58%  - **R&B/Hip-Hop**:   - Total Activity: 52%   - Album Sales: 46%   - Song Sales: 47%   - Streams: 61%  - **Country**:   - Total Activity: 55%   - Album Sales: 54%   - Song Sales: 48%   - Streams: 70%  The color coding is as follows: - Green: Total Activity - Orange: Album Sales - Purple: Song Sales - Red: Streams  Each percentage value is labeled in blue above the respective bars. The graph provides a visualization of how each format contributes to the overall catalog activity in each music genre.](image1)

For Rock, the catalog share is highest in streams (82%) and lowest in album sales (63%). Pop has its highest catalog share in streams (58%) and its lowest in album sales (21%). R&B/Hip-Hop's catalog share peaks in streams (61%) and is lowest in album sales (46%). Country music's catalog share is highest in streams (70%) and lowest in song sales (48%) [12].

![The table displays a ranking list of music albums based on their total sales volume. It includes the following columns:  1. **Rank**: Position in the list. 2. **Artist**: Name of the musician or band. 3. **Title**: Title of the album. 4. **Total Volume (000)**: Total number of units sold in thousands. 5. **Album Share**: Percentage of sales attributed to the full album. 6. **Song Sales Share**: Percentage of sales attributed to individual songs. 7. **On-Demand Audio Stream Share**: Percentage of sales attributed to on-demand audio streams.  Highlighted values in green indicate the highest percentages for "Song Sales Share" (48% for Maroon 5) and "On-Demand Audio Stream Share" (18% for Nicki Minaj), as well as the highest "Album Share" (84% for Kendrick Lamar). Taylor Swift ranks first with 1,608,000 total sales volume.](image5)

As for albums with high on-demand audio stream shares, Nicki Minaj's album has the highest percentage at 18% in the given image that provide the ranking list of music albums based on their total sales volume.

In summary, catalog share percentages vary significantly between music genres, with streaming generally having a high share across all formats, and Nicki Minaj has the highest on-demand audio stream share among the listed albums.

In 2015, Rock was the dominant genre in album sales, but R&B/Hip-Hop led in streaming [1]. Rock had the highest share of total activity at 30%, followed by R&B/Hip-Hop at 21%, and Pop at 17% [6].
![Share of Total Activity by Genre](image2)
A more detailed breakdown shows that Rock had 37% of album sales, 24% of song sales, and 23% of streams. R&B/Hip-Hop had 18% of album sales, 23% of song sales, and 26% of streams. Pop had 19% of album sales, 26% of song sales, and 23% of streams [4].
![Genre Share of Total for Album Sales, Song Sales, and Streams](image4)
Streaming became the leading format overall and in most genres [10, 11]. For example, within R&B/Hip-Hop, streaming accounted for 39% of the total music sales, while in Pop, it accounted for 36% [5].
![Distribution of Music Sales Across Different Genres](image5)
In summary, Rock dominated album sales, while R&B/Hip-Hop was the most streamed genre in 2015.

In 2015, the distribution of music sales formats varied significantly across different genres [8].

For instance, Rock music had a higher percentage of sales in Physical Albums (32%) and Digital Albums (26%), while R&B/Hip-Hop showed a stronger reliance on Streaming Equivalent Albums (SEA) with 39% [3]. Pop music also demonstrated a significant portion of sales from streaming (36%), whereas Country music leaned more towards Physical Albums (35%) [image1]. Notably, Latin music had the highest dependency on streaming, with 68% of its total sales attributed to SEA, and Dance/Electronic music also showed a strong streaming presence at 51% [image1].

The genres that rely most on streaming are Latin and Dance/Electronic.

In comparing music consumption formats between Rock and R&B/Hip-Hop, distinct patterns emerge. For Rock, the catalog share is notably high across all formats, with 68% for Total Activity, 63% for Album Sales, 68% for Song Sales, and a significant 82% for Streams [12]. This suggests that older Rock music remains popular.
![Rock has the highest catalog share in streaming at 82%.](image4)
On the other hand, R&B/Hip-Hop shows a different trend. The Total Activity catalog share is 52%, Album Sales at 46%, Song Sales at 47%, and Streams at 61% [12].
![R&B/Hip-Hop shows a 61% catalog share in streams, lower than Rock.](image4)
These figures indicate that, for both genres, streaming is a dominant format [8]. It’s clear that streaming constitutes a substantial portion of overall music activity at 57% [image1].
![Streaming is the highest percentage of total music activity, at 57%.](image1)
However, the catalog share for streams is much higher in Rock (82%) compared to R&B/Hip-Hop (61%), indicating that Rock music listeners are more engaged with older tracks, while R&B/Hip-Hop has a comparatively stronger focus on current tracks and a substantial streaming presence [12, 9].

In summary, Rock music has a higher catalog share in streaming compared to R&B/Hip-Hop, indicating Rock fans listen to older music more, while R&B/Hip-Hop fans also significantly engage with streaming, but have greater relative engagement with current music.

Overall, music streaming constitutes the largest share of the music business [9, 12]. The trends in streaming and album sales differ significantly across music genres, and here’s how and their implications:

*   **Rock**: This genre leads in album sales, with physical and digital albums making up a significant portion of its total sales [6]. Specifically, physical albums are at 32% and digital albums at 26% [4]. However, streaming is not as dominant in Rock, with Streaming Equivalent Albums (SEA) at 26% [4]. Rock’s catalog share is high across all formats [8], especially in streams where it reaches 82%  ![Share of catalog across music formats](image8).
*   **R&B/Hip-Hop**: This genre is strong in streaming [6]. The breakdown shows SEA at 39%, leading all other categories in this genre [4]. Hip-hop fans are at the front of digital music movement [3]. Hip-hop fans also spend 35% more annually on music [5].
*   **Pop**: Pop music sees a balance between album sales and streaming, but with a tilt towards streaming [6]. Pop is driven by "Current" and "Streams" [8]. Album sales are divided between physical (18%) and digital (15%) formats, while SEA constitutes 36% of sales [4].
*    **Latin**: The Latin genre shows a very high dependency on streaming, with SEA accounting for 68% of its total, by far the highest among all genres [4].

Artists in top streamed songs are trendsetters in music industry [1]. As an example of top songs, "Uptown Funk!" by Mark Ronson feat. Bruno Mars tops the charts with 285,647,000 streams.
![Top On-Demand Songs YTD](image1)

For top albums of a year, Taylor Swift’s album achieved the highest total volume with 1,608,000 sales.
![Top albums, ranked by total sales volume](image2)

These differences suggest that the music industry is highly segmented by genre preferences, with some genres like Rock maintaining a strong foothold in traditional album sales, while others like R&B/Hip-Hop and Latin are heavily dominant in the streaming format.

The main implications of these is that streaming has become the primary format for music consumption across most genres.

The music industry sees varied consumption patterns across different genres and formats [1]. For instance, Rock music dominates album sales, while Pop music leads in song sales, and R&B/Hip-Hop is at the forefront of streaming [6].

When examining catalog activity (older releases) versus current activity (new releases), interesting trends emerge. Overall, streams are 70% catalog [12].
![Streams %](image5)
Across genres, Rock has the highest catalog share in streams at 82%, while Pop has the lowest at 58% [2].
![The catalog share of different music formats across four music genres: Rock, Pop, R&B/Hip-Hop, and Country.](image2)
In terms of total activity, Rock leads with a 30% share, followed by R&B/Hip-Hop at 21%, and Pop at 17% [7].
![Share of Total Activity](image7)
The distribution of music sales across different genres shows that for all music, Streaming Equivalent Albums (SEA) make up 34%, while Physical Albums (Phys Albums) account for 24% [4].
![Distribution of Music Sales across different genres](image4)
In summary, streaming is predominantly catalog-driven across most genres, with Rock having the highest catalog share in streaming, while album sales vary significantly by genre, with Rock leading in overall album sales.

The report focuses on the Vietnam market and uses data from Q3 2015 on the App ota platform, in addition to publicly available data [3].

Regarding the adoption rates of Android operating systems, the image shows a comparison between Q2 and Q3 of 2015. Lollipop, Google's latest OS, had a significant increase in adoption, rising from 16% in Q2 to 35% in Q3 [6].
![This image is a bar chart comparing the usage percentages of different Android operating system versions across two quarters in 2015.](image6)

For iOS, the image presents a comparison of device usage across different iOS versions between Q2 and Q3 of 2015. iOS 9, which was not present in Q2, had a 13% usage rate in Q3. iOS 8 experienced significant growth, increasing from 29% in Q2 to 52% in Q3 [8].
![This image is a bar chart comparing the percentage of devices running different versions of iOS during the second and third quarters of 2015.](image7)

In terms of market share for different phone brands. Samsung holds the largest share at 36% [11].
![The image is a pie chart depicting the market share of different phone brands.](image1)

In summary, during Q2 and Q3 of 2015, Lollipop (Android) and iOS 9 saw increased adoption rates, while Samsung maintained the largest market share among phone brands at 36%.

Android has significantly dominated the smartphone market, holding a share of 82.8% as of Q2 2015 [2]. This dominance is visually represented in a line graph showing Android's increasing market share over three years, reaching 82.8% by Q2 2015, while iOS's share decreased to 13.9% in the same period [7].
![Android's market share significantly increased, reaching 82.8% by Q2 2015, while iOS declined to 13.9%.](image7)

In terms of the distribution of different Android versions, Lollipop and KitKat have the largest portions. Specifically, KitKat stands at 39.2% [4], and Lollipop accounts for 35% of total Android users [9]. The distribution is visualized in a donut chart where Lollipop and KitKat clearly occupy larger segments, with Lollipop, Google's latest OS, showing a big adoption rate [9].
![Donut chart representing the distribution of various Android operating system versions, with Lollipop and KitKat having the largest shares.](image8)

In another perspective, there is data on the market shares of different mobile operating systems, including Android with 44.6%, iOS with 33.4%, Java with 19.8%, and Windows Phone with 2.3% [4].
![Comparison of market shares among different mobile platforms, showing Android leading followed by iOS, Java, and Windows Phone.](image4)

iOS, despite its lower market share compared to Android, has shown a rapid adoption rate for its latest version. Specifically, iOS 9 had more than 50% of devices using it as measured by the App Store on September 19, 2015 [5]. However, iOS saw its market share for 2015/Q2 decline by 22.3% QoQ with 47.5 million shipments [11].

In summary, Android leads in market share globally and has a varied distribution among its versions, with Lollipop and KitKat being the most prevalent, while iOS has a smaller market share but a high adoption rate for its newest operating system version.

iOS 9 has experienced a rapid adoption rate, with over 50% of devices using it as measured by the App Store on September 19, 2015 [8].
![iOS 9 has the fastest adoption rate ever, with more than 50 percent of devices already using it.](image1)
Android's latest OS, Lollipop, also has a significant adoption rate, accounting for 35% of total Android users [6]. A more detailed breakdown of Android versions shows that Lollipop (versions 5.0 and 5.1 combined) makes up 21% of the Android market, while KitKat remains the most prevalent version at 39.2% [2].

The LOGIC-LM framework, as depicted in the flowchart, consists of three primary components: the Problem Formulator, the Symbolic Reasoner, and the Result Interpreter. The Self-Refine component iteratively refines the process by feeding back into the Problem Formulator [11].
![The image is a flowchart depicting the overview of the LOGIC-LM framework. It consists of three main components: 1. Problem Formulator: Takes input from "Problem" and "Goal" and produces a "Symbolic Formulation." 2. Symbolic Reasoner: Uses the symbolic formulation to generate a "Symbolic Result." 3. Result Interpreter: Interprets the symbolic result to provide an "Answer." There is also a "Self-Refine" component that feeds back into the Problem Formulator to refine the process iteratively.](image1)
For deductive reasoning, LOGIC-LM uses the Pyke expert system, which relies on logic programming [10]. Pyke works by first building a knowledge base filled with established facts and rules. It then employs forward- and backward-chaining algorithms to deduce new information and validate the objective [10].
![This table compares the performance of GPT-3.5 and GPT-4 on various datasets: ProntoQA, ProofWriter, FOLIO, Logical Deduction, and AR-LSAT. It evaluates two metrics: Execution Rate (Exe_Rate) and Execution Accuracy (Exe_Acc), with and without SR (System Rewrite) indicated by '+' and '−'.](image3)

The symbolic solver used to implement the logic programming module in Figure 1 is the Pyke expert system.

No, the information flow from label words to the target position does not dominate in all layers. In shallow layers, the information flow from the text part to label words ($S_{wp}$) is high, while the information flow from label words to targeted positions ($S_{pq}$) is low [6]. In deep layers, $S_{pq}$ becomes the dominant one [6]. This is further illustrated in the figures showing the relative sizes of $S_{wp}$, $S_{pq}$, and $S_{ww}$ in different layers. Initially, $S_{wp}$ occupies a significant proportion, but it gradually decays over layers, while $S_{pq}$ becomes the dominant one [10].

Therefore, the dominance of information flow changes between shallow and deep layers.

The system generates a response to the user's request through a multi-stage process, as depicted in the overall architecture [3].

First, the user's input in natural language is encoded into a continuous vector using a bidirectional LSTM utterance encoder [3]. This encoding, along with the encoding of the previous system action, feeds into a dialogue-level LSTM, which maintains a continuous representation of the dialogue state [3].

Based on this dialogue state, the model generates a probability distribution over candidate values for each tracked goal slot [3]. The dialogue state tracking component maintains the state of the conversation and updates its estimation of the user's goal, represented by slot-value pairs [10].

A query command is then formulated using the state tracking outputs and issued to a knowledge base to retrieve information [3].
![End-to-end task-oriented dialogue system architecture](image6)
The system then produces a dialogue action conditioned on the dialogue state, the estimated user's goal, and the encoding of the query results [3]. This dialogue action is determined by the policy network.
![Dialogue state and policy network](image1)
Finally, the system generates a natural language response using a natural language generator (NLG) [3]. The NLG combines the state tracker outputs, the retrieved knowledge base (KB) entities, and the emitted system action [6]. In this specific system, a template-based NLG is used, where delexicalised tokens in the template are replaced by values from either the estimated user goal values or the KB entities [6].

The response generation of the system is achieved by encoding the user input, maintaining a dialogue state, querying a knowledge base, determining a system action through a policy network, and generating a natural language response via an NLG.

RAPTOR consistently enhances the performance of various models across different datasets, as evidenced by improvements in both accuracy and F1 scores.

On the QuALITY dataset, RAPTOR improves accuracy:
  *   When used with GPT-3, RAPTOR achieved an accuracy of 62.4%, outperforming DPR (60.4%) and BM25 (57.3%) [2].
  *   With UnifiedQA, RAPTOR's accuracy was 56.6%, surpassing DPR (53.9%) and BM25 (49.9%) [2].
  *   These improvements are also visualized, showing RAPTOR's superior performance. ![RAPTOR shows the highest accuracy in both GPT-3 Acc. and UnifiedQA Acc. categories.](image2)

For the QASPER dataset, RAPTOR demonstrates improved F1 scores:
*   Using GPT-3, RAPTOR's F1 score was 53.1%, exceeding DPR (51.3%) and BM25 (46.6%) [5].
*   With GPT-4, RAPTOR achieved an F1 score of 55.7%, again surpassing DPR (53.0%) and BM25 (50.2%) [5].
    *   With UnifiedQA, RAPTOR's F1 score of 36.6% surpassed DPR (32.1%) and BM25(26.4%) [5].
*   The table comparing F-1 scores on the QASPER dataset clearly shows RAPTOR's superior performance. ![RAPTOR has the highest scores across all models.](image6)
*   A direct comparison shows RAPTOR with GPT-4 achieving the highest F-1 score. ![RAPTOR + GPT-4 achieved the highest score of 55.7.](image4)

In general, across all the datasets(QASPER, Narrative QA, and QuALITY), RAPTOR consistently outperforms the respective retriever across all datasets when combined with any retriever [9].
These results prove RAPTOR's effectiveness in enhancing model performance, consistently improving both accuracy and F1 scores across various models and datasets.

The SnapNTell dataset is distinct from traditional VQA datasets in several key ways. It encompasses a wide range of categorized entities, each represented by images and explicitly named in the answers [10]. SnapNTell includes 22 major categories [10], with a total of 7,568 unique entities [5, 10].
![Table showing SnapNTell has 22 categories and 7568 entities.](image5)
This is a significantly larger number of categories and entities compared to datasets like ViQuAE and Encyclopedic VQA [9].
![Table showing comparison of SnapNTell with other datasets.](image7)
Furthermore, it features QA pairs that require extensive knowledge for accurate responses, going beyond simplistic binary answers [7]. The average answer length in SnapNTell is 25.7 words, considerably longer than other datasets, indicating the depth of knowledge required [9].
![Table showing SnapNTell is knowledge-intensive and entity-centric.](image8)
SnapNTell is specifically designed for entity-centric VQA, testing models' abilities in identifying entities and providing detailed, entity-specific knowledge [10]. This contrasts with other datasets that may focus on freeform answers, yes/no questions, or choice selection [4].
![Comparison of SnapNTell with existing VQA methods.](image1)
In summary, the SnapNTell dataset surpasses others in the variety of categories, number of entities, and focus on knowledge-intensive responses.

Across multiple datasets, the model that consistently achieves the highest F1 score is BERT+DSC or XLNet+DSC, with DSC referring to a specific training objective or loss function used to enhance the base models.

For instance, in Part-of-Speech (POS) tagging tasks on Chinese datasets (CTB5, CTB6, and UD1.4), BERT+DSC outperforms other models, including Joint-POS, Lattice-LSTM, and the base BERT-Tagger [10]. Specifically, it achieves F1 scores of 97.92 on CTB5, 96.57 on CTB6, and 96.98 on UD1.4 [8]. This is visually confirmed in the data presented, where BERT+DSC consistently shows the highest F1 scores across these datasets.
![Highest F1 Score: BERT+DSC (97.92 on CTB5, 96.57 on CTB6, and 96.98 on UD1.4).](image2)

In Machine Reading Comprehension (MRC) tasks, both BERT+DSC and XLNet+DSC show significant performance boosts. For example, on the SQuAD v1.1 dataset, XLNet+DSC outperforms the base XLNet model by +1.25 in F1 score and +0.84 in Exact Match (EM) [2].
![Performance Summary: XLNet+DSC achieves the highest scores among XLNet variants, outperforming the base XLNet model by +1.25 in F1 score and +0.84 in EM.](image1)

Similarly, for Named Entity Recognition (NER) tasks, DSC-enhanced models show superior performance. On the English OntoNotes 5.0 dataset, BERT-MRC+DSC achieves the highest F1-score of 92.07, an improvement of +0.96 over the base BERT-MRC model [1, 12].
![The table presents the performance of different models on the English OntoNotes 5.0 dataset, with BERT-MRC+DSC having the highest F1-score.](image5)
On the English CoNLL 2003 dataset, BERT-MRC+DSC records a precision of 93.41, recall of 93.25, and F1 Score of 93.33 (+0.29 improvement) [6].
![BERT-MRC+DSC improved by +0.29.](image6)

For paraphrase identification tasks on the MRPC and QQP datasets, both BERT+DSC and XLNet+DSC achieve the highest F1 scores compared to their base models and other variations [5].
![Highest scores in both datasets for both models, showing the most significant improvements.](image8)

On Chinese MSRA and Chinese OntoNotes 4.0, BERT-MRC+DSC model shows the highest F1-scores in both datasets.
![The BERT-MRC+DSC model shows the highest F1-scores in both datasets.](image7)

The highest F1 score on Chinese OntoNotes4.0 is 84.67 when α is set to 0.6 while for QuoRef, the highest F1 is 68.44 when α is set to 0.4 [4].
DSC achieves the highest F1 score across all datasets [6].

In summary, the **BERT+DSC or XLNet+DSC** consistently achieve the highest F1 scores across the various datasets and tasks.

The performance of the "Ours" model is benchmarked against several other Named Entity Recognition (NER) models, specifically focusing on accuracy and F1 scores. The data shows that the "Ours" model outperforms others across multiple metrics.

On the OntoNotes fine-grained entity typing test set, the "Ours" model, which utilizes all distant supervision sources (ONTO+WIKI+HEAD), shows superior results compared to prior work [4, 8]. Specifically, it achieves an accuracy of 59.5, a macro-averaged F1 score (Ma-F1) of 76.8, and a micro-averaged F1 score (Mi-F1) of 71.8. These figures are notably higher than those of other models like AttentiveNER++, AFET, and LNR [4].
![Comparison of model performance on the OntoNotes test set.](image2)

This enhanced performance is attributed to the combination of the model and the training data used [8]. When comparing different training data combinations, the "Ours" model consistently shows improvements. For instance, when trained on ONTO, WIKI, and HEAD data, the accuracy reaches 61.6, Ma-F1 is 77.3, and Mi-F1 is 71.8, which is the highest performance recorded among all tested configurations.
![Performance breakdown for different training data types.](image1)

These comparisons indicate that the "Ours" model sets a new state-of-the-art result by effectively leveraging multiple sources of supervision [11].

In conclusion, the "Ours" model demonstrates superior performance compared to other NER models, achieving the highest accuracy and F1 scores when trained with combined ONTO, WIKI, and HEAD datasets.

The $\mathrm{NCRF++}$ model utilizes a layered architecture to process and classify sequences, as illustrated in the provided diagram. The model processes the sentence at multiple levels.
![The image is a diagram representing the structure of the $\mathrm{NCRF++}$ model applied to the sentence “I love Bruce Lee.” It consists of three layers: 1. **Char Sequence Layer**:    - Green circles represent character embeddings for each character in the words of the sentence.   - These embeddings are processed through an RNN/CNN. 2. **Word Sequence Layer**:    - The output from the Char Sequence Layer, along with additional features represented by grey circles, contributes to word embeddings (represented by red and yellow circles).   - These are combined and processed to form word sequence representations. 3. **Inference Layer**:   - Blue circles represent the word sequence representations processed through the RNN/CNN.   - The final output is determined using either a Softmax or CRF (Conditional Random Field) function.](image5)

First, the **Char Sequence Layer** uses character embeddings (green circles) processed through an RNN/CNN. Then, the **Word Sequence Layer** combines these outputs with additional features (grey circles) to form word embeddings (red and yellow circles). Finally, the **Inference Layer** processes these representations through an RNN/CNN, with the final output determined by either a Softmax or CRF function [6].

The model's performance across various configurations is detailed. Specifically, the performances of six CRF-based models with different character and word sequence representations are shown [7].
![The table presents the performance of various models across three different tasks: Named Entity Recognition (NER), Chunking, and Part-of-Speech (POS) tagging. Each model is evaluated using either the F1-value (for NER and Chunking) or Accuracy (for POS) as the metric. 1. **Models**:     - The models are combinations of different components indicated by their names:         - Nochar+WCNN+CRF         - CLSTM+WCNN+CRF         - CCNN+WCNN+CRF         - Nochar+WLSTM+CRF         - CLSTM+WLSTM+CRF         - CCNN+WLSTM+CRF  2. **NER (Named Entity Recognition)**:     - Performance is reported as the F1-value.     - Best performance in NER is 91.35, achieved by the model: CCNN+WLSTM+CRF. 3. **Chunking**:     - Performance is reported as the F1-value.     - Best performance in Chunking is 95.06, achieved by the model: CCNN+WLSTM+CRF. 4. **POS (Part-of-Speech) tagging**:     - Performance is reported as Accuracy.     - Highest accuracy is 97.55, achieved by Ma and Hovy (2016) and Yang et al. (2017). 5. **Additional references**:     - Lample et al. (2016), Ma and Hovy (2016), Yang et al. (2017), and Peters et al. (2017) are additional models cited for comparison.     - Note that some values for these references are missing or not applicable (e.g., Chunking F1-value is not provided for Lample et al. and Peters et al.). Overall, the table primarily compares the efficiency of different model architectures in processing NER, Chunking, and POS tasks, highlighting significant achievers in each category.](image3)

For Named Entity Recognition (NER), the model that achieves the highest F1-value is "CCNN+WLSTM+CRF,". Character information significantly improves model performance [9]. The features contributing to this model are character-level CNN (CCNN), word-level LSTM (WLSTM), and a CRF layer [9].

The highest F1-value achieved for Named Entity Recognition (NER) is 91.35 by the CCNN+WLSTM+CRF model, utilizing character-level CNN, word-level LSTM, and a CRF layer.

The evaluation of various methods for news recommendation involves several approaches, focusing on user and news representations. Based on the provided data, different models have been tested and compared.

The LSTUR approach, which combines both long-term and short-term user representations, has shown superior performance compared to other baseline methods. This approach leverages an attention mechanism in the news encoder to select important words, enhancing the learning of informative news representations [6]. The LSTUR method is implemented in two variants: LSTUR-ini and LSTUR-con [8].

A detailed comparison of various methods is presented, showcasing the performance metrics such as AUC (Area Under the Curve) and nDCG@10 (Normalized Discounted Cumulative Gain at 10).
![Performance comparison of various methods](image4)
The table indicates that LSTUR-ini consistently achieves the highest values across all four metrics, signifying its superior performance [image4].

Further analysis reveals the effectiveness of incorporating both long-term and short-term user representations.
![Comparison of user representation methods](image8)
The chart highlights that LSTUR-ini outperforms other methods like LTUR, STUR, and LSTUR-con in both AUC and nDCG@10 metrics [image8].

Additionally, the research explores the optimal balance for incorporating long-term user representation (LTUR) by adjusting a masking probability parameter,  `p` .
![Influence of mask probability on performance](image1)
The charts for LSTUR-ini and LSTUR-con show that a moderate choice of `p` (around 0.5) is most appropriate for balancing the learning of LTUR and STUR, which helps in achieving optimal performance [10, 11, image1].

In conclusion, the LSTUR-ini method shows the best performance for news recommendation based on AUC and nDCG@10 metrics.

The architecture of the BERT classifier, as used in these experiments, involves processing the claim and reason as a combined first text segment, paired with each warrant independently [3].
![This image is a diagram illustrating the architecture of a BERT model used for processing input data. It shows how claims, reasons, and warrants are tokenized and input into the BERT model.](image2)
The final layer CLS vector from BERT is then passed to a linear layer to obtain logits, and the entire architecture is fine-tuned [3]. The general architecture for such models involves learning shared parameters to classify each warrant independently with the argument, yielding logits that are then concatenated and passed through a Softmax layer.
![The image depicts the general architecture of a model used in the experiments described in the accompanying caption.](image1)

In summary, BERT (Large) has the highest test median score, and its architecture involves processing claims and reasons combined with warrants, utilizing a final layer CLS vector passed to a linear layer for logit calculation.

The performance of BiDAF and FastQA models on the WikiHop and MedHop datasets varies significantly between the standard and gold chain conditions.

Under the **standard condition**, BiDAF outperforms FastQA on both datasets. Specifically, on WikiHop, BiDAF achieves a test accuracy of 42.9% and 49.7% (test*), while FastQA scores 25.7% and 27.2% (test*) [3]. On MedHop, BiDAF scores 47.8% and 61.2% (test*), whereas FastQA scores 23.1% and 24.5% (test*) [3].

Under the **gold chain condition**, where models are presented only with relevant documents, the performance of both models improves significantly [9]. BiDAF's performance on WikiHop rises to 57.9% and 63.4 (test*), and on MedHop, it dramatically increases to 86.4% and 89.8% (test*) [3]. FastQA also sees improvements, with scores on WikiHop going up to 44.5% and 53.5% (test*), and on MedHop to 54.6% and 59.2% (test*) [3].
These improvements show how the information from different locations can be integrated [3].
This indicates that both models, especially BiDAF, are capable of identifying the correct answer when provided with a clear path, but their performance in the standard setting is hampered by the presence of irrelevant documents.
This situation can be explained by a diagram that shows how to validate relationships between entities and documents within a knowledge base.
![Entities, Documents and Knowledge Base](image1)

The performance comparison is visually summarized in the table, highlighting the differences between the two models under both conditions.
![Performance on WikiHop and MedHop](image3)

In summary, BiDAF consistently outperforms FastQA on both WikiHop and MedHop datasets, and both models perform significantly better when provided only with relevant documents (gold chain).

The DETR (Detection Transformer) model's performance, particularly its Average Precision (AP), is influenced by different configurations of positional encodings and loss components. Let's look at positional encodings first.

The type of positional encoding used in both the encoder and decoder significantly impacts AP. Not using spatial positional encodings leads to a significant drop in AP [8]. Interestingly, passing them only in the decoder leads to a minor AP drop [8]. The baseline configuration, which achieves the highest AP, uses fixed sine positional encodings at every attention layer in both the encoder and the decoder [8].
![Table of Positional Encoding Results](image3)

The configurations of loss components on AP shows:
The combination of loss components used during training also affects the model's performance.
*   Using only `class` and `ℓ₁` losses results in an AP of 35.8.
*  Using `class` and `GIoU` losses improves the AP to 39.9.
*   The best performance is achieved when combining all three: `class`, `ℓ₁`, and `GIoU` losses, resulting in an AP of 40.6 [7].
![Loss configuration results](image7)

In summary, different configuration of both positional encodings and loss components have affect on AP in DETR model. Using fixed sine positional encodings in both encoder and decoder, and combining class, ℓ₁, and GIoU losses, results in the highest Average Precision.

PROGRAM FC consistently outperforms FLAN-T5 across all tested model sizes (Small, Base, Large, XL, XXL) and task complexities (2-hop, 3-hop, 4-hop) on the HOVER dataset, as evidenced by the F1 scores [6]. The performance advantage of PROGRAM FC is particularly noticeable when smaller language models are used. As model size decreases, the performance of the end-to-end FLAN-T5 model drops significantly, while PROGRAM FC's performance remains relatively stable [6].

The visual representation of this comparison is clear in the provided graphs:
![The image consists of three line graphs comparing the F1 scores of two fact-checking approaches, FLAN-T5 (blue line) and PROGRAM FC (green line), across different model sizes: FLAN-T5-small (80M), FLAN-T5-base (250M), FLAN-large (780M), FLAN-T5-XL (3B), and FLAN-T5-XXL (11B). The graphs assess performance on different HOVER fact-checking tasks, including 2-hop (left graph), 3-hop (middle graph), and 4-hop (right graph).

- **In the 2-hop scenario**, both methods show increasing F1 scores with larger models. PROGRAM FC consistently outperforms FLAN-T5 across all model sizes, with the highest score at 11B size (77.62 for PROGRAM FC and 77.07 for FLAN-T5).

- **In the 3-hop scenario**, similar trends are observed with increasing F1 scores as model size grows. Once again, PROGRAM FC shows consistently better performance than FLAN-T5, peaking at 69.56 for the 11B size, compared to 66.89 for FLAN-T5).

- **In the 4-hop scenario**, the PROGRAM FC maintains a higher F1 score across all model sizes, with a gradual increase as model sizes get larger. PROGRAM FC achieves the highest score of 68.18 at 11B, compared to FLAN-T5's 63.39.

Overall, PROGRAM FC consistently outperforms FLAN-T5 across all tested scenarios and model sizes.](image5)

For instance, PROGRAM FC using FLAN-T5-small (80M parameters) achieves comparable performance to the 137x larger FLAN-T5-XXL (11B parameters) model on 4-hop claims [6].

In terms of retrieval recall, PROGRAM FC, with its iterative step-by-step BM25 retriever, significantly outperforms the one-step BM25 retriever used in the baselines [3, 8]. The bar chart below clearly shows the recall improvement:

![The image is a bar chart comparing retrieval recall between two methods: one-step retrieval and ProgramFC. It displays data for different tasks: 

- **HOVER (2-hop):** One-step Retrieval (73.18), ProgramFC (77.13)
- **HOVER (3-hop):** One-step Retrieval (51.33), ProgramFC (59.17)
- **HOVER (4-hop):** One-step Retrieval (36.43), ProgramFC (49.93)
- **FEVEROUS-S:** One-step Retrieval (76.25), ProgramFC (85.65)

ProgramFC shows higher retrieval recall in all categories compared to One-step Retrieval.](image8)

The largest improvement is observed on HOVER 4-hop, with a 37.1% increase [8]. This demonstrates that iterative retrieval, guided by the reasoning program, is more effective at finding relevant evidence [8].

In summary, PROGRAM FC demonstrates superior F1 scores compared to FLAN-T5 across various model sizes and task complexities, and its iterative retrieval method exhibits significantly better recall than one-step retrieval.

PROGRAM FC's performance is compared against several models, including FLAN-T5, InstructGPT, Codex, and others, across various fact-checking tasks. In the gold evidence setting, PROGRAM FC, leveraging the same FLAN-T5 model for sub-tasks, outperforms direct claim verification with FLAN-T5 across all four datasets. The improvement is particularly significant for more complex reasoning tasks, such as 4-hop claims, where PROGRAM FC shows a 14.9% improvement in the gold evidence setting and a 6.7% improvement in the open-book setting [5].

PROGRAM FC demonstrates superior performance, especially when the model size is smaller. The decreasing performance trend with smaller model sizes is less notable for PROGRAM FC than for the end-to-end FLAN-T5 model [7].
![Performance comparison across model sizes](image3)

In open-domain settings, PROGRAM FC enhances the retrieval of relevant evidence. It outperforms one-step retrieval on all datasets, with the most significant improvement (37.1%) observed on HOVER 4-hop [12].
![Retrieval recall comparison](image1)

When examining error trends, a study of 300 claims where PROGRAM FC incorrectly predicted veracity labels on the HOVER dataset (2-hop, 3-hop, and 4-hop) revealed several key points [6]. Notably, no syntax errors were found in the generated programs, indicating the effectiveness of Codex in generating executable programs [1].
![Error distribution across hops](image7)
However, semantic errors increased with claim complexity, with structural errors becoming particularly prevalent in 4-hop claims [11].

In terms of overall performance compared to other models like InstructGPT, PROGRAM FC shows mixed results. While it outperforms PROGRAM FC on HOVER 2-hop and FEVEROUS, chain-of-thought prompting performs worse on HOVER 3-hop and 4-hop [10].
![Model performance on HOVER and FEVEROUS datasets](image6)

In summary, PROGRAM FC generally outperforms other models, especially in complex reasoning tasks and with smaller model sizes, but it shows an increasing trend of semantic errors as the complexity of the claims increases.

The analysis of error types and model performance across varying complexities (2-hop, 3-hop, and 4-hop) in the HOVER and FEVEROUS datasets reveals several key trends.

**Error Types:**

A breakdown of error types shows a shift in the distribution as the complexity increases [8].
![Error distribution across different hop levels](image4)
*   **Syntax Errors:** Remain consistently at 0% across all hop levels, indicating the model has no problem to follow defined grammar [8].
*   **Semantic Errors:** Increase significantly with complexity, from 29% in 2-hop to 77% in 4-hop scenarios [8]. This category includes incorrect or missing arguments/variables (Token), incorrect program structure (Structure), and incorrect sub-task calls (Subtask) [8]. Structural errors become particularly prevalent in 4-hop claims [11].
*    **Incorrect Execution:** Decreases as complexity increases, dropping from 71% (2-hop) to 23% (4-hop) [8]. This suggests that while the model may generate a correct program, the underlying question answering or fact-checking modules fail more often in simpler cases [5].

**Model Performance:**

Performance trends also vary with complexity.
![Performance on HOVER 2-hop, 3-hop and 4-hop](image3)
*   **PROGRAM FC:** This model demonstrates increasing effectiveness as the reasoning depth increases, outperforming baselines on average by 10.38%, 11.37%, and 14.77% on 2-hop, 3-hop, and 4-hop claims respectively, in the HOVER dataset [4].
*   **Chain-of-Thought (CoT) Prompting:** Shows improved performance over direct prompting, highlighting the importance of step-by-step reasoning, but is outperformed by PROGRAM FC on HOVER 3-hop and 4-hop [7].
    ![Performance on HOVER and FEVEROUS.](image1)
* Other models' performances can be seen in the image below.
![Performance on HOVER and FEVEROUS.](image3)

**Overall, as complexity increases, semantic errors in program generation become more prevalent, and models that can perform effective multi-step reasoning, like PROGRAM FC, show superior performance.**

The "hard-to-contrast" strategy generally outperforms other active querying strategies across various datasets, particularly in the initial stages of active learning [3, 5, 6].

On medical imaging datasets such as PathMNIST, OrganAMNIST, and BloodMNIST, the "hard-to-contrast" strategy shows significant improvements over random selection and other strategies by querying a small portion of the dataset [3]. For instance, on PathMNIST, it outperforms random selection by 1.8% by querying just 0.1% of the entire dataset. Similar improvements are observed on OrganAMNIST (2.6%) and BloodMNIST (5.2%) [3].
![Performance comparison across datasets](image3)

The performance of "hard-to-contrast" data as an initial query consistently leads to better model performance throughout subsequent active learning cycles [5, 6]. This strategy mitigates the cold start problem in active learning [8].
![Impact of label diversity on performance](image5)

The "hard-to-contrast" strategy, combined with K-means clustering and contrastive features, ensures 100% class coverage in most low-budget scenarios [10].
![Initial query strategies comparison](image1)

"Hard-to-contrast" data are identified using pseudo-labels, which means the method does not require ground truth labels, making it practical for real-world applications where labeled data is scarce [3, 1].
![Data map by pseudo-labels for CIFAR-10-LT](image7)

In summary, the "hard-to-contrast" strategy offers a label-free approach that effectively addresses the cold start problem by improving both initial query selection and overall active learning performance across various datasets.

The study investigates the impact of various prompt designs on the performance of LLMs, specifically focusing on ChatGPT and Codex [7]. Different instruction formats, demonstration numbers, and selection strategies are examined to see how they affect performance on the FewNERD dataset [7].

The left graph shows the F1 scores for different instruction formats (I0 to I5), with performance varying across these formats. Some instruction formats result in higher F1 scores than others, indicating that the way instructions are phrased can significantly influence the effectiveness of the models [7].
![Performance with different instruction formats](image7)
The performance of ChatGPT and Codex is also influenced by the number of demonstrations provided. The sentence embedding strategy generally performs better than random sampling when choosing demonstration samples. The Efficient Prompt Retriever (EPR) strategy shows the highest performance among the selection strategies [7]. Because of the simplicity of the sentence embedding, it is preferred over EPR [2].

In summary, different instruction formats, the number of demonstrations, and the selection strategy significantly impact ChatGPT and Codex's performance on the FewNERD dataset, with variations observed across different configurations and strategies.

The SCITAB dataset involves a variety of reasoning steps and challenges in verifying scientific claims. The most common reasoning steps, derived from analyzing 100 samples and 476 atomic reasoning steps, include [10]:

*   **Simple lookup** (20.6%): Retrieving a specific value from a cell.
*   **Comparison** (19.5%): Comparing two numbers.
*   **Closed-domain knowledge** (12.1%): Extracting information from table captions or titles.
*   **Open-domain knowledge** (5.3%): Using external information required by domain experts.
*  **Commonsense knowledge** (5.3%): using commonsense knowledge to verify claims

These functions are essential for data analysis within the dataset.
![Table showing data analysis functions, their descriptions, and proportions.](image6)

The challenges in verifying claims are reflected in the reasons for refuted or unverifiable (NEI) claims. For refuted claims, common issues include [5]:

*   Incorrect calculation results (41.7%).
*   Incorrect approximation words (33.3%).

For NEI claims, the main challenges are [8]:

*   Insufficient evidence in the table (33.3%).
*    Lack of background knowledge, both open-domain (25.0%) and closed-domain (15.0%).

![Table outlining reasons for refuted and NEI claims.](image8)

Claims in SCITAB can also require multiple reasoning steps, some times up to eleven steps, for verification [12].
![Histogram of reasoning steps in dataset claims, showing shallow and deep claim distributions.](image4)

The verification of claims in the dataset includes examining the reasoning graph.
![An example of the reasoning graph.](image1)

In summary, the most common reasoning steps in the SCITAB dataset are simple lookups, comparisons, and using closed-domain knowledge, while the main challenges involve incorrect calculations, incorrect approximation words, insufficient evidence, and a lack of necessary background knowledge.

The main reasoning functions in the SciTab dataset, along with their usage proportions, are detailed in the provided data. The functions range from simple lookups to more complex operations:

*   **Simple lookup (20.6%)**: Retrieves a specific cell value.
*   **Comparison (19.5%)**: Compares two numbers.
*   **Closed-domain knowledge (12.1%)**: Extracts information from context within the table caption or article.
*   Other functions include *Open-domain knowledge*, *Commonsense knowledge*, *Subtract*, *Divide*, *Rank*, *Different / Same*, *Add*, *Max / Min*, *Col / Rowname*, *Trend same/different*, and *Set check*, each with decreasing proportions [7].
![Reasoning functions usage.](image7)

These reasoning functions correlate with the complexity of reasoning steps depicted in the dataset’s distribution.
![Reasoning step distribution.](image3)

The distribution shows that a significant portion of claims require multiple reasoning steps ("deep" claims), with the most frequent being 5 steps (20%) [3]. This complexity is further evidenced by the fact that SciTab has a maximum of 11 reasoning hops, the highest among the compared datasets [1].
![Dataset comparison](image1)

The variety of reasoning types of tasks like *numerical reasoning* [6, 11], and operations, and the need for multiple steps to verify claims, showcase the intricate nature of the SciTab dataset.

The main reasoning functions and their usage proportions in the SciTab dataset highlight the complexity, with a significant number of claims requiring multiple, diverse reasoning steps.

The SciTab dataset features a variety of reasoning types, each with specific proportions, influencing both the distribution of reasoning steps and the types of errors encountered. The functions involved in data analysis, as part of the reasoning types, are detailed as follows [6]:

*   **Simple lookup (20.6%)**: Retrieving a specific cell's value.
*   **Comparison (19.5%)**: Comparing two numerical values.
*   **Closed-domain knowledge (12.1%)**: Extracting information from context within the table caption or article.
*   **Open-domain knowledge (5.3%)**: Gathering additional domain-specific information.
*   **Commonsense knowledge (5.3%)**: Applying general knowledge to verify claims.
*   **Subtract (5.3%)**: Calculating the difference between two numbers.
*    **Divide (5.3%)**: division of two numbers.
*    **Rank (5.3%)**: Determine the rank of a set of numbers.
*   **Different / Same (5.3%)**: Determine if two numbers are different or the same.
*   **Other operations**: Including Add, Max/Min, Col/Row name, Trend analysis, and Set check, each contributing less than 5% [6].
![Data analysis task and proportions](image6)

These reasoning types are intertwined with the distribution of reasoning steps, which can be categorized into "shallow" (1–2 steps) and "deep" (3 or more steps) claims [image2].
![Reasoning steps distribution](image2)

Error analysis within the SciTab dataset reveals common issues [8]:

*   **Grounding errors (50%)**: Incorrectly associating data with table cells [image5].
*   **Ambiguity errors (22%)**: Misinterpreting ambiguous expressions in claims [image5].
*   **Calculation errors (20%)**: Inaccurate arithmetic [image5].
*   **Program errors (8%)**: Mistakes in program arguments, variables, or operations [8, image5].
![Error types and proportions](image5)

The reasons for refuted claims include incorrect calculation results (41.7%), wrong approximation words (33.3%), and partially correct claims (10.0%) [image3]. For claims labeled as NEI (Not Enough Information), issues include insufficient evidence (33.3%), lack of open-domain knowledge (25.0%), and lack of closed-domain knowledge (15.0%) [6, image3].
![Reasons for Refuted and NEI Claims](image3)

An illustrative example from the dataset highlights how these elements combine [2, image1]: a claim about a word's productivity is supported by verifying data in the table, using commonsense and closed-domain knowledge to perform a subtraction, confirming the claim's validity [image1].
![Example of a supported claim from SCI TAB](image1)

In summary, the main reasoning types in the SciTab dataset include simple lookups, comparisons, and various knowledge extractions, with grounding and ambiguity errors being prominent, and refuted claims often stem from calculation or approximation inaccuracies.

The primary reasons for refuted claims in the SCITAB dataset are varied. The most common reason is an incorrect calculation result (41.7%), followed by incorrect approximation words (33.3%), and claims that are only partially right (10.0%) [7]. Other reasons include mismatched values and incorrect operation types [7].
![Reasons for refuted and NEI claims in the dataset.](image7)

Regarding the performance of large language models (LLMs) in fact-checking these claims, the results differ between zero-shot and in-context settings, and also depend on whether it's a 2-class or 3-class classification [12]. In general, open-source LLMs do not achieve very promising results on SCITAB, and there's a substantial gap compared to human performance [2]. Counter-intuitively, table-based LLMs do not outperform models pre-trained on pure texts [8].

![Comparison of large language model performances](image5)

When comparing different models, the performance in the 3-class setting (Supported, Refuted, NEI) is notably poorer than in the 2-class setting (Supported, Refuted) [5]. This shows the difficulty models face when dealing with the "Not Enough Information" (NEI) class [5].
![Comparison of confusion matrices between InstructGPT and GPT-4 in a zero-shot, 3-class setting.](image4)

The primary reasons for refuted claims in the SciTab dataset include incorrect calculation results, wrong approximation words, partially correct claims, mismatched values, and incorrect operation types, while different large language models show varying performance, generally struggling with the complexity of the dataset, especially in the 3-class setting.

The primary reasons for refuted claims in SciTab include incorrect calculation results (41.7%), wrong approximation words (33.3%), partially correct claims (10.0%), mismatched values (8.3%), and incorrect operation types (6.7%) [6].
![Reasons for Refuted and NEI Claims in SciTab](image6)
For NEI (Not Enough Information) claims, the reasons are insufficient matching evidence (33.3%), lack of open-domain knowledge (25.0%), absence of closed-domain knowledge (15.0%), references to another table (11.7%), vague pronouns (8.3%), and omission of specific information (6.7%) [6].

These reasons significantly impact model performance, especially in a zero-shot 3-class classification setting. Both InstructGPT and GPT-4 struggle with the NEI class [7]. InstructGPT tends to classify supported and refuted claims as NEI, indicating a lack of confidence [7].
![Confusion Matrices for InstructGPT and GPT-4](image7)
GPT-4, conversely, overconfidently categorizes NEI claims as either supported or refuted [7]. This highlights a key challenge in distinguishing whether a claim is verifiable, affecting the models' overall accuracy [7]. The difficulty in accurately predicting the NEI class corroborates observations that differentiating between 'refuted' and 'NEI' is challenging even for human annotators [10].

The primary reasons for refuted claims are incorrect calculations and wrong approximation words, while NEI claims primarily result from insufficient evidence and lack of background knowledge.

The performance of InstructGPT and GPT-4 on the zero-shot 3-class classification task can be compared using their confusion matrices.  InstructGPT shows a tendency to classify claims as "NEI" (Not Enough Information), indicating lower confidence.
![image8](image8) shows that InstructGPT predicted a significant portion of both supported (26.8%) and refuted (23.6%) claims as NEI. [6]

In contrast, GPT-4 exhibits "overconfidence," often misclassifying NEI claims as either supported or refuted. ![image8](image8) shows that GPT-4 incorrectly categorized 10.3% of NEI claims as supported and 8.5% as refuted. This "corroborates our earlier observation that distinguishing whether a claim is verifiable is one of the key challenges for SCITAB" [6].

Error analysis further highlights the performance differences.
![image3](image3) Grounding errors (50%) and ambiguity errors (22%) are significant contributors. [5]
Also, Refuted Reasons and NEI Reasons listed in
![image2](image2).
All models, except for GPT-4, achieve only marginally better F1 scores than random guessing [8]. However, GPT-4 significantly outperforms other models, achieving a macro-F1 score of 64.80 in the 3-class setting [10].
Closed-source LLMs like GPT-4 generally perform better than open-source LLMs on this task [10].
![image1](image1) Human performance is substantially higher than all models, highlighting the difficulty of the task. [2]

In summary, GPT-4 outperforms InstructGPT in the zero-shot 3-class classification task, but both models struggle with different aspects of the task, with InstructGPT being less confident and GPT-4 being overconfident in its classifications.

InstructGPT and GPT-4 exhibit distinct performance characteristics and error patterns in zero-shot 3-class classification tasks. The confusion matrices reveal that both models struggle with the NEI (Not Enough Information) class, but in different ways [1].

![Confusion matrices for InstructGPT and GPT-4 in the zero-shot 3-class setting.](image3)

InstructGPT tends to be "less confident," often classifying supported and refuted claims as NEI [1]. This is evident in the confusion matrix where a significant portion of both supported (26.8%) and refuted (23.6%) claims are misclassified as NEI.

GPT-4, conversely, displays "overconfidence," frequently categorizing NEI claims as either supported or refuted [1]. The confusion matrix shows that GPT-4 incorrectly labels a substantial number of NEI claims as supported (10.3%) or refuted (8.5%).

These error tendencies highlight a key challenge in the SCITAB dataset: determining whether a claim is verifiable [1].
In addition, the proportions of error types are available.

![The error types and their estimated proportions.](image8)

Grounding errors are the most prevalent, accounting for 50% of the errors, followed by ambiguity errors at 22%, calculation errors at 20%, and program errors at 8% [12].

In summary, InstructGPT is more prone to under-classify claims as NEI, while GPT-4 tends to over-classify claims as supported or refuted, which reflect differing error tendencies and accuracy levels in handling the NEI class.

The confusion matrices for InstructGPT and GPT-4 in the zero-shot 3-class setting reveal specific challenges each model faces with the NEI (Not Enough Info) class [5].

InstructGPT demonstrates a "less confident" pattern, often misclassifying supported and refuted claims as NEI [5].
![InstructGPT Confusion Matrix](image7)
Specifically, InstructGPT incorrectly classifies a significant portion of both supported (26.8%) and refuted (23.6%) claims as NEI. This indicates a tendency to default to NEI when uncertain [5].

GPT-4, in contrast, shows an "over-confidence" pattern, misclassifying NEI claims as either supported or refuted [5].
![GPT-4 Confusion Matrix](image7)
GPT-4 incorrectly categorizes 10.3% of NEI claims as supported and 8.5% as refuted, suggesting it struggles to recognize when there is insufficient information to verify a claim [5]. This difference is quite pronounced, as it classifies NEI claims to verifiable ones.

The main difference is that InstructGPT tends to err on the side of uncertainty, frequently choosing NEI, while GPT-4 tends to be overconfident, incorrectly labeling NEI claims as supported or refuted.
