Llama 2-Chat models demonstrate strong safety performance in comparison to other AI models [1, 7].

The safety evaluations show that Llama 2-Chat models generally have lower violation percentages, indicating that they are considered safer [1, 8].
![Safety evaluation results comparing Llama 2-Chat models with other open-source and closed-source models.](image1)
For instance, Llama 2-Chat models exhibit a lower overall violation percentage across various model sizes when compared to models like MPT, Vicuna, Falcon, PaLM Bison, and ChatGPT [8].

The training process of Llama 2-Chat contributes significantly to these safety features.
![Flowchart of Llama 2-Chat training process.](image6)
The process begins with pretraining using self-supervised learning on pretraining data to develop Llama 2 [6]. It is followed by supervised fine-tuning to create an initial version of Llama 2-Chat [6]. Human feedback is utilized to develop both Safety and Helpful Reward Models. Subsequently, Reinforcement Learning with Human Feedback (RLHF) is employed, using techniques like Rejection Sampling and Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) for iterative refinement [6]. This iterative process, involving safety-specific data annotation, tuning, red-teaming, and iterative evaluations, enhances the safety of the models [7].

Adding more safety data into model RLHF in a quantitative manner makes Llama 2-Chat become safer responding to unsafe prompts [3].

In conclusion, Llama 2-Chat models outperform other open-source chat models in safety benchmarks and demonstrate comparable or lower violation percentages, thanks to their comprehensive training process that includes iterative refinement and safety-specific data.

The environmental impact of LLaMA 2 models is quantified in terms of computational resources and carbon emissions during the pretraining phase [7]. A cumulative total of 3.3 million GPU hours was used, with an estimated total emission of 539 tons of CO2 equivalent. These emissions were completely offset by Meta's sustainability program [7].

The details of computational time, power consumption, and carbon emissions for each LLaMA 2 model size (7B, 13B, 34B, and 70B) are shown here:
![Environmental impact data for LLaMA 2 models](image8)

LLaMA 2 models show varied performance across different benchmarks. The 70B model outperforms all open-source models [6]. It's close to GPT-3.5 on MMLU and GSM8K, but there is a significant gap in coding benchmarks [9]. LLaMA 2 (70B) is on par with or even better than PaLM (540B) on nearly all benchmarks. However, there is still a notable performance difference between LLaMA 2 (70B), GPT-4, and PaLM-2-L [9]. The performance scores are summarized as follows:
![Performance scores of LLaMA 2 compared to other models.](image1)
LLaMA 2 models outperform LLaMA 1 models, and the 7B and 34B LLaMA 2 models perform better than Falcon 7B and 40B models across all benchmark categories [6].
![model comparisons across various performance metrics.](image2)

In conclusion, LLaMA 2's environmental impact during pretraining is substantial but offset, and its performance is generally superior to comparable open-source models and competitive with some closed-source models.

LLaMA 2 models demonstrate significant improvements over their predecessors and other open-source models across a range of benchmarks [3, 4]. LLaMA 2 70B, in particular, outperforms all open-source models [3].

![Comparison of various models across different performance metrics.](image4)

Specifically, LLaMA 2 70B shows an improvement of approximately 5 and 8 points on MMLU and BBH benchmarks, respectively, compared to LLaMA 1 65B [3]. It also surpasses MPT models of corresponding sizes in all categories except code benchmarks, and outperforms Falcon models across all benchmark categories [3].

In comparison to closed-source models, LLaMA 2 70B is close to GPT-3.5 on MMLU and GSM8K but shows a significant gap in coding benchmarks [11].

![Comparison of language model performance across different benchmarks.](image6)

However, it is on par with or better than PaLM (540B) on almost all benchmarks [11]. LLaMA 2-Chat models also outperform open-source models by a significant margin on both single-turn and multi-turn prompts [7]. The 7B model outperforms MPT-7B-chat on 60% of the prompts, and the 34B model has an overall win rate of more than 75% against equivalently sized Vicuna-33B and Falcon 40B models [7]. Fine-tuned LLaMA 2-Chat models demonstrate superior performance in truthfulness and toxicity compared to Falcon and MPT [5].

In summary, LLaMA 2 models, particularly the 70B variant, outperform other open-source models across various benchmarks and show competitive performance against some closed-source models, with particular strengths in helpfulness, truthfulness, and reduced toxicity, but they still lag behind in coding benchmarks compared to models like GPT-3.5.

The impact of removing knowledge elements on precision, recall, and F1-score is examined within the "Conscious Incompetence" setting and retrieval analysis.

In the "Conscious Incompetence" setting, as more knowledge is removed:

*   Precision increases significantly.
*   Recall remains relatively stable.
*   F1-Score shows a moderate increase.

This is visually represented in a line graph:  ![The image is a line graph titled "Experiment Result on Conscious Incompetence.” It shows the relationship between the number of knowledge elements removed and three metrics: precision, recall, and F1-Score.](image1)

The graph shows precision (blue line) increasing as more knowledge is removed, recall (orange line) staying relatively constant, and the F1-score (green line) moderately increasing [10]. This trend suggests that with more absent knowledge, the models, using the \[NA] indicator, are better able to pinpoint the missing information, thus increasing precision [10]. The stable recall indicates the models can, to some extent, identify that knowledge is absent [10].
The specific changes in these metrics as knowledge elements are removed can be observed to change.
![The table displays the following data across five columns: "Removed", "Corr.", "Prec.", "Rec.", and "F1."](image2)
With removal of required knowledge elements, the precision, recall and F1 scores drops drastically [9].

In retrieval analysis, the removal of knowledge elements, simulated by decreasing retrieval accuracy, leads to a decrease in all metrics (precision, recall, and F1-score), in retrieval analysis [7].
![The image is a line graph titled "Retrieval Analysis," showing the evaluation of generated texts using knowledge graphs. The x-axis represents "Retrieval Accuracy" with values at gold (100), 80, 60, 40, and 20. The y-axis represents the "Score."](image7)

The graph shows that all metrics (Precision, Recall, F1-Score and Correctness) decrease as retrieval accuracy goes down [1].

The decline in recall is nearly linear with decreasing retrieval accuracy [1]. This is because a knowledge element cannot be cited if it is not provided [1]. The impact on recall is much more significant than on precision [1]. The model's ability to filter out incorrect knowledge results in a less noticeable impact on precision [1].

In summary, removing knowledge elements increases precision but keeps recall stable in the "Conscious Incompetence" setting, while all metrics decrease with lower retrieval accuracy in retrieval analysis.

The integration of logical constraints and demonstration samples significantly influences model performance on the MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank datasets.

  When the number of demonstration samples increases from 1 to 5, there's a noticeable improvement in performance; however, improvements become limited with further increases (e.g., ≥10) [1].
  This trend is visible in the Micro-F1 scores across different models.
  ![Performance improvements with increasing demonstrations](image1)
Adding logical constraints to the LLM instructions provides stable improvements, especially when more demonstrations are used [1].
  Incorporating logical constraints with a smaller number of demonstrations can even outperform prompts that only have a larger number of demonstrations [1].
  For example, 5 demonstrations with logical constraints on MAVEN-ERE (25.7%) surpass 10 demonstrations without logical constraints (24.5%) [1].

  Pre-training models with logical constraints also substantially boosts performance.
  ![Pretraining enhances model output](image4)
For instance, Llama2-13B-PT, trained on a dataset ( LLM-LR ) with logical constraints, shows considerable improvement [3].
  This configuration helps achieve higher Micro-F1 scores and lower Logical Inconsistency (LI) [3].
![Improved performance with pre-training](image3)
The use of different logical constraint methods, including generative, retrieval, and pre-training, demonstrates that logical constraints play a crucial role in refining the accuracy of LLM outputs.
  ![Approach incorporating logical constraints](image2)
  The performance varies with different models and configurations, as shown by the use of all logical constraints, retrieved logical constraints, and post-processing steps [7].
  ![Impact of logical constraints on model performance](image7)
  It is also helpful to provide relevant logic to LLMs, that improves performance, while irrelevant logic leads to fluctuations [4].

In conclusion, using logical constraints and demonstration samples improves model performance, with logical constraints offering stable improvements, especially when combined with pre-training.

The comparison between using logical constraints and post-processing to reduce logical inconsistency in LLMs reveals distinct outcomes based on the dataset and implementation method.

In the MAVEN-ERE dataset, incorporating logical constraints directly into the model's instructions significantly improves performance. For instance, Llama2-13B-PT achieves a Micro-F1 score of 26.4% with logical constraints, compared to lower scores without them [7]. Post-processing guarantees the elimination of logical conflicts, resulting in a Logical Inconsistency (LI) of 0% [1]. However, this method may compromise the overall quality of generation because the semantics of the post-processed answer may deviate significantly from the ground truth due to random selection processes [1].

For the Causal-TimeBank dataset, similar trends are observed. Llama2-13B-PT shows the highest Micro-F1 score of 13.3% when logical constraints are used [7]. Again, post-processing ensures 0% LI [1], but as with MAVEN-ERE, this comes with potential reductions in the quality of the generated content [1].

The tables highlight these differences, with models like GPT-4, Vicuna, and Llama2 showing varying degrees of improvement when logical constraints are applied versus when post-processing is used. Specifically, the table in image1 shows that all models achieve 0% LI with post-processing.
![Comparison of model performance on MAVEN-ERE and Causal-TimeBank datasets using different methods.](image1)

In summary, while post-processing guarantees the absence of logical inconsistencies, incorporating logical constraints directly into LLM instructions is more effective at improving the overall performance and quality of generation, as evidenced by higher Micro-F1 scores across both datasets.

The MMMU dataset is structured to cover a wide array of disciplines, with a specific focus on challenging, expert-level questions. Within this framework, the distribution of questions across disciplines such as Business and Health & Medicine, along with examples of the specific types of questions included, provides insight into the benchmark's design [3, 7].

The distribution of questions across the six core disciplines shows that Business accounts for 14% of the total questions and Health & Medicine accounts for 17% [![image6](image6)]. This distribution highlights the significant presence of both disciplines within the dataset, aiming to test models on a wide spectrum of domain-specific knowledge and reasoning skills.

Specifically, the breakdown within these disciplines is as follows:

MMMU is designed to assess expert-level multimodal understanding and reasoning across various disciplines [1, 2, 3]. MMMU requires deeper joint interpretation of images and text, necessitates recalling domain-specific knowledge, and involves step-by-step reasoning to derive solutions [2, 10].

The benchmark consists of 11.5K questions, with a distribution of 150 for the development set, 900 for validation, and 10,500 for the test set [4]. The MMMU benchmark evaluates model performance across various difficulty levels and image types, revealing key insights and errors, particularly for GPT-4V.

Across difficulty levels, GPT-4V consistently outperforms other models, showing a success rate of 76.1% in the "Easy" category, significantly higher than open-source models [11]. The table in the provided image shows GPT-4V's scores: 76.1 for Easy, 55.6 for Medium, 31.2 for Hard, and an overall score of 55.7.  ![Performance Comparison Across Difficulty Levels](image8)
However, as task complexity increases, the performance gap diminishes, with GPT-4V's advantage nearly disappearing in the "Hard" category, indicating limitations in handling expert-level queries [8].

For different image types, GPT-4V consistently leads by a large margin [12]. Open-source models perform relatively well with common image types like Photos and Paintings but struggle with less frequent types such as Geometric shapes, Music sheets, and Chemical structures [12]. Performance of various models across different image types, with GPT-4V consistently outperforming others. ![Model Performance Across Image Types](image3)
Open-source models like BLIP2-FLAN-T5-XXL and LLaVA-1.5 achieve around 34% accuracy [10].

Key errors encountered by GPT-4V were analyzed in 150 randomly sampled instances, revealing that 35% of errors are perceptual, 29% result from a lack of knowledge, and 26% are due to flaws in the reasoning process [10]. The distribution of error types is illustrated in the provided image. ![Distribution of Error Types](image7) One specific error example involves GPT-4V correctly reasoning but misidentifying the order of illustrations. ![Example of GPT-4V Error](image1)

In summary, GPT-4V leads in performance across difficulty levels and image types in the MMMU benchmark, but the performance gap narrows with increasing complexity, and key errors arise from perceptual issues, lack of knowledge, and reasoning flaws.

GPT-4V consistently outperforms other models across a range of tests and difficulty levels [3, 5, 10]. When examining performance across various image types, GPT-4V leads by a significant margin [3].
![Performance Across Image Types](image3)
This is further supported by data on different difficulty levels, where GPT-4V achieves a success rate of 76.1% in the "Easy" category, significantly higher than open-source models [10].
![Performance Across Difficulty Levels](image5)
Even as the complexity increases, GPT-4V maintains a lead, although the performance gap narrows in the "Hard" category, indicating current limitations in handling expert-level challenges [6, 10]. The MMMU benchmark highlights that GPT-4V leads in overall performance, yet there's substantial room for improvement, especially in domains involving complex visual input and heavy reasoning [12]. Overall, GPT-4V achieves an accuracy of 55.7% on the MMMU benchmark, indicating both its advanced capabilities and the potential for further development [2, 5].

In conclusion, GPT-4V performs the best across various test categories and difficulty levels, significantly outperforming other models, though there is still room for improvement, especially in complex tasks.

The performance metrics of LLaVA-1.5-13B and GPT-4V vary significantly across different difficulty levels and subject categories in the multi-modal benchmark.

In terms of difficulty, GPT-4V consistently outperforms LLaVA-1.5-13B across all levels. Specifically, on the "Easy" category, GPT-4V achieves a success rate of 76.1%, while LLaVA-1.5-13B scores significantly lower [6]. In the "Medium" category, GPT-4V's performance is 55.6%, and it further decreases to 31.2% in the "Hard" category [7]. The performance gap narrows as the difficulty increases, but GPT-4V maintains a considerable lead. The overall accuracy of GPT-4V is 55.7% [1].
![Comparison of model performance across difficulty levels](image1)

Across different subject categories, the performance of both models varies. In disciplines where visual data is less complex, such as Art & Design and Humanities & Social Science, models exhibit higher performance [3]. For instance, in Art & Design, LLaVA-1.5-13B shows a better performance relative to other categories but still lags behind GPT-4V [3, 4]. However, in more complex fields like Science, Health & Medicine, and Tech & Engineering, which require more intricate reasoning and complex visual data, the performance of all models, including GPT-4V, is relatively lower [3].
![Model performance metrics across validation and test sets](image3)

LLaVA-1.5-13B achieves an accuracy level of approximately 34%, which is significantly lower than GPT-4V's 55.7% [1].

In summary, GPT-4V significantly outperforms LLaVA-1.5-13B across all difficulty levels and most subject categories in the MMMU benchmark, although both models show reduced performance in areas with complex visual data and intricate reasoning.

Several evaluation frameworks focus on both retrieval and generation quality in Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) systems [3]. These frameworks include RGB, RAGAS, ARES, and TruLens [6].

*   **RGB**: Evaluates Noise Robustness, Negative Rejection, Information Integration, and Counterfactual Robustness, using metrics such as Accuracy and EM (Exact Match) [2].
    ![Evaluation frameworks, their targets, aspects, and metrics.](image2)
*    **RAGAS**: Focuses on Context Relevance, Faithfulness, and Answer Relevance. The metrics are unspecified in the provided documentation but include Cosine Similarity for certain aspects [2].

*   **ARES**: Assesses Context Relevance, Faithfulness, and Answer Relevance with metrics including Accuracy for all these aspects [2].

*   **TruLens**: Also evaluates Context Relevance, Faithfulness, and Answer Relevance, with unspecified metrics, marked as '*' in the documentation [2].
    Context Relevance, Faithfulness, and Answer Relevance are assessed by metrics including Accuracy [7].
    ![Different evaluation metrics or criteria.](image7)

In summary, the evaluation frameworks that focus on both retrieval and generation quality are RGB, RAGAS, ARES, and TruLens, utilizing various metrics and aspects such as Accuracy, EM, Context Relevance, Faithfulness, and Answer Relevance.

The key evaluation aspects for assessing Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) models focus on both retrieval and generation quality, using a variety of metrics to cover different dimensions of performance [7].

For **Retrieval Quality**, crucial aspects include:

*   **Context Relevance**: This assesses how pertinent the retrieved information is to the query. Metrics used here include Accuracy, Exact Match (EM), Recall, Precision, Cosine Similarity, Hit Rate, Mean Reciprocal Rank (MRR), and ROUGE/ROUGE-L [12].
    ![Context Relevance is assessed by Accuracy, EM, Recall, Precision, Cosine Similarity, Hit Rate, MRR, and ROUGE/ROUGE-L.](image1)

For **Generation Quality**, the important aspects are:

*   **Faithfulness**: Measures how factually consistent the generated text is with the retrieved context. Metrics include Accuracy, EM, BLEU, and ROUGE/ROUGE-L.
    ![Faithfulness is assessed by Accuracy, EM, BLEU, and ROUGE/ROUGE-L.](image1)
*   **Answer Relevance**: Evaluates how relevant the generated answer is to the original query. Metrics include Accuracy, EM, and R-Rate.
    ![Answer Relevance is assessed by Accuracy, EM, and R-Rate.](image1)

Several evaluation frameworks employ these aspects and metrics in different combinations:
*In **RGB**, aspects like Noise Robustness, Negative Rejection, Information Integration, and Counterfactual Robustness, use metrics including Accuracy and EM.*
![Evaluation Framework RGB](image4)
*In **RECALL**, the focus is on Counterfactual Robustness, using the R-Rate (Reappearance Rate) as the metric.*
![Evaluation Framework RECALL](image4)
*Frameworks like **RAGAS**, **ARES**, and **TruLens** evaluate Context Relevance, Faithfulness, and Answer Relevance, although the specific metrics can vary (indicated by asterisks in the table for TruLens). ARES, for example, uses Accuracy for all three aspects.*
![Evaluation Frameworks RAGAS, ARES and TruLens](image4)

These frameworks and metrics ensure a comprehensive assessment of RAG models, enabling a detailed understanding of their performance across various dimensions [5].

The key evaluation aspects for RAG models include context relevance, faithfulness, and answer relevance, measured through various metrics such as accuracy, EM, recall, precision, and ROUGE, with different frameworks emphasizing different combinations of these aspects.

The RGB and CRUD evaluation frameworks differ in both their evaluation targets and the specific aspects they assess within Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) models.

RGB focuses on evaluating both Retrieval Quality and Generation Quality [image5]. It specifically assesses four aspects [image5]:
*   Noise Robustness
*   Negative Rejection
*   Information Integration
*   Counterfactual Robustness

These aspects are crucial for understanding how well the RAG model performs under various challenging conditions and scenarios [3]. The metrics used in RGB include Accuracy and EM (Exact Match) [image5].

CRUD, on the other hand, also evaluates Retrieval Quality and Generation Quality but focuses on different application scenarios [image5]:
*   Creative Generation
*   Knowledge-intensive QA
*   Error Correction
*   Summarization,
These cover a broader range of applications. The metrics include BLEU, ROUGE-L, BertScore and RAGQuestEval [image5].

![Comparison of Evaluation Frameworks](image5)

In summary, while both RGB and CRUD assess retrieval and generation quality, RGB is oriented towards robustness and accuracy under stress, whereas CRUD evaluates performance across a variety of practical tasks.

The evaluation frameworks RGB, RAGAS, and CRUD differ in their evaluation targets, aspects, and the quantitative metrics they use, as detailed in the provided table:

*   **RGB** evaluates both Retrieval Quality and Generation Quality. It focuses on aspects such as Noise Robustness, Negative Rejection, Information Integration, and Counterfactual Robustness. The quantitative metrics used are Accuracy and EM (Exact Match) [image1].
*   **RAGAS** also targets both Retrieval Quality and Generation Quality. It assesses aspects like Context Relevance, Faithfulness, and Answer Relevance. It uses Cosine Similarity as a metric, among others not specified (* ) [image1].
*    **CRUD** evaluates Retrieval and Generation quality. Aspects are Creative Generation, Knowledge-intensive QA, Error Correction, Summarization, with metrics BLEU, ROUGE-L, BertScore, RAGQuestEval [image2].

![Overview of different evaluation frameworks.](image1)

These frameworks are crucial for understanding RAG model's ability [5], and their respective strengths and weaknesses in various operational scenarios [7]. The technology stacks are very helpful for RAG's prospect [image2].

![Summary of RAG ecosystem.](image2)

In summary, RGB, RAGAS, and CRUD differ significantly: RGB uses Accuracy and EM for various robustness aspects, RAGAS employs metrics like Cosine Similarity for relevance and faithfulness, and CRUD covers creative and knowledge-intensive tasks using BLEU, ROUGE-L, and others.

Advanced RAG enhances Naive RAG by introducing pre-retrieval and post-retrieval strategies, refining indexing techniques, and incorporating optimization methods to streamline the retrieval process [1]. This is visually represented in the comparison of the three RAG paradigms, where Advanced RAG includes additional optimization strategies before and after the retrieval stage, unlike Naive RAG [4, 5].
![Comparison of Naive RAG, Advanced RAG, and Modular RAG](image5)
Specifically, Advanced RAG refines its indexing techniques using a sliding window approach, fine-grained segmentation, and incorporating metadata [1].
![RAG technology tree](image1)
Modular RAG, on the other hand, offers significant adaptability by allowing module substitution or reconfiguration to address specific challenges [3]. It builds upon the principles of both Naive and Advanced RAG but introduces additional specialized components and more flexible interactions between them [3, 11].
![model optimization methods](image6)
This includes integrating new modules or adjusting the interaction flow among existing ones, which enhances applicability across different tasks. For instance, the Modular RAG framework introduces specialized components such as the Search module, Memory module, and Task Adapter module to enhance retrieval and processing capabilities [9].

In summary, Advanced RAG improves upon Naive RAG through optimized retrieval and indexing strategies, while Modular RAG enhances retrieval-augmented generation by introducing a flexible, modular architecture that can adapt to various tasks and challenges.

Let's explore the differences between Naive, Advanced, and Modular RAG frameworks in their approach to document retrieval and query processing.

The Naive RAG follows a straightforward process, often described as a "Retrieve-Read" framework [9]. It involves indexing documents, retrieving information relevant to a user query, and then using a language model to generate an output based on the retrieved information [4, 12]. It operates in three steps: indexing, retrieval, and generation.
![Naive RAG](image4)

Advanced RAG builds upon the Naive RAG framework, adding optimization strategies to improve performance. It uses pre-retrieval strategies to optimize the query. [10].
![Advanced RAG](image4)

Modular RAG enhances flexibility by introducing multiple specialized functional modules. [1, 6, 11]. These modules can include routing, searching, rewriting, and fusion, which supports complex interactions. [3].
![Modular RAG](image4)

In summary, Naive RAG is a basic "Retrieve-Read" framework, Advanced RAG adds optimization strategies, and Modular RAG introduces specialized, interchangeable modules for more flexible and complex query processing.

RAPTOR's collapsed tree retrieval method generally outperforms the tree traversal method. Specifically, the collapsed tree approach consistently shows better performance in terms of F1 scores across various context lengths, peaking at 2000 tokens on the QASPER dataset [3].
![Collapsed tree retrieval performs better on the QASPER dataset](image3)
The collapsed tree retrieval offers greater flexibility by searching through all nodes simultaneously, which allows it to retrieve information at the correct level of granularity for a given question [3].

When comparing RAPTOR (which utilizes the collapsed tree method) with DPR, RAPTOR consistently outperforms DPR across multiple evaluation metrics and datasets. On the QASPER dataset, RAPTOR's F1 scores are significantly higher than DPR's when used with different language models like GPT-3, GPT-4, and UnifiedQA [1, 4].
![RAPTOR has better F-1 Match scores than DPR.](image6)
For instance, RAPTOR’s F-1 Match scores are 53.1%, 55.7%, and 36.6% when using GPT-3, GPT-4, and UnifiedQA, respectively, surpassing DPR by margins of 1.8, 2.7, and 4.5 points [1]. Moreover, RAPTOR demonstrates superior performance on other datasets such as QuALITY and NarrativeQA [7, 11].

In summary, the collapsed tree retrieval method in RAPTOR is more effective than the tree traversal method, and RAPTOR shows significantly better performance compared to DPR across various evaluation metrics, including F1 scores on the QASPER dataset.

RAPTOR employs two distinct querying mechanisms: tree traversal and collapsed tree [7]. The collapsed tree method evaluates nodes across all layers simultaneously [11], offering greater flexibility by searching through all nodes at once to retrieve information at the appropriate granularity [9]. In contrast, tree traversal goes layer-by-layer, pruning and selecting the most relevant nodes at each level [11].

The performance comparison between these methods, specifically on the QASPER dataset, indicates that the collapsed tree approach consistently outperforms tree traversal [9].
![Performance comparison of querying methods](image1)
This graph illustrates that the collapsed tree method (green line) achieves higher F1 scores across various context lengths, peaking at 2000 tokens [9].

When comparing RAPTOR's performance with different models across various metrics such as ROUGE, BLEU, and METEOR, RAPTOR generally enhances performance.
![Model performance with and without RAPTOR](image3)
Models enhanced with RAPTOR show improved performance across all metrics compared to those without it [image3].

In summary, the collapsed tree method surpasses tree traversal in performance due to its flexibility in retrieving information across all levels, and RAPTOR demonstrates superior performance metrics when integrated with various language models.

RAPTOR's performance is notably superior across various evaluation metrics and retrieval methods. When combined with UnifiedQA 3B, RAPTOR not only surpasses traditional retrieval methods like BM25 and DPR but also achieves a new state-of-the-art in the METEOR metric on the NarrativeQA dataset [10].

On the QASPER dataset, RAPTOR consistently outperforms BM25 and DPR across all three Language Models (GPT-3, GPT-4, and UnifiedQA) [6, 9].
![Controlled comparison of F-1 scores on the QASPER dataset, using various language models and retrieval methods.](image3)
RAPTOR’s F-1 Match scores are significantly higher, surpassing DPR by margins of 1.8 to 4.5 points and BM25 by 6.5 to 10.2 points, depending on the LLM used [6]. For instance, RAPTOR with GPT-4 sets a new benchmark on QASPER, with a 55.7% F-1 score, surpassing CoLT5 XL's score of 53.9% [2]. Similarly, on the QuALITY dev dataset, RAPTOR outperforms BM25 and DPR by at least 2.0% in accuracy [11].
![Comparison of accuracies on the QuALITY dev dataset for different language models and retrieval methods.](image4)

Regarding the impact of context length on retrieval methods, the collapsed tree approach, which offers greater flexibility and superior performance, is preferred. Specifically, a collapsed tree with 2000 maximum tokens is used, which approximately equates to retrieving the top-20 nodes [7]. This token-based approach ensures that the context does not exceed model context constraints, as token counts can vary across nodes. For experiments with the UnifiedQA model, 400 tokens of context are provided, as UnifiedQA has a maximum context length of 512 tokens [7].

In summary, RAPTOR consistently outperforms traditional retrieval methods across multiple datasets and evaluation metrics, with the collapsed tree approach using a token-based limit to manage context length effectively.

RAPTOR consistently outperforms traditional retrieval methods like BM25 and DPR across various datasets and metrics [5]. For example, in the QASPER dataset, RAPTOR's F-1 scores are at least 1.8% points higher than DPR and at least 5.3% points higher than BM25 across all tested language models (GPT-3, GPT-4, and UnifiedQA) [4].

![image5](image5)

Specifically, when using GPT-3, GPT-4, and UnifiedQA, RAPTOR achieves F-1 Match scores of 53.1%, 55.7%, and 36.6%, respectively [2].
These scores surpass DPR by margins of 1.8, 2.7, and 4.5 points, and BM25 by 6.5, 5.5, and 10.2 points [2].

![image1](image1)

On the QuALITY dataset, RAPTOR also shows superior performance, with accuracy improvements of at least 2.0% compared to BM25 and DPR [8].
In the Narrative QA dataset, RAPTOR excels in metrics like ROUGE-L, BLEU-1, BLEU-4, and METEOR, outperforming BM25 and DPR significantly [1]. It achieves a new state-of-the-art METEOR score in this dataset [7].

![image2](image2)

Moreover, RAPTOR, when combined with any retriever, consistently outperforms the respective retriever across all datasets [10]. Ablation studies confirm the effectiveness of RAPTOR's clustering mechanism, showing improvements in both Accuracy (QuALITY) and Answer F1 (QASPER) scores when compared to configurations without RAPTOR [12].

![image4](image4)

RAPTOR's tree-based retrieval system also demonstrates qualitative advantages, as it can select nodes from different layers of the tree, matching the granularity required by the query [9, 11].
![image3](image3)

In summary, RAPTOR consistently outperforms other retrieval methods, demonstrating superior performance across multiple metrics and datasets.

RAPTOR's performance is notably superior across various evaluation metrics and datasets due to its innovative tree-based retrieval system. This system uses recursive clustering and summarization techniques, creating a hierarchical structure that synthesizes information effectively [12].

On the QASPER dataset, RAPTOR consistently outperforms BM25 and DPR across all tested language models (GPT-3, GPT-4, UnifiedQA 3B), with F1 scores at least 1.8% points higher than DPR and 5.3% points higher than BM25 [2]. Specifically, when paired with GPT-4, RAPTOR achieves a new benchmark F-1 score of 55.7% [10].
![RAPTOR outperforms other methods on the QASPER dataset.](image1)
For the NarrativeQA dataset, RAPTOR excels in multiple metrics like ROUGE-L, BLEU-1, BLEU-4, and METEOR, outperforming BM25 and DPR significantly [1, 8]. It sets a new state-of-the-art in the METEOR metric when paired with UnifiedQA 3B [7, 8].
![RAPTOR shows superior performance across multiple metrics on the NarrativeQA dataset.](image2)
On the QuALITY dataset, RAPTOR also surpasses the baselines of BM25 and DPR by at least 2.0% in accuracy [3].
![RAPTOR's accuracy on the QuALITY dataset exceeds that of BM25 and DPR.](image3)
The querying structure of RAPTOR, particularly its upper nodes, plays a crucial role in handling thematic or multi-hop queries that require a broader understanding of the text [4]. This hierarchical structure allows RAPTOR to capture a range of information, from general themes to specific details, contributing to its strong performance [7]. RAPTOR, when combined with any retriever, consistently outperforms the respective retriever across all datasets [5].

In conclusion, RAPTOR outperforms other retrieval methods due to its hierarchical tree structure and recursive clustering, which enable it to synthesize information effectively and handle complex queries, setting new performance benchmarks across multiple datasets and evaluation metrics.

The inter-annotator agreement is analyzed in the evaluation of Chameleon against other models like Gemini and GPT-4V [9]. These statistics offer insight into the consistency of human judgments when assessing the models' performance. Similar agreement levels are observed when comparing with GPT-4V and their enhanced versions [7].

The text also reinforces that for questions about simple, objective properties, there's rarely complete disagreement among annotators [4]. When there are disagreements on task fulfillment or prompt interpretation, the judgments are usually close rather than opposite [4].

In summary, inter-annotator agreement varies, with high agreement on objective measures and more variability on subjective ones in absolute evaluations, while relative evaluations show a mix of agreement levels, with a significant portion of unanimous or majority agreement.

The multimodal retriever system processes and ranks objects for recognition in detection datasets through a multi-stage pipeline that combines image preprocessing, embedding, retrieval, and ranking steps [6].

Initially, in the preprocessing stage, images from detection datasets undergo cropping and blurring [5]. The images are cropped based on proposal bounding box coordinates, and the cropped regions are resized to a fixed proportion. Non-target areas surrounding the objects of interest are blurred to direct the focus toward the relevant objects.
![Object Recognition Pipeline](image7)

The image embeddings,  $e_{\mathrm{img}}$, are extracted from the cropped and resized images [5]. Unlike image classification tasks, the system employs image-to-text retrieval using CLIP's image-text interaction capabilities due to the small size of the cropped sub-images [12].
![Multimodal Retriever Pipeline](image6)

A multimodal retriever creates and stores multimodal embeddings, optimizing retrieval speed through index construction techniques [11]. During inference, the system retrieves the top-*k* category information with the highest similarity [12]. The retrieved category labels, along with the image embedding, are integrated and sent to Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) through a ranking prompt [7]. MLLMs combine internal knowledge and retrieved information to make a final prediction of the image category [7, 8].
![Reranking Example](image2)

The MLLMs rank the retrieved class names, with the capability of MLLM perform semantic analysis to assess the contextual appropriateness of each class name with the input image [4].
![Ranking Prompt Example](image4)

In summary, the multimodal retriever system processes images by cropping and blurring, extracts embeddings, retrieves the top-k similar categories, and uses MLLMs to rank these categories for object recognition in detection datasets.

The error analysis results for Step-Back + RAG show notable differences between TimeQA and StrategyQA.

On TimeQA, Step-Back + RAG is able to fix 39.9% of the predictions where the baseline prediction is wrong, while causing 5.6% errors [10]. Furthermore, Step-Back + RAG fixes 21.6% errors coming from RAG, The % of errors introduced by S TEP -B ACK P ROMPTING to RAG is still relatively low (6.3%) [10].
![Error Analysis of Step-Back Prompting on TimeQA.](image8)

In contrast, on StrategyQA, Step-Back + RAG turns 15.4% of wrong baseline predictions into correct ones, with a 6.1% error rate [9, 11]. It fixes 12.7% of errors from RAG, introducing only 4.4% new errors [9, 11].
![Error Analysis of Step-Back Prompting on StrategyQA.](image3)

These datasets differ significantly in their composition and focus. TimeQA, a Knowledge QA dataset, includes 5226 examples in its test split, focusing on temporal reasoning [8].
![Example numbers for different datasets.](image6)
StrategyQA, categorized under Multi-hop Reasoning, has 229 examples in its development split and requires strategic thinking to answer questions [8].

In summary, Step-Back + RAG demonstrates a higher error correction rate on TimeQA compared to StrategyQA, likely due to TimeQA's focus on temporal reasoning and larger dataset size, which may allow for better generalization, while StrategyQA's multi-hop reasoning presents a more complex challenge.

Step-Back prompting generally shows significant performance improvements across various tasks compared to other methods like Chain of Thought (CoT) and retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) [8]. Specifically, on Knowledge QA tasks, Step-Back prompting leads to notable performance gains [8].

For instance, on the TimeQA benchmark, Step-Back + RAG achieves a remarkable 68.7% accuracy, substantially outperforming baseline models like GPT-4 and PaLM-2L, as well as other prompting techniques such as CoT and TDB [3].
![Performance across tasks](image2)

In terms of error analysis, Step-Back prompting is helpful most of the time, effectively addressing abstraction before tackling the original question [6]. It fixes 39.9% of the baseline model's wrong predictions while introducing only 5.6% new errors [6].
![Breakdown of errors](image6)

The primary sources of errors in Step-Back prompting are dominated by reasoning, followed by issues with retrieval augmentation (RAG) [2].
![Error types comparison](image7)

Moreover, the performance of Step-Back prompting remains robust regardless of the number of exemplars used in the demonstration, which highlights its sample efficiency [5].
![Accuracy across number of shots](image1)

On specific benchmarks like MMLU Physics and Chemistry, PaLM-2L with Step-Back prompting achieves the highest performance, even surpassing GPT-4 [4].
![Physics and Chemistry benchmarks](image4)

On multi-hop reasoning tasks such as MuSiQue and StrategyQA, the combination of Step-Back and RAG also shows the highest performance [5].
![MuSiQue and StrategyQA benchmarks](image5)

In summary, Step-Back prompting consistently enhances task performance and effectively reduces errors across various benchmarks compared to traditional methods.

STEP-BACK PROMPTING, a technique that enables LLMs to derive high-level concepts and principles, significantly improves performance on various QA tasks [2]. This method, especially when combined with Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), shows substantial gains across multiple benchmarks.

On Multi-Hop Reasoning tasks like MuSiQue and StrategyQA, STEP-BACK PROMPTING combined with RAG achieves the highest performance. Specifically, it scores 42.8% on MuSiQue and 86.4% on StrategyQA, outperforming GPT-4 on both tasks [1].
![Performance on MuSiQue and StrategyQA](image5)

For Knowledge QA tasks, such as TimeQA and SituatedQA, the combination of STEP-BACK and RAG also demonstrates remarkable improvements [11]. On TimeQA, this approach achieves an accuracy of 68.7%, significantly higher than the baseline models [10].
![Performance on TimeQA, TQA Easy, TQA Hard and SituatedQA](image4)

Even on STEM tasks like MMLU Physics and Chemistry, STEP-BACK PROMPTING enhances performance. For instance, PaLM-2L with STEP-BACK PROMPTING achieves 73.2% on MMLU Physics and 81.8% on MMLU Chemistry, surpassing GPT-4's performance on these tasks [2].
![Performance on MMLU Physics and Chemistry](image7)
Overall performance of models can be shown on the chart below.
![Overall Performance of Models](image3)

However, STEP-BACK PROMPTING is not without its limitations. Error analysis reveals that the most common error type is reasoning errors, which account for over 90% of the mistakes in tasks like MMLU Physics [6]. Other error types, although less frequent, include factual errors, math errors, context loss, and principle errors [6, 9].
![Error Analysis](image8)

The performance of STEP-BACK PROMPTING is robust, even with a few-shot demonstration.
![Ablation Study](image1)

In summary, different methods significantly influence QA task performance, with STEP-BACK PROMPTING combined with RAG showing the highest performance, although reasoning errors remain the primary challenge.

Step-Back Prompting with Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) significantly enhances the performance of PaLM-2L across various question-answering tasks.

On TimeQA, PaLM-2L + Step-Back + RAG achieves a remarkable 68.7% accuracy, outperforming other methods, including GPT-4 and PaLM-2L with Chain of Thought (CoT) or Take a Deep Breath (TDB) prompting [2]. This demonstrates the effectiveness of combining high-level concept abstraction with reliable retrieval augmentation [2].
![Performance of Different Methods on TimeQA, TQA Easy, TQA Hard, and SituatedQA](image2)

For MuSiQue, a challenging multi-hop reasoning benchmark, PaLM-2L + Step-Back + RAG achieves the highest performance at 42.8% [3, 4].
![Performance Comparison on MuSiQue and StrategyQA Datasets](image4)

Similarly, on StrategyQA, PaLM-2L + Step-Back + RAG achieves the highest performance, reaching 86.4% [3, 4]. The consistent improvement across these different tasks highlights the power of abstraction provided by Step-Back Prompting in enhancing model performance [1, 3].
![Performance of Different Models Across Various Tasks](image1)

In summary, PaLM-2L with Step-Back and RAG consistently achieves the highest performance across TimeQA, MuSiQue, and StrategyQA, showcasing its effectiveness in diverse question-answering scenarios.

The SnapNTell model's performance is significantly impacted by the inclusion of entity detection (ED) and retrieval augmentation (RA).

The integration of ED into the model leads to improvements across all metrics. Specifically, the model "w/ ED" shows higher scores in ROUGE (35.28), BLEU (7.81), METEOR (29.27), and BELURT (0.55) compared to the model "w/o ED" [7]. This demonstrates that entity detection plays a crucial role in the model's overall effectiveness [2].
![Table showing improved scores across all metrics with Entity Detection (ED)](image7)

Retrieval augmentation also has a positive impact, particularly on long-tailed entities. The performance improvement for torso-to-tail entities is notably higher than for head entities when RA is used [6].
![Table showing accuracy and hallucination changes with retrieval augmentation (RA).](image8)
The table shows a significant increase in accuracy and decrease in hallucination rates across all entity types (Head, Torso, Tail) when using RA [6]. The architecture of the SnapNTell model, which incorporates retrieval augmentation, is shown.
![Diagram of the SnapNTell model architecture with Retrieval Augmentation](image2)
It illustrates the process, taking image-question pairs, detects and recognizes entities by image encoder, and uses retrieval augmentation to source information, the information merges before entering the LLM, resulting in a knowledgeable answer [11].

In conclusion, incorporating entity detection and retrieval augmentation significantly enhances the SnapNTell model's accuracy and reduces hallucination, especially for long-tailed entities.

The SnapNTell model demonstrates superior performance compared to existing baseline models across several metrics [7].

The model's architecture plays a crucial role in its performance. It takes an image-question pair as input and uses retrieval augmentation to source relevant information about the entity in the image [10]. This information, combined with the question, is fed into the word embedding layer. Text embeddings merge with image-projected embeddings before entering the LLM, resulting in a knowledgeable answer [10].
![The image is a diagram of the SnapNTell model architecture. 
](image1)

Specifically, the model incorporates:

1.  **Image Processing**: An image encoder processes the input image, while an entity detection model and entity recognition model identify entities (e.g., "Eiffel Tower") [image1].
2.  **Retrieval Augmentation**: This step uses the identified entities to retrieve additional information from a database [image1].
3.  **Text and Image Fusion**: Projection layers combine image features as embeddings, which are integrated with the text embeddings [image1].
4.  **LLM Processing**: A Large Language Model (LLM) takes the combined embeddings to generate a knowledgeable answer [image1].

The inclusion of entity detection (ED) significantly contributes to the model's effectiveness [2]. The comparison shows marked improvement with ED across all metrics [2].
![The table compares evaluation metrics for two methods, "w/o ED" (without ED) and "w/ ED" (with ED), across four metrics:](image6)

Retrieval augmentation enhances performance, particularly for torso-to-tail entities, and helps address the issue of hallucinations in long-tailed entities [1].
![The table shows changes in accuracy and hallucination rates for different categories (Head, Torso, Tail) with and without RA. Here's a breakdown:](image8)
The SnapNTell model achieved the highest scores of evaluation metrics.
![The table shows a comparison of various methods using four evaluation metrics: ROUGE, BLEU, METEOR, and BLEURT. Each method is associated with a paper:](image5)
In human evaluations, the model also outperformed baselines by displaying a significantly smaller difference when compared to manually annotated ground-truth samples [9].
![The image is a bar chart comparing human evaluation results of different models in terms of win, tie, and lose percentages against the manually annotated ground truth from SnapNTell. 
](image7)

In summary, the SnapNTell model outperforms other models in terms of accuracy due to its retrieval-augmented multimodal LLM architecture and entity detection component.

The SnapNTell model's performance is significantly enhanced by incorporating entity detection (ED) across all evaluation metrics. Specifically, the model "w/ ED" demonstrates improved scores compared to the model "w/o ED" in the following metrics [8]:

Specifically, the SnapNTell model achieves the highest scores in ROUGE, BLEU, METEOR, and BLEURT metrics when compared to other methods such as Instruct-BLIP, BLIP2, Mini-GPT4, LLaVA, Open-Flamingo, COGVLM, and mPLUG-Owl2.  This is evidenced by the scores presented in the comparison table: ROUGE (35.28), BLEU (7.81), METEOR (29.27), and BLEURT (0.55) for SnapNTell, all of which are higher than those of the other methods listed [9].  ![Comparison of SnapNTell with other methods across various metrics.](image6)

Furthermore, retrieval augmentation plays a significant role in the improved performance of SnapNTell, The performance gains from using retrieval augmentation (RA) are substantial, as shown in table, particularly for "tail" entities, which see an 85.3% increase in accuracy and a 6.2% decrease in hallucination [12]. ![Accuracy and hallucination rates comparison with and without Retrieval Augmentation (RA).](image4)

Entity detection (ED) is crucial to SnapNTell's effectiveness. The ablation study comparing performance with and without ED demonstrates that incorporating entity detection significantly improves results across all metrics (ROUGE, BLEU, METEOR, and BLEURT) [7].
![Performance comparison with and without Entity Detection (ED).](image2)

In human evaluations, SnapNTell also outperforms other models. The bar chart shows that SnapNTell has the highest "win" percentage when compared to ground truth annotations, indicating better alignment with human judgment than models like MIni-GPT4, Open-Flamingo, COGVLM, mPLUG-Owl2, and LLaVA 1.5. ![Human evaluation results showing win, tie, and lose percentages against ground truth.](image5)

The SnapNTell process, involves image encoding, entity detection and recognition, retrieval augmentation, and at last using a Large Language Model (LLM) to generate answers, which shows a comprehensive approach of SnapNTell.
![Flowchart of the SnapNTell process.](image1)

In summary, SnapNTell outperforms other methods in both automated evaluation metrics and human evaluations, demonstrating its effectiveness in generating entity-centric, knowledge-rich answers.

The SPECTER model generally outperforms other models across a range of tasks, including document classification, user activity prediction, citation prediction, and recommendation [11]. This is demonstrated by its high scores in metrics such as F1 for classification, MAP and nDCG for user activity and citation prediction, and nDCG and P@1 for recommendation.  Specifically, SPECTER achieves an average performance of 80.0 across all metrics on all tasks, which is a 3.1 point absolute improvement over the next-best baseline.

![Performance comparison of SPECTER and other models across various tasks.](image1)

Furthermore, SPECTER, without any task-specific fine-tuning, outperforms a SciBERT model fine-tuned on specific end tasks as well as their multitask combination [12].
![Performance comparison of different training signals, including SPECTER and SciBERT.](image2)

As for the effects of including additional metadata, such as venue and author information. Adding the venue slightly decreases performance, except on document classification, adding authors as an input (along with title and abstract) also hurts performance [2].
![Effects of including additional metadata.](image5)
The reason might be that tokenization using Wordpieces might be suboptimal for author names, and many author names are out-of-vocabulary for SciBERT [2]. But the fact that SPECTER does not require inputs like authors or venues makes it applicable in situations where this metadata is not available [9].

In conclusion, SPECTER demonstrates superior performance compared to other models across various tasks, and including additional metadata such as venue and author information does not consistently improve, and can even degrade, its performance.

SPECTER consistently outperforms SciBERT across a range of tasks, including document classification, user activity prediction, citation prediction, and recommendation tasks [10, 9]. For instance, in document classification, SPECTER achieves an F1 score of 86.4 on the MeSH dataset, a 2.3 point increase over the best baseline, which includes SciBERT [10].
![Performance comparison of SPECTER and other models across various tasks.](image1)
In user activity prediction tasks, SPECTER shows improvements in MAP scores of 2.7 and 4.0 points on co-view and co-read tasks, respectively, compared to the best baseline [10]. Furthermore, in citation prediction, it outperforms nearly all baselines, with a notable nDCG of 94.8 on co-citation data, surpassing SGC by 2.3 points [10].

![Comparison of SPECTER against different SciBERT fine-tuning signals.](image2)

These performance metrics highlight SPECTER's enhanced ability to generate effective embeddings. Fine-tuning SciBERT on specific tasks is generally found to be inferior to using the fixed representations from SPECTER [12].

![Visualization of document embeddings by SPECTER and SciBERT, showing clustering by academic topic.](image4)

Visualizations of the embeddings using t-SNE projections further reveal that SPECTER's embeddings are better at encoding topical information [8, 3]. The clusters formed by SPECTER embeddings are more compact, indicating a clearer separation of topics compared to SciBERT [3]. Quantitatively, SPECTER achieves higher homogeneity and completeness scores (0.41 and 0.72, respectively) compared to SciBERT (0.19 and 0.63) when using the DBScan clustering algorithm [3]. This suggests that SPECTER embeddings are better at topically grouping.

In summary, SPECTER's performance surpasses SciBERT's across various tasks, and its embeddings demonstrate superior topical clustering, indicating more effective encoding of document-level information.

SPECTER generally outperforms SciBERT when fine-tuned on various signals in document classification tasks. This is demonstrated through several comparisons and analyses.

Quantitatively, the completeness and homogeneity clustering quality measures using the DBScan algorithm for SPECTER are 0.41 and 0.72, respectively, compared to SciBERT's 0.19 and 0.63 [7].

Across the datasets, enhancements to the BERT-MRC models, specifically BERT-MRC+FL, BERT-MRC+DL, and BERT-MRC+DSC, generally show consistent improvements in F1-scores. The degree of improvement varies among the enhancements, with DSC providing the most significant gains.

For the English OntoNotes 5.0 dataset, BERT-MRC+DSC improves the F1-score by +0.96 over the base BERT-MRC model.
![BERT-MRC+DSC shows the greatest improvement in F1-score on the English OntoNotes 5.0 dataset.](image1)
Similarly, on the English CoNLL 2003 dataset, BERT-MRC+DSC shows a +0.29 improvement [11].
![BERT-MRC+DSC demonstrates notable F1-score improvements on the English CoNLL 2003 dataset.](image4)
For Chinese datasets, such as MSRA and OntoNotes 4.0, the BERT-MRC+DSC model also exhibits substantial gains [8].
![BERT-MRC+DSC achieves the highest F1-scores in both the Chinese MSRA and OntoNotes 4.0 datasets.](image5)
The improvements are not limited to Named Entity Recognition (NER) tasks but also observed in Machine Reading Comprehension (MRC) [12] and paraphrase identification tasks [10].
![BERT-MRC+DSC and XLNet+DSC variants achieve the highest scores, showing significant improvements on MRPC and QQP datasets.](image2)
These improvements show that the DSC enhancement is generally more effective at boosting performance compared to FL and DL across different tasks and datasets [1, 11].

In summary, enhancements to BERT-MRC models consistently improve F1-scores across various datasets, with the DSC enhancement providing the most substantial improvements.

The performance of different variations of the BERT model on the English CoNLL 2003 and English OntoNotes 5.0 datasets can be observed in the provided tables. Specifically:

For the English CoNLL 2003 dataset, the BERT-MRC model achieves an F1 score of 93.04. With the DSC enhancement (BERT-MRC+DSC), the F1 score improves to 93.33, showing an increase of +0.29 [12].
![Performance of different models on the English CoNLL 2003 dataset](image5)

For the English OntoNotes 5.0 dataset, the BERT-MRC model achieves an F1 score of 91.11. The DSC enhancement (BERT-MRC+DSC) boosts the F1 score to 92.07, marking an improvement of +0.96 [12].
![Performance of different models on the English OntoNotes 5.0 dataset](image3)

In both datasets, the DSC enhancement consistently improves the performance of the BERT-MRC model.

In summary, different variations of the BERT model show improved performance with the DSC enhancement on both the English CoNLL 2003 and English OntoNotes 5.0 datasets, with F1 score improvements of +0.29 and +0.96, respectively.

The enhancements (FL, DL, and DSC) to the BERT-MRC model consistently improve its performance on the English CoNLL 2003 dataset. Specifically, BERT-MRC+DSC achieves the highest F1 score of 93.33, showing a +0.29 improvement over the baseline BERT-MRC model [10].
![Performance of different models on the English CoNLL 2003 dataset](image3)
This improvement is also observed in the Chinese MSRA dataset, where BERT-MRC+DSC shows the highest F1 score among all tested models [9].
![Performance of different models on two datasets: Chinese MSRA and Chinese OntoNotes 4.0. ](image1)
For the XLNet, The QuoRef dataset, the proposed method(DSC) surpasses XLNet by +1.46 on EM and +1.41 on F1 [4].
![Performance of different models on various datasets for question answering tasks](image2)

In summary, DSC enhancement consistently improves the performance of both BERT-MRC and XLNet models across different datasets and tasks.

The enhancements (FL, DL, DSC) generally improve the performance of both BERT and XLNet models across various datasets and tasks, although the degree of improvement varies.

For the Named Entity Recognition (NER) task, on the English CoNLL 2003 dataset, `BERT-MRC+DSC` improves the F1 score by +0.29 compared to the baseline `BERT-MRC`. Similarly, enhancements show improvements on the Chinese MSRA and Chinese OntoNotes 4.0 datasets, with `BERT-MRC+DSC` achieving the highest F1 scores.
![Performance on the English CoNLL 2003 dataset.](image1)
![Performance on the Chinese datasets.](image2)
On English OntoNotes 5.0 dataset, `BERT-MRC+DSC` shows an F1 score improvement of +0.96 over the baseline `BERT-MRC`.
![OntoNotes 5.0 Dataset Results](image4)

For Machine Reading Comprehension (MRC) tasks, the enhancements also boost performance.
![MRC Task Results](image6)
Specifically, on SQuAD v1.1, `XLNet+DSC` improves the F1 score by +1.25 and the EM by +0.84 over the baseline XLNet [10]. On QuoRef, `XLNet+DSC` surpasses XLNet by +1.46 on EM and +1.41 on F1 [10].

For paraphrase identification tasks, using the MRPC and QQP datasets, `BERT+DSC` and `XLNet+DSC` show the most significant improvements in F1 scores compared to the baseline models.
![Paraphrase Identification Task Results](image5)
However, for sentiment classification tasks, the enhancements do not improve, and can sometimes mildly decrease, performance compared to using cross-entropy (CE) [5].
![Sentiment Classification Task Results](image3)
It is mentioned that the dice loss (DL) and DSC are not accuracy-oriented and should not be used for accuracy-oriented tasks [5].

The effect of hyperparameters in the Tversky index (TI), used in DSC, is also explored, showing that performance varies significantly with different  α  values, indicating the importance of hyperparameter tuning [9].
![Hyperparameter Tuning Results](image7)
DSC helps more on imbalanced datasets [6]. Data imbalance issue is that most tokens are background [8]. Data imbalance results in two issues: the training-test discrepancy and the overwhelming effect of easy-negative examples [1].

In summary, the enhancements, especially DSC, generally improve performance for imbalanced data tasks like NER and MRC, but not for accuracy-oriented tasks like sentiment classification.

Different data augmentation techniques, such as "+Positive," "+Negative," and "-Negative," impact the performance of BERT models differently. These effects are measured primarily through F1 scores across various configurations.

For instance, the "+Positive" technique, which creates a balanced dataset, outperforms the original, while "+Negative," which creates a more imbalanced dataset, underperforms the original [1]. This can be seen quantitatively where "+Positive" generally shows improvements in the F1 score compared to the baseline BERT model, whereas "+Negative" may show mixed results depending on the specific dataset and model configuration. ![\
The performance of different models on two datasets: Chinese MSRA and Chinese OntoNotes 4.0.](image2)

The impact is also seen in the improvement in F1 score. DSC helps even more on the imbalanced '+Negative' dataset [9]. These data augmentation techniques are explored across several datasets. The effect of DL and DSC on sentiment classification tasks is also evaluated [4].

The data augmented technique are exactly the same as +negative, except that we chose negative training examples as templates [5].

Different data augmentation techniques impact BERT model performance, with "+Positive" generally improving and "+Negative" having mixed effects, measured by changes in F1 scores.

The performance differences among various BERT model configurations are notable across different augmentation techniques and datasets.

On the MRPC and QQP datasets, the BERT model shows varying F1 scores. The baseline BERT model achieves an F1 score of 88.0 on MRPC and 91.3 on QQP. With enhancements, `+DSC` shows the most significant improvements, increasing the F1 scores substantially compared to the baseline [1].


Different data augmentation techniques also influence model performance. When positive examples are added (`+Positive`), the performance generally improves. DSC (Dice Loss) consistently performs the best on all datasets, particularly helping more on imbalanced datasets [5].

*   For language pairs where English is the target, the COMET-RANK model demonstrates strong correlations with human judgments, surpassing BLEU in all cases. ![The table presents evaluation metrics for machine translation systems across various language pairs.](image6)
* In non-English language pairs, COMET models maintain consistent results. ![The table presents the performance of various metrics for evaluating machine translation quality across three language pairs](image2)

Dialog State Tracking (DST) models, DS-DST and DS-Picklist, are evaluated based on joint accuracy and slot-level accuracy.

The joint accuracy metric measures the percentage of turns where all predicted triplets (domain, slot, value) are correct [1]. DS-Picklist outperforms DS-DST in terms of joint accuracy, as shown in the provided data: DS-Picklist achieves 53.30% joint accuracy compared to DS-DST's 51.21% on MultiWOZ 2.1 dataset.
![Joint accuracy comparison of different models](image6)

DS-DST model that jointly handles both categorical and non-categorical slots.
![Schematic representation of the DS-DST model architecture](image1)

For slot-level accuracy, the performance varies depending on the slot type. DS-DST shows significant improvements over DS-Span for slots such as `hotel-type`, `attraction-type`, `attraction-name`, `hotel-internet`, and `hotel-parking` [3]. This indicates the effectiveness of using a dual strategy, as some slots are better handled as categorical slots, benefiting from candidate value lists.
![Slot-level accuracy comparison](image2)

DS-Picklist, which treats all slots as categorical, performs slightly better than DS-DST overall [6]. Some slots, such as time-related slots (e.g., `taxi-leave at`, `train-arrive by`), are more effectively handled by DS-Picklist because their values are found on the candidate-values lists [7].

In summary, DS-Picklist has higher joint accuracy, and while both models improve upon DS-Span, DS-Picklist generally performs better on slots where a full ontology is accessible.

The performance of the DS-DST and DS-Picklist models on the MultiWOZ 2.1 dataset can be compared across different slots as shown in the provided data.

The slot-level accuracy on the test set of MultiWOZ 2.1 is detailed, highlighting the absolute performance improvement or degradation compared with DS-Span [12]. The models DS-DST and DS-Picklist generally show significant improvement over the DS-Span baseline for several slots [7]. These slots include `hotel-type`, `attraction-type`, `attraction-name`, `hotel-internet`, and `hotel-parking` [7]. This improvement is because the values for these slots often have different expressions and cannot be extracted directly from the dialog context, which hinders the performance of span-based methods [7].

The table comparing the two models shows that DS-Picklist has a slightly higher average accuracy (97.40%) compared to DS-DST (97.35%) [image2].
![Average Accuracy for DS-Span, DS-DST, and DS-Picklist](image2)

For specific slots, the differences are generally minor, but DS-Picklist demonstrates improvements in areas like `hotel-internet` and `hotel-parking`, likely because their values can be predicted directly from candidate-value lists [7]. While for some slots such as  `taxi-leave at`  and  `train-arrive by`, only few values (i.e., ‘ none ’ and ‘ dontcare ’) can be correctly predicted [2].

Overall, DS-Picklist performs slightly better than DS-DST on the MultiWOZ 2.1 dataset.

The DS-Picklist model demonstrates superior performance compared to both DS-DST and DS-Span in terms of joint accuracy and slot accuracy.

Specifically, examining the joint accuracy on the MultiWOZ 2.1 dataset, DS-Picklist achieves 53.30% [9], outperforming DS-DST, which scores 51.21% [9], and significantly exceeding DS-Span [2].
![Table showing Joint accuracy on the test sets of MultiWOZ 2.1.](image7)

DS-Picklist model's architecture, which can access the full ontology, contributes to its improved performance [1].
![Schematic representation of the DS-DST model architecture.](image1)

In terms of slot-level accuracy on the MultiWOZ 2.1 test set, the DS-Picklist model also generally outperforms both DS-DST and DS-Span across various slot types [12].
![Table showing accuracy for each slot type on the MultiWOZ 2.1 test set.](image6)

Some slots, such as 'hotel-internet' and 'hotel-parking', see substantial improvements with DS-Picklist because their values can be directly predicted from the candidate-value lists [3, 12].
![Table about various "Slot Names" and their corresponding statistics under three categories: DS-Span, DS-DST, and DS-Picklist.](image2)

In summary, DS-Picklist has better performance than DS-DST and DS-Span models regarding joint accuracy and slot accuracy.

The DeClarE model shows varied performance across different datasets and configurations, demonstrating its adaptability to different tasks, including credibility classification and regression.

On the Snopes and PolitiFact datasets, which focus on credibility classification, DeClarE (Full) outperforms LSTM-text and CNN-text models by a significant margin [11]. The inclusion of attention mechanisms and source embeddings improves the model's performance. Specifically, on the Snopes dataset, DeClarE (Full) has a Macro F1-score of 0.79 and an AUC of 0.86, while on the PolitiFact dataset, it achieves a Macro F1-score of 0.71 and an AUC of 0.76 [11].
![Credibility Classification Results](image1)

For the NewsTrust dataset, which involves credibility regression, DeClarE (Full) outperforms all baseline models, including CNN-text, LSTM-text, and CCRF+SWR, achieving the lowest Mean Squared Error (MSE) of 0.29 [2, 6]. This demonstrates a 17% decrease in MSE compared to the best-performing baselines [2].
![Credibility Regression Results](image6)

On the SemEval dataset, which also tests credibility classification, DeClarE (Full) shows superior performance compared to other approaches like NileTMRG and IITP [12]. It achieves the highest Macro Accuracy of 0.57 and the lowest RMSE of 0.604 [3].
![Performance Comparison on SemEval Dataset](image2)

The different configurations of DeClarE, such as Plain, Plain+Attn, Plain+SrEmb, and Full, show how each component contributes to the overall performance [8]. The full model, incorporating both attention mechanisms and source embeddings, consistently performs the best across all datasets.

In conclusion, DeClarE demonstrates strong performance across all datasets, with the full configuration consistently outperforming other models and baselines in both credibility classification and regression tasks.

The analysis reveals distinct differences between the LANI and CHAI datasets in terms of task completion and performance metrics.

For the LANI dataset, which focuses on navigation between landmarks [2], the primary evaluation metrics are Stop Distance (SD) and Task Completion (TC) [11]. "Our Approach" outperforms other methods, showing a lower SD and higher TC [12]. Specifically, "Our Approach" achieves an SD of 8.65 and a TC of 35.72 on the development set.
![Comparative results of different methods on LANI and CHAI datasets.](image7)

In contrast, the CHAI dataset involves more complex instructions combining navigation and manipulation within a 3D house environment [2]. The evaluation metrics for CHAI are Stop Distance (SD) and Manipulation Accuracy (MA) [11]. While "Our Approach" shows improvement in SD, all models, including "Our Approach", perform poorly on manipulation tasks, particularly in MA [12]. For the test data, "Our Approach" on CHAI gives a stop distance (SD) of 3.34, and MA is 39.97.
![Test results on LANI and CHAI, with different methods and metrics.](image3)
The LANI dataset presents a simpler navigation.
![3D navigation environment with landmarks.](image2)

The CHAI instructions require multiple intermediate goals. [2]
![Instructions with multiple intermediate goals in a 3D house.](image6)

In the CHAI, instructions were collected using scenarios that given to workers. [7]
![Scenario for CHAI instructions.](image8)
These instructions often includes multiple intermediate goals. [2]
The CHAI dataset has mean actions per instruction is 54.5, and The LANI dataset has mean actions per instruction is 24.6. [4]
![Statistics comparing LANI and CHAI datasets.](image4)
The performance gap between the two datasets can be attributed to several factors. The CHAI involves multiple sub-goals. [5]

In summary, the key difference is that LANI primarily tests navigation abilities, showing higher task completion rates, while CHAI includes both navigation and object manipulation, with significantly lower performance in manipulation tasks, highlighting the increased complexity of CHAI.

LANI and CHAI are two benchmark tasks designed for different levels of complexity in goal prediction and action generation [3]. LANI focuses on 3D navigation, with instructions for navigating between landmarks, while CHAI, set in a 3D house environment (C HALET), combines navigation with simple manipulation tasks, such as moving objects and opening containers [3].

The performance comparison indicates that "Our Approach" generally outperforms other methods on both LANI and CHAI tasks. Specifically, for LANI, "Our Approach" achieves a lower Stop Distance (SD) of 8.43 and a higher Task Completion (TC) of 36.9, compared to other methods.
![Performance on held-out test set.](image3)
For CHAI, "Our Approach" also shows better performance with an SD of 3.34, although all models perform poorly on manipulation tasks (MA) [4]. Ablation studies demonstrate the importance of various model components, especially the benefit of decomposing learning and using supervised learning for the language problem [7].

Linguistically, the two systems differ significantly in several categories, as shown by the counts and examples in the provided table.
![Comparison of linguistic categories in the LANI and CHAI datasets.](image2)
For instance, LANI has a higher occurrence of spatial relations between locations (123) compared to CHAI (52) [image2]. Additionally, trajectory constraints are present in LANI (94) but absent in CHAI (0) [image2].

Statistically, LANI consists of 6,000 paragraphs with an average of 4.7 instructions per paragraph, whereas CHAI has 1,596 paragraphs with a higher average of 7.70 instructions per paragraph [image8].
![Data statistics for the LANI and CHAI datasets.](image8)
This indicates that while LANI provides a larger dataset focused on navigation, CHAI offers more complex instructions involving both navigation and manipulation [3].

In summary, LANI and CHAI differ significantly, with LANI focusing on navigation with simpler instructions and CHAI involving more complex instructions combining navigation and manipulation, with "Our Approach" showing performance improvements over baseline methods in both systems.

The proposed approach ("Our Approach") is compared against several baseline and existing methods, with performance evaluated using Task Completion (TC) for the LANI dataset and Manipulation Accuracy (MA) for the CHAI dataset.

For LANI, "Our Approach" achieves a TC of 35.72 in development and 36.9 in test. This outperforms the baselines (STOP, RANDOMWALK, MOSTFREQUENT) and the previous methods (MISRA17, CHAPLOT18) [7, 8].
![Table showing LANI TC and CHAI MA of different approaches](image7)
![Table showing LANI TC and CHAI MA of different approaches in test set](image8)
For CHAI, "Our Approach" demonstrates a MA of 39.97 in test, although the development MA is not shown [8]. While the provided quotes do not give specific MA values for other methods on CHAI, it's stated that "all models perform poorly on CHAI, especially on manipulation (MA)," but "Our Approach" shows an improvement on stop distance (SD) [3].

The comparison reveals that decomposing instruction execution into goal prediction and action generation, as done in "Our Approach," significantly improves performance on the LANI navigation task [6]. However, performance on the CHAI task remains challenging for all methods, especially in manipulation accuracy, because CHAI has longer average actions per instruction than LANI [1], highlighting its greater complexity [6].

In conclusion, "Our Approach" shows improved performance in task completion for LANI and offers some gains in manipulation accuracy for CHAI compared to other methods, but CHAI remains a more complex challenge.

The performance of the "Our Approach" method is compared to several baselines and previous methods across two datasets, LANI and CHAI, using metrics such as Stop Distance (SD) and Task Completion (TC) [12].

On the LANI dataset, "Our Approach" outperforms CHAPLOT18, improving task completion (TC) accuracy by 5%, and both methods outperform MISRA17 [5]. The detailed results show that "Our Approach" achieves an SD of 8.65 and a TC of 35.72 [8].

On the CHAI dataset, while all models perform poorly, "Our Approach" shows an improvement on stop distance (SD) [5]. Specifically, "Our Approach" achieves an SD of 2.75 on CHAI [8]. Potential limitations include cascading errors, where action generation relies completely on the predicted goal and is not exposed to the language otherwise [4]. Instructions includes constraints such as trajectory constraints.

The presence of certain linguistic categories has a measurable effect on goal prediction error.
